name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The session, which was interrupted on Thursday, March 15, 2018, resumed.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The US, France and the UK hit military targets on Syrian soil on Friday night. This intervention is the consequence of the Damascus regime's use of chemical weapons towards the civilian population. In view of the seriousness of the situation, I believe it is necessary that Parliament, already today, send a strong message before tomorrow's debate with the High Representative, Mogherini, and the confrontation we will have in morning with the President of the French Republic, Macron. Precisely because the debate within Parliament is considered of great importance, I received a phone call yesterday from the British Prime Minister, Mrs May, who had to inform, through me, the European Parliament that the attack on bases in Syria was an attack aimed at targeting only chemical weapons and not the civilian population. Objective: to prevent these weapons from continuing to use against the civilian population. The second message you have given me and that I transmit to you is that the United Kingdom intends, on the Syrian question, to continue working with the countries of the European Union. A few hours ago also ended a meeting of EU foreign ministers on the situation in Syria. I am convinced that Parliament has to reiterate strongly and clearly today that the use of chemical weapons is unacceptable and that it represents a red line beyond which no one in the world can go. Nor can we resign ourselves to the fact that Syria continues to be a ground for confrontation between global and regional powers and terrorist organisations, who pursue their own careless interests of Very serious suffering that causes to the unarmed civilian population: since 2011 more than 500 thousand people have died and 12 and a half million refugees have been forced to abandon their homes and, among them, 5 millions have left Syria. We must act with greater determination to pursue peace and stability in the Middle Eastern Mediterranean area, strengthening dialogue and diplomacy, with the full involvement of the United Nations. But Europe must play a leading role, because the area of the Mediterranean is the area where Europe can say a lot to prevent violence from ramping up, that war crimes can be carried out and that may recourse to weapons which are prohibited by international conventions. To do this, a strong unity of Europeans is essential: to go in a scattered order would be a serious mistake. The dramatic nature of the situation is to disparage all doubts about the need and urgency to build an increasingly incisive common foreign and defence policy of the Union and the ongoing debate on the next budget is an essential test on our desire to provide ourselves with the resources necessary to be true global actors but, above all, to be bearers, in the world, of the values around which the Union was born European.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, on behalf of the PPE Group. I would like to thank you for the initiative we look to Syria at the start of this plenary week. The ban on chemical weapons was adopted almost a hundred years ago — an international agreement in Geneva — and we must not look the other way if this commitment has now been broken. As you have reported, the intervention measures taken by our American, French and British friends were necessary because a signal had to be sent that we cannot tolerate this action in Syria by Assad and his partners. The use of chemical weapons must not be applied against civilians. From our point of view, the activities of the allies in Syria were proportionate. They were limited to the infrastructure necessary for the use of chemical weapons. From our point of view, however, the time window for diplomacy has also come. Russia must now abandon its blockade in the UN Security Council. And while it is often said that Europe has too little presence in the Syrian conflict, I would like to point out that Europeans have now provided more than EUR 9 billion in humanitarian aid in recent years. We Europeans are partners of those affected and threatened people in the region. The EU is helping, and that is why a European initiative to resolve the conflict must now be launched after these military strikes. Thank you for your initiative, Mr President.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group. It is good that we have this short debate. It is also good, however, that we are having this week's extensive discussion on Syria. The use of chemical weapons is a war crime and has to be stopped. There is no further sentence behind this. But still, allow the question of how all this is coming. And we have to ask this question, because we agree that we need diplomacy, that we need de-escalation, that we now urgently need to strengthen the United Nations. But let us ask critically how we slid into a situation where Russia does not understand where Iran does not understand this — I could look to the north of Syria and say, where Turkey does not understand — that de-escalation is the order of the day. We need to speak clear language — sympathetic, but clear. If Russia wants to demonstrate its strength, it must not be on the back of poisoned children and on the back of attacks against hospitals. If Mr Erdoğan wants to demonstrate his strength, then he does not have to do so in a situation where ISIS has defeated in the north, he has waited so long with his tanks for the Kurds to clean up the conflict field to drive the tanks now. And if Iran wants a future in the modern world, then it must consider its role in this conflict scenario. I have one request: strengthen Mrs Mogherini's back! The European Union must speak with one voice, and we MEPs are calling for an immediate ceasefire, humanitarian aid and a political solution with the binding participation of all parties.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, thank you very much for updating the Chamber on your conversation and your briefing from the British Prime Minister. I know that the British Prime Minister is extremely grateful not only for the European support, but also for the international support shown for these actions that were deemed necessary. All of us, many of us, would have wished that the solution could be achieved through diplomatic aims. We wish it could have been achieved through the United Nations, but we all know that Russia has vetoed no less than six times any attempt to address this issue in the UN. Does that mean it is time for inaction? No. What it means is actually that we have to use this in a targeted way. The American President, the French President and the British Prime Minister have been quite clear that this is not about regime change. It is not about taking sides in a civil war. It is a limited action making sure that we reinstate international norms and rules regarding the use of chemical weapons. The previous speakers have already mentioned how hideous and heinous these crimes are: the use of chemical weapons against your population. We have not been able to solve this purely diplomatically up to now, but now we have sent a message from the international community: limited action based on stopping the use of chemical weapons. Nothing more, nothing less. And let’s all be clear. Whatever our views about other issues and whatever our views about those other issues that divide us in this House, the use of chemical weapons whether on the battlefield, against civilian populations or used to poison individuals, is something that we should all take very seriously. We all know that there are norms that have to be respected, and these norms have been crossed and ignored by the Syrian regime. Let us continue to cooperate as the international community, as well as within the European Union, and let us be clear, but now making sure that we pursue the diplomatic channel with even more vigour, with even more determination, having sent a signal that the use of chemical weapons is clearly unacceptable. Can I thank colleagues from across the Chamber, from across the political spectrum, for their support and the support that they have shown to the national leaders who were involved in the strike.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me be very clear: we support without any reservation the targeted strikes against the chemical facilities. I know there are some people who are making a comparison with the Iraq war. Well, I continue to believe that the Iraq war was a mistake, based on a lie. I was Prime Minister of one of the only European countries that openly opposed that war, and I am still proud of that attitude. But I think that this intervention in Syria is fully justified because it is a regime that has used chemical weapons against its own population – against women, against children – and not for the first time. Different types of chemicals have already been used 73 times, so all you can say about the Assad regime is that it is genocidal and no longer has any legitimacy. I never agree with Donald Trump, but for once, when he tweeted that Assad is a monster, I agreed with him.  At the same time, we also have to be clear – and that has to be our second message – that precision attacks against civilian military facilities are not a strategy for peace and will not end in this. I have to tell you that I am also sad when I see the outcome of the Foreign Affairs Council of today: eleven pages with a very general condemnation and very general statements of principle. I do not think that we can continue like that. We need more than general condemnation. We need a real European strategy in this Syrian tragedy, and I think there are three key elements for such a strategy. The first is to engage all constructive forces in the region in a new initiative. This new initiative must be a roadmap to a new Syria that is democratic, that is neutral, and that is respectful of the different religions that are practised in that country. Finally, I also think that we need to launch new sanctions to increase the costs of those who behave irresponsibly, who violate agreed ceasefires, undermine peace efforts and use these criminal chemical weapons, as has happened in recent weeks. I do not think we can abandon Syria and leave it in the hands of Assad. It concerns our own security and that is the reason why we need to urge the Council to come forward with a consistent strategy towards Syria.  (Applause)

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, chemical warfare is always totally unacceptable and it is very difficult to imagine what kind of a person could bombard his own population with chemical weapons. This is totally unimaginable, and it should not have happened ever. What we need now is that the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) gets a strong a comprehensive mandate, is able to work in Syria, and that such a situation is not repeated. International law needs to be upheld and indeed Russia needs to finally give up its blockade at the UN institutions. All the suffering that we’ve seen for so many years in Syria needs to end. It has lasted way too long. I believe many opportunities have also been missed in the past to find, or at least to have the opportunity to find, a solution. The international community and especially the European Union must do more to stop this war and must develop a political strategy, because air strikes will not end this war. A solution can only be political and diplomatic. It cannot be made by weapons and I think it’s really important that we indeed speak more with one European voice, because if we speak with one voice, we have much more weight behind us. We are much stronger if we speak with one voice and not if we speak with 28 different voices. I am really hoping that we will see increased efforts now to end this war, to stop the suffering of so many millions of women, children, men, so many people who had to flee who are still stuck in Syria. This needs to be our focus of attention.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. My group, and I too, will not be in line with this account of what happened last weekend — the military attack — the military attack. We too condemn the use of chemical weapons and we are in favour of its being obladed that no chemical weapons exist anywhere in the world. And it is precisely in Europe, where chemical weapons were first used in the last century, that we are very sensitive to this. We believe that the use of chemical weapons is a breach of international law, an international law crime, and that must be punished. For this, however, there are political, diplomatic, international bodies, institutions, obligations and agreements. And if — if — one really wants to achieve something, then every effort must be done to get Russia on the side of those who are clearly and clearly opposed to this use of chemical weapons here. I think it's insane to send missiles, allegedly organizing targeted blows! No one has ever explained to us to some extent what has really been destroyed, and I also assume that these blows will not facilitate the political, diplomatic solution. I have never seen in the last two or three years, or in this legislature, how much the deployment has been downplayed through the media, but above all through governments — it was only a targeted effort. It was played with fire! And I do not understand at all that heads of government of the European Union seriously believe that we should stand next to Trump to discuss with him the use of missiles, weapons at all — one who says this today and pushes the other button tomorrow. That cannot be the EU's role! We need to make sure — and I mean one voice — that we say clearly: no, we are not playing Trump's game or Assad's game, but not Putin's. We're not playing for either of the two or the three. We are an independent organization, political power in the world, focusing primarily on de-escalation, diplomacy and strengthening the UN. What happened this weekend is also that the UN Secretary-General has been embarrassed by the fact that he has been presented with facts that have rendered all his commitment null and void. I believe that we should also live up to this responsibility. Incidentally, when you say that the Heads of Government are concerned: above all, people are concerned. People in the Member States are concerned, not only in the EU, but also far beyond. We in Parliament have to face such a game with fire and not press it down again and pretend that everything has just been a little little game.

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, concerning the casus belli, on the verge of outright victory over ISIS in Syria, can anybody explain to the world why Assad would contemplate chemical bombing his own people and risk international opposition and even attack? The Assad government would have nothing to gain at this juncture by the actions of which they stand accused. Regarding the Western reaction, virtue bombing by Western powers without proof of Syrian Government involvement will bring no good. The only people who are celebrating at the moment are the supporters of ISIS and other Islamist groups, who oppose Assad. The clear lack of any long-term strategy in the Middle East and experience of repeated failures in Iraq and Libya do not bode well at this time. This is hellish stupidity by the misguided, misinformed governments of the UK, the USA and France. I remind you that before this awful proxy war kicked off, Syria was one of the very few countries in the Middle East where religious minorities and women were respected in practice and in law. The neo-conservative hawks once again have made the wrong call, with terrible consequences for the many.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the night of Friday to Saturday, France, aligned with the US and British warmongers positions, carried out a series of strikes on Syrian territory. These acts of war were decided unilaterally, without any UN mandate, in total violation of the rules of international law and without even the slightest discussion either within the framework of the United Nations or within the framework of national parliaments. Emmanuel Macron justified these strikes by the alleged use of chemical weapons by the Bashar al-Assad regime against civilian populations. Let us be clear: if chlorine weapons were used, this would of course constitute an ignominy to condemn without any reservation. But at this stage, no shadow of an early evidence has been brought in support of these accusations. It would have been normal to allow the investigation to take place since the OPCW experts had to go there on Saturday. Those who speak of red lines today are nevertheless very discreet when it comes to, for example, the massacres of Yemeni populations by the Saudi regime. Moreover, one can legitimately wonder: what would have been the interest of the Syrian government to use such weapons when, thanks in particular to the decisive action of Russia, 95% of the Syrian territory is now liberated from the yoke of the Islamic State and the Islamist factions that occupied Eastern Ghouta are now completely destroyed? Whatever the Syrian regime might think, this intervention has no real military effectiveness. Tens of millions of euros were spent on an hour of fireworks. There is no strategic interest in this costly operation either. Is it probably a communication action, perhaps an attempt to get back into the game and be able to sit down at the negotiating table? Let's not forget that this is our blindly dogmatic for several years that has excluded us from it. But just like the past Western military actions against Saddam Hussein's Iraq or Gaddafi's Libya have led to strengthening Islamists and sowing war first and then chaos, these strikes against Syria do not correspond to the interests of European nations or the interests of the Syrian people. Indeed, the countries of Europe must ensure that this part of the globe, which is in the immediate vicinity of our continent, is stabilized. In Syria, any weakening of the Damascus regime will allow Islamists to prosper, especially those supported by Saudi Arabia. The total eradication of all jihadist groups must remain our priority, since this objective alone corresponds to both European and Syrian interests.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you to all the chairmen of the groups for expressing a strong position on the Syrian affair and the latest developments: it seems to me that unanimously we are all against the use of chemical weapons; Most of the groups support targeted action to destroy the places of production of chemical weapons; they all call for a strong political initiative by Europe, political and diplomatic action. I hope that the attack carried out will be the last and that the intelligence and desire to dialogue prevail on the part of all, starting with the great powers that have great responsibilities, but also the powers locals — Iran, Turkey, Saudi Arabia — must do their part to help pacify a territory that has suffered for too many years. Because there is not only Syria: there is also Iraq, there is the Israeli-Palestinian conflict; the situation is very intricate. We need Europe to speak with one voice, we need Europe not only to say that it wants peace, but to be the protagonist of peacebuilding. Tomorrow, of course, a thorough debate will take place; we will also discuss this with President Macron, to whom I will report, before his speech in the House, during the interview, what has been said today in this House, then of course there will be a text that will be voted on and which will therefore be the official position of Parliament. Today I broke traditional rules a bit but we couldn't, in the face of what happened, be silent and accept that routine prevailed in the face of emergency. This is a political Parliament which must make its voice heard: we are the representatives of the peoples of Europe and it is right that, although briefly, we have immediately discussed this matter. I thank you for the summary but nevertheless for the active participation of all the groups in dealing with such a very important issue. ***

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: — Mr President, if you may, before going to the Minutes, you said that we are a political parliament and that we must make our voice heard. That's what we do regularly. I would like to bring to your attention that on 26 October last, here, we voted for a resolution against sexual harassment by a very large majority. Six months later, the roadmap is still not in place. Even worse, six months later, a number of elements contained in the resolution do not appear on the roadmap, including three key points: the call for external audit, training of members and the recomposition of anti-harassment committees, including administrative staff. It is our collective responsibility to combat sexual harassment. We did so by voting on this resolution, but it is also your responsibility and duty, Mr. President, to enforce the implementation of the resolution — of the resolution as a whole. I therefore ask you to put in the road map the three missing points.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this evening in Cyprus the two political leaders are meeting, many months after the collapse of the Crans-Montana talks. Let us not ignore that the Cyprus problem can easily evolve — I am afraid to say so — into something like Syria, following the deep Islamisation that is being attempted in the occupied areas of Cyprus. I want Parliament to send a message to both leaders to break the impasse, but on their table it must be Parliament's demand that Turkey abandon its intention to remain troops or remain guarantees after a solution to the Cyprus problem. (Applause)

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President! On 15 May, the international community celebrates the International Day of the Family. This official day of action of the United Nations is based on Resolution No. 47/237 of the General Assembly of 20 September 1993. This year, the leitmotif is “Promoting the role of the family in a peaceful society and for sustainable development”. I ask you how the European Parliament would like to support this official family day on 15 May in the spirit of the United Nations resolution of principle? I also ask you this because, on 17 May, the European Parliament wishes to celebrate a so-called International Day against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia. The motto is: “Celebrating the diversity of sex and gender”. But 17 May is by no means an official day to justify this, neither in the Member States nor in the EU, nor in the United Nations. I hope that you will agree with me on the need to ask the Member States first of all whether the European Parliament can so easily apply the gender rainbow flag in public space. This is a devaluation of sovereign sovereign symbols. And I hope that you will agree with me on the need, on 15 May — International Day of the Family — to inform with the same effort, means and determination of the importance of the family, building on marriage between a man and a woman, for the sustainable development of all Western societies and the European Union.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — Mr President, I thought we had one-minute speeches until tonight. I would like to point out that, according to the Rules of Procedure, at this time, the person who wants to speak must say what point they want to comment on, which colleagues do not do. Please for the future be a minor Democrat and follow the rules of procedure.

The discussion took place at the October 2017 session.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President, as you said, more than six months ago, Parliament decided to have a debate about the situation in the Republic of Moldova and also to vote on a resolution. During the October session, the vote on the resolution was postponed and, since then, every month, our political group has asked for the text to be voted on. We were denied. The last pretext was that a delegation of the Foreign Affairs Commission will go to the Republic of Moldova and, after returning, we will have the opportunity to make an informed vote on a resolution. The delegation paid this visit two weeks ago, and I think it is time for us to keep our word on voting on this text. I believe that the Republic of Moldova needs the support of the European Parliament and I see no reason to prevent us from moving to the vote after, behold, six months after the debate that was held in the hemicycle.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Well over half a year ago, we talked about the situation in Moldova at that time. Because it is also about controversial matters, we then tried to bring together those who could solve the problem, and not everyone from Moldova was ready to come to a table — from both sides. And now, after half a year, we suddenly get something out of there because it fits so well, maybe for the election campaign in Chișinau. I don't think that's right. We should at least revisit this situation if we are to vote on something well over half a year ago.

name: Stanisław ŻÓŁTEK
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Mr President! Until now, it was the case that these types of discussions had taken place before, there were already such discussions about the budget, but not that year. That year for unknown reasons, such a discussion did not take place. Budget resolutions are the most important resolutions of the European Parliament and people from Europe who we take away from sometimes would like to know what our decisions are about, why we make decisions and so on. So that clearly and completely compliant with Union rules, it is with the spirit of the European Union that this matter is transparent and for the transparency of the budget, for the transparency of our behaviour, we ask you to put this on the agenda on Thursday. Hopefully the extra few minutes of time taken doesn't get in the way of such an important matter.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President! I understand the concern of the honourable Member and can also support it in such a way that, of course, a debate on the budget is very important. We will have a wide-ranging debate on the budget this week, namely in the discharge procedure, where Parliament's budget is being discussed explicitly and exclusively. We know that the estimate is currently an internal procedure and that the official budget debate will, of course, as every year take place in the autumn and will then also be voted on in plenary, so that there is a full opportunity to do so here. That is why I would like to reject this motion, because otherwise it would be a doubling of the debate, and we have very little time to debate this week anyway.
