text: The first item on the agenda is the joint debate on፦ the report by Norbert Lins, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the inclusion of greenhouse gas emissions and removals resulting from the use of greenhouse gases land, land-use change and forestry within the framework of climate and energy action until 2030, and amending Regulation No 525/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council on a mechanism for monitoring and reporting greenhouse gas emissions and other information relevant to climate change (COM (2016) 0479 - C8-0330/2016 - 2016/0230 (COD)) (A8-0262/2017), and - the report by Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on binding annual reductions in emissions of greenhouse gases by Member States from 2021 to 2030 for a resilient Energy Union in order to fulfil their commitments under the Paris Agreement and amending Regulation (EU) No 525/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council on a mechanism for monitoring and monitoring reporting greenhouse gas emissions and other information relevant to climate change (COM (2016) 0482 - C8-0331/2016 - 2016/0231 (COD)) (A8-0208/2017).

name: Norbert LINS
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner Cañete, ladies and gentlemen, today we are once again discussing Europe's contribution to combating climate change. The practical implementation of the Paris Agreement on Climate Change is at stake. By designing all three pillars, we have filled this with life. With the agreement on burden-sharing and ambitious LULUCF regulation, we have now put European climate policy into concrete terms. I thank my colleague, Mr Gerbrandy, for the good cooperation. However, while the burden sharing focuses on CO2 reduction targets, LULUCF is concerned with the positive contribution of agriculture and forestry to combating climate change. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to present to you today the trilogue result: what has we achieved in concrete terms? We have achieved that there are serious and robust accounting rules for CO2 uptake and levy. Parliament has worked to strike a balance between flexibility and comparable accounting rules for the 28 Member States. And the question arises: what does such a balance look like? I am convinced that we have managed to strengthen the bioeconomy — that is, timber for housing, furniture and bioenergy — but at the same time we have found a benchmark that can be used to measure the impact on the climate, called the reference value for forests. It is important to me personally to stress that the targets are addressed to the Member States directly and not to forest owners. This is the only way to enable active and sustainable forest management. At the same time, this is good for the forest, for the climate and, last but not least, for the forestry. Due to far-sighted and responsible management, our forests have grown over the past 25 years by an area as large as Portugal — that is nine million hectares. another Success is the integration of wetlands managed into the Member States by 2026 at the latest. This can be seen above all by taking into account the enormous amounts of CO2 that are stored there. Just as the Council has met us with regard to wetlands, we had to agree to the compromise on the so-called compensation mechanisms and the reference value for forests. I would have liked to see the reference value of 2000-2012, which would have given Member States even more flexibility in their harvest rates without weakening the climate balance. At the same time, flexible forest management means active and sustainable use, which opens up even more storage potential. In spite of everything, ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced that we reached a balanced and ambitious compromise in the trilogue. In the LULUCF area, there is no reduction potential but, on the contrary, enormous potential to combat climate change. Overall, our forests account for around 10% of total EU emissions. This performance is absolutely positive, great and needs to be strengthened accordingly. With this legislation, we are sending a signal: we want our forests in Europe to continue to be managed in a sustainable and far-sighted manner, and we want this to be valued. We want to continue to maintain strong forestry in Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, vote in favour of this regulation on Wednesday, because climate change and the contribution of the forest are all of our concerns. Let us take responsibility for ourselves and our children.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me start by seriously thanking my colleagues for the wonderful spirit in which we worked in the last month and for more than a year in order to come to an agreement with the Council in the end. I would really like to emphasise that even those who were not strong supporters of Parliament’s mandate were still very, very supportive, defending that mandate during the quite difficult, trilogue, so many thanks again for that. I would also like, despite the absence of the Council here, to thank the Estonian Presidency for the work they have done, but their absence might say enough at this moment. I am standing here with quite mixed feelings. This morning, before I came to Strasbourg, I again checked the so-called carbon clock, and the carbon clock indicates how much time we still have left with current CO2 emissions in order to stay within the Paris Agreement. We all so strongly supported the Paris Agreement and, to refresh your memories, the Paris Agreement also tries to stay within the 1.5 degrees scenario. For the 1.5 degrees scenario, the time we have left in the medium estimate – so that is not the most extreme – with current CO2 emissions is four months and 22 days. Four months and 22 days! So it is obviously clear that we need an extreme sense of urgency to stay within that scenario, and it’s clear that during the negotiations with the Council, the Member States have not shown that sense of urgency. On the contrary, it was extremely difficult, extremely difficult, to get the Council moving, and even the arguments that we used from Parliament’s side, that with the energy efficiency, a proposal from the Commission of 30% instead of the 27%, and with the upcoming facilitative dialogue in the UN process, it was absolutely necessary to increase ambition, their answer was very stubborn and that was a clear ‘no’. Some Member States even argued that given the fact that because of those developments, the ambition might increase in the coming one or two years, they wanted to stay on the lower side by concluding this act of law, which is quite scandalous. So if you ask me if I am satisfied with the final result we agreed, I’m afraid my answer is no, but it was the maximum that we could get out of the Council and I think it would have been irresponsible if we had not tried to find an agreement there. But still, I am not satisfied. Nevertheless Parliament did achieve quite some improvements in this Climate Action Regulation because now we finally got rid of that awful name of ‘Effort Sharing Regulation’, from now on we can call it clearly the Climate Action Regulation. Parliament fought hard to get an additional 125 million tonnes of ambition and I am proud of that, and we did tighten the trajectory. Member States cannot sit back during the first few years when it kicks in from 2020 onwards. And, very important, there is a strong reference to the long-term climate strategy that the EU and the individual Member States must develop, and the European Council recently confirmed that by asking the Commission to come forward with proposals. So we might now finally get rid of the October 2014 conclusions. We also came to a strict review clause, and that one is extremely important, also in light of what the Commission can do in the coming year with the Talanoa Dialogue and the long-term strategy. I am convinced that this is only the start and that with increased stringency in the coming years we might tighten it up.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am glad we are meeting today to finalise the adoption of two key files to achieve our 2030 climate target. Bold regulations are essential elements of our legal framework for implementing the European Union’s 2030 commitments under the Paris Agreement. They show our international partners that the European Union is leading by example, because we turn our pledges into agreed action and we are on track on a long-term low emissions pathway. This week a step forward has been possible due to the constructive efforts of the negotiators from both institutions. In particular, I would like to wholeheartedly thank the rapporteurs Mr Gerbrandy and Mr Lins for their leadership on these challenging files and congratulate them on the result. We have been able to come to an ambitious and realistic agreement within three months. Let me now highlight some specific elements of each of the two laws, starting with the Effort Sharing Regulation, or Climate Action Regulation. This regulation is a crucial instrument to accelerate the low—carbon transition in a number of key sectors of the economy, such as transport, buildings, agriculture and industry, not covered by the emissions trading system. It notably sets binding national targets covering well over half of the European Union’s domestic greenhouse gas emissions in order to achieve a European Union-wide reduction by 30% in 2030 compared to 2005. The trilogue agreement, which strikes a good balance between environmental integrity, fairness and efficiency, is the result of a thorough negotiation process that involved difficult compromises. The support and steering by the rapporteur Mr Gerbrandy, as well as the active engagement of the shadow rapporteurs Ms Ayuso, Ms Dalli, Mr Duncan and Ms Girling, Ms Konečná, Mr Eickhout, Ms Evi and Mr Jalkh, was crucial in this regard, and I particularly appreciate Parliament’s crucial role in ensuring an ambitious outcome. Parliament insisted on an early starting date for the emissions reduction trajectory. This saves more than 120 million tonnes of emissions over the period 2021-2030, hence it increases the additional effort by more than 10%. Other examples where Parliament left a good mark include the introduction of banking limits, the way the ETS flexibility is accounted for with reference to the ETS market stability reserve, stronger provisions on corrective action, a further substantiated review clause including reference to the manner in which all sectors of the economy contribute in the post-2030 framework and the LULUCF flexibility with the inclusion of wetlands, and making their use conditional on annual Member State reporting on their intended use. Let me move to the LULUCF Regulation. The LULUCF Regulation sets for the first time a clear quantitative objective, together with a solid accounting framework, for emissions and removals from land use and forests. Once again, this demonstrates to our international partners how the European Union tries to lead by example. The contribution from land and forest in reaching the long-term climate mitigation objectives is critical because of the potential for anthropogenic removal of carbon from the atmosphere. Forests alone currently cover more than 42% of the European Union land surface. They have huge potential for climate change mitigation through regional sequestration and storage of CO2. They also have the potential to substitute fossil—based energy materials. I am convinced that the LULUCF Agreement strikes a proper balance between conflicting interests, and as it was for effort-sharing, the trilogue agreement on this file involves some difficult compromises. The support and active engagement of the rapporteur Mr Lins, but also of the shadow rapporteurs Mr Brannen, Mr Turmes, Mr Flanagan, Mr Jávor and Ms Wiśniewska, was crucial in this regard. The European Parliament has strongly contributed to the final shape of the legal text. The agreed provisions of the regulation clearly carry the European Parliament’s signature, and I would like to offer some examples: mandatory accounting for emissions and the removal of wetlands towards the commitment of 2026, thus completing the European Union’s scope for land accounting; the introduction of a safeguard to prevent decreasing the European Union’s overall sink; obliging the Commission to assess, at the review, the need for additional Union policies and measures, and this includes exploring a post—2030 framework in view of the necessary strengthening of greenhouse gas emissions reductions and removals in the Union. Parliament’s hand can also be seen in a core article of the regulation on forest accounting. Indeed, the rules and governance process for establishing forest reference levels were clarified, taking into account the main requests of Parliament. First, the accounting rules were not locked in the harvest rates of the past and this should reassure forest-rich Member States and the related industry. Second, the forest reference level presented by Member States through national plans will be adopted by delegated act. This will ensure the highest degree of involvement of Parliament in setting these benchmarks. And thirdly, reflecting on the European Parliament’s priorities, this regulation gives more prominence to long-lived harvested products. More wood products create positive incentives not only for the climate, but also for jobs and the economy. Finally, keeping deadwood in forests will have environmental benefits such as for biodiversity. This shows the kind of balance that exemplifies the positive spirit of the negotiation. I invite you to support both motions and put Europe on track to take its place as a champion of climate policy and to lay out our vision for the way this policy will implement the Paris Agreement over the next decade.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. — Mr President, climate change is a question of global justice. Fighting the climate and empowering the world's most impoverished population are two sides of the same coin. And to that end, we need to generate negative emissions from land and forest use, while protecting the right to food and land. With this vision, I am pleased that the trialogue has improved from the initial positions of the Council and the European Parliament, and I am also glad that the final report takes into account food security and food production. Thanks to this, we are going to come to COP24 with a pioneering regulation in the world, which can become a model for international negotiations. Let us not forget that it would also have to be taken into account the rights to land tenure and indigenous peoples because, I repeat, to fight for climate and global justice go hand in hand.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. — (PT) Mr President, having climate summits so that governments are concerned about climate change and feel good about themselves does not change anything. Consequent measures are urgently needed to meet the objectives of the Paris Summit, and it is not enough to count emissions. We also need to eliminate carbon dioxide already existing in the atmosphere. This can only be achieved by protecting and recovering our forests, seriously, without tricks and hypocrisy, the emissions that occur there. You can invent all schemes to not account for issues, or you might even want everything to be resolved with a collection mechanism. But that's called cosmetic policy, and we can't always walk to the minimum. That is why I call again for the importance of reforestation to combat emissions and to reduce them. Also proof of the farce that reducing emissions is a business for this house is the proposal for a European carbon tax. It is not reducing, it is paying to continue to produce the same.

name: Peter JAHR
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. — Mr President. It was already a battle between ideology and science — for example, forest or, for example, forestry. It's just not right if a forest is left alone. When a forest is almost in balance with itself, there is a lot of good, but there is no storage of CO2. We want to manage our forests sustainably, and sustainable management is the key prerequisite for the forest, that the forest can also function as a CO2 storage system. I am very, very grateful to the rapporteur, Mr Lins, for bringing this report closer to the scientific facts, if you will, so that our forest can fulfil its full range of functions, namely that it can function in its protective, useful and recreational function. Now I hope — hopefully not in vain — for an unbureaucratic implementation of the regulation.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the whole common team for their good cooperation on behalf of the Committee on Transport. Traffic emissions are a quarter of our greenhouse gas emissions, i.e. in the area of transport, we really need radical action in all Member States. Now it is not just talk or papers that are enough, but we need everyday measures. In Europe, private motoring continues to play a very big role, so as a whole, the low-carbonisation of transport and the development of vehicle technology will play a big role. They also need bold pioneering measures that I believe all actors will find, because without them, there will be no outcome in emissions reductions. Multimodal use of transport, increased sharing and various transport services — their introduction is necessary. Now the active actions begin. Speeches have been made.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Effort Sharing Regulations and LULUCF bring the European Union closer to achieving the commitment made in Paris on climate change and to the objectives of the Energy Union. With regard to the effort sharing regulation, Member States managed to change the starting point: the European Parliament called for the start of 2018 but the Council managed to tear up, as a point starting, June 2019, making perhaps lose the final text some ambition. The LULUCF Regulation will provide a framework that ensures the accounting of emissions and general absorption from forests and will ensure that CO2 emissions in forestry do not exceed Carbon dioxide removals secured by natural reservoirs, the so-called “zero goal”. However, the deal could be more ambitious, perhaps with a target of negative net emissions. Finally, with regard to the use of woody biomass in the energy field, a truly sustainable strategy should only allow the use of waste biomass, avoiding the destruction of virgin forests, approach, this, which however was not shared in the trilogist.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, the Commission and this Parliament are still taking steps towards fulfilling the Paris Agreement and combating climate change. By 2030 emissions from transport, agriculture, buildings and waste management will be reduced by 30% compared to 2015. This effort will be shared among the Member States taking into account their per capita income. I think it's a good regulation. This Regulation will cover various measures to be implemented by Member States, such as improving forest and agricultural management, replacing less efficient boilers in buildings, reducing waste disposal in landfills and promoting cleaner transport technologies. But the Member States have social, environmental, energy and industrial challenges, and it is therefore a good thing that we have agreed to give countries different flexibilities in meeting the emission targets. This will enable Member States to approach their reductions with the greatest technological advantages and lower costs. I also welcome the inclusion of rules that take into account the special situation of the countries most punished by the economic crisis. Finally, I consider it of great importance that removals can be accounted for in the forest sector to offset emissions. Member States, however, need to develop computing systems that are robust and comparable. And I conclude by congratulating the Commissioner for the effort he has made during these months of negotiation, also to the Council; and I call on all political groups to support the agreement in recognition of the great work done by the rapporteur of this House, Mr Gerbrandy, and because it is a good agreement. (She agreed to answer a question under the blue card procedure (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: blue card issue. — As the previous speaker said, we need a broad, good forest policy. This is part of the fact that we have rules so that climate duty should also be taken into account in forest management. But as the previous speaker also said, this allows emissions from other sectors to be taken into account in the growth of the forest. Therefore, I would like to ask that you also see a role in the fact that forest products can replace fossil products, plastics with bio-plastics and many other bio-producing products. For example, producing cement for building houses is much more climate unfriendly than timber house construction, and in order to have timber houses, needs forests to be managed and diversified use for other biomass from economic forests can be found if we do the bioeconomy right in the future.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: answer from 'blue card'. — Mrs Kumpula-Natri, well, I thank you for your considerations, but you have not asked me any questions.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I have always believed that we need very strong policies to make sure that we deliver on our climate obligations. I am strongly convinced, however, that we did not manage to deliver this in the Effort Sharing Regulation or Climate Action Regulation, call it what you may. It comes as no surprise that I am critical of the final agreement reached, because I believe that this agreement falls short of what is actually needed. As Socialists and Democrats, we will be abstaining on the final deal, in the same way that we did in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, because the deal reached is far less than what is needed and far less than what can be achieved. I believe it keeps us from embarking on a truly low-emissions development pathway. I acknowledge the efforts made by the rapporteur, Gerben—Jan Gerbrandy, but I would like to highlight what I consider to be an evident lack of ambition and lack of initiative throughout the negotiations, particularly by the Council, but also at times by the Commission itself. I have always considered the Commission to be an honest broker that plays a fundamental role in climate policy. That is why I call upon the Commission to enhance its role and make sure that Member States play their part because all of them – I repeat, all of them – should share in the efforts to address climate change. The two—faced approach, where national leaders make fancy statements at climate summits, but then show very little ambition where it counts, should cease.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Commissioner! The European Union is leading the way when it comes to the implementation of the Paris Agreement. We have adopted the EU ETS, we are completing work on sectors not covered by the EU ETS and LULUCF. We have set ambitious targets to cut emissions by 40% by 2030. But let us remember that the European Union is only responsible for about 10% of the world's greenhouse gas emissions. Therefore, we should focus our efforts on making the commitments made at the COP 21 conference in Paris are met by other countries as well. We need to think and act globally. We should prepare well for the COP 24 conference in Katowice. Our priority should be to adopt a full package implementing the Paris Agreement. In an international forum, we should speak with one voice. To achieve the objectives, we need to build a broad coalition to which countries outside the European Union will join. This is a key issue, because the implementation of the Paris Agreement will depend on the final shape of the package.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Mr President, thank you also to the Commissioner for his presence and his strict monitoring of matters. We were quite close to agreeing in this committee, but we ran out of time, perhaps above all, because the forests and us are now facing very different demands. For that reason then in the last few metres we fell apart somewhat. At the same time as our working little bit broke down, there have been huge changes. 60 years ago, forestry work was the work of a lonely man, a sawmill and a horse. At the moment, it is extremely complex and technological work more akin to the chemical industry than the traditional forestry industry. For that reason, we may need about 200 million cubic kilometres of new forest in Europe today to cope with the challenges posed by plastic. You can also make plastic out of wood and fix the problems we face.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank both the rapporteurs, Mr Lins and Mr Gerbrandy, because I am also talking on behalf of Mr Jávor on these two files. They were tough negotiations but there is now a package on the table, and with this package we conclude the climate legislation until 2030 – at least for the moment, because we all know that what is on the table will lead us to minus 40% in 2030, which is insufficient for the Paris implementation. We are happy that countries like the Netherlands, Sweden and France are already acknowledging that, and so we look forward to the Commission also coming forward with its long—term proposals to show that more needs to happen at the European front also.  But if we know already that the targets are insufficient, let’s at least have the reporting rules straight, and that is what we did in these two regulations as well. On LULUCF I am happy that now we can also make sure that at the European level there will not be a decrease of the sink, and that is why the Greens will support the LULUCF Regulation. However, on effort—sharing there are too many loopholes. It has been weakened too often and we know also that the base year has been put to a very bad level which means that the cumulative emissions will be much bigger than could have been possible. In the end, for climate it is the cumulative emissions that count. That is why the Greens will vote against that part of the climate legislation. That is for now, and now it is onto the Commission to come up with new proposals to make sure that we really are implementing Paris.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, the adoption of these two emissions regulations not currently covered by the EU ETS will finally be completed legislative process to the climate package. All sectors must participate in fulfilling the commitments under the Paris Agreement. Thus, even those who avoid their part in solving the problem for a long time, such as forestry, transport, buildings, agriculture and waste management. I see the failure to secure an earlier trajectory start than in May 2019 as the biggest failure to negotiate a Shared Effort Regulation. The mandate of us as Parliament was far more ambitious, after all. However, since not only the Shared Effort Regulation itself constitutes a mere emission reduction framework and for entry into force, other regulations implementing the objectives therein await us as the proposal regarding CO2 for cars, I would intercede for the smooth acceptance of both proposals, although I have a number of reservations towards them. But if we want to keep commitments from Paris, we need to start filling them with practical steps.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 12 December at the One Planet Summit our Heads of State and Government were scurried to renew their commitment to the implementation of the Paris agreement. A few days later, however, at the time of closing the negotiations on the regulations we are discussing today and in particular the effort sharing regulation, the chasm between climate rhetoric and the willingness to bind oneself seriously at cutting greenhouse gases was baffling. But the surprise is relative because, within the negotiation, the Council has been kept in check by governments, such as Italy, which are strenuous defenders of fossil sources. In 2017 Parliament called for 2030 a reduction of 529 million tonnes of CO2 in non-ETS sectors, greatly improving the Commission's proposal. Now, however, thanks to a downward compromise and a start of the linear reduction trajectory delayed to May 2019, thanks to loopholes, tricks and accounting artifice, we find ourselves getting to barely to a 25% reduction. For us this is an inadmissible compromise that moves us dangerously away from international climate targets.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, the issue of global warming and, more generally, all the environmental challenges facing us are extremely important problems. Our settled and non-negotiable position is that we support any initiative, move or agreement aimed at protecting the environment. The Paris agreement is a step in the right direction, even if we disagree on some of its elements. We should note the extremely positive fact that the total percentage of soil in Europe covered by forests has increased significantly, but certain Member States are facing problems. For example, due to global warming and the ongoing desertification of large parts of North Africa, it has been observed in recent years in. Greece a sharp increase in the appearance of dust clouds from the Sahara causing health problems for citizens, since concentrations of dangerous heavy metals such as lead, zinc and arsenic have been identified in them. There is also a dramatic increase in forest fires due to the rise in temperature, which in turn contribute to the destruction of large forest and arable areas. Having said all of the above, I would like to highlight one thing that I think we should pay particular attention to: we should not impose disproportionately large restrictions on European farmers because all we will achieve in this way is to reduce the European agricultural production, while at the same time importing cheaper agricultural products from countries with much worse environmental standards. I believe that serious restrictions must be placed on imports of agricultural products from outside the Union, as only in this way will we be able to protect the environment by imposing equally stringent environmental standards on these countries.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President! Thank you and congratulations to the two rapporteurs! They both fought well. We are a little more satisfied with Norbert Lin's report. I think it is particularly important what he said is that we do not impose direct conditions on individual foresters here, but that legislation is addressed to the Member States. With regard to the Gerbrandy report on burden-sharing or climate action, I agree with those who say: 'We could have imagined a little more. 'I find it particularly regrettable that the Council of Ministers is always ready to impose strict climate change requirements when it does not concern the Member States. In the ETS — we agreed to this at the end of the day, and this is a good compromise — the Council of Ministers tightened legislation. In burden-sharing, he mitigated them, and that's not a good balance. Nevertheless, we have to agree tomorrow, even if we are not satisfied. Because we need this legislation so that something can move in these other sectors too. Voting against this is not, in my view, responsible. It's a small step forward, but we have to do this now.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: – Mr President, across the European Union, 10% of our carbon emissions are absorbed by our forest cover. So how we manage and use our forests is of crucial importance. As well as our forests playing a key role, so do other forms of land use. Agriculture needs to deliver its part and the land use, land-use change and forestry (LULUCF) text explicitly refers to agro-forestry and agro-ecology, as practices that can deliver on climate change. Wetlands, including peatlands, can absorb staggeringly high amounts of carbon. For instance, there is more CO2 stored in the peatlands of northern England than in all of the forests of the United Kingdom, France and Germany together. Wetlands, including peatlands, will be included mandatorily in the LULUCF accounting as of 2026, which was not in the Commission’s or the Council’s proposals and as such it is a win for the Parliament. The LULUCF proposals also recognise the role of long-life harvested wood products and deadwood, both of which have the potential for storing carbon for long enough to be relevant for our climate action. Increasing the range of products to which harvested wood goes, including long-life engineered construction timbers, such as cross-laminated timber and laminated veneer lumber, can help countries improve their climate action. The S&D recognises that the legislation falls short on forest land, but this new LULUCF legislation means that how we use land is being recognised as of key importance in how we tackle climate change.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: - Mr President! We have come to the end of what this is the climate legislation package, but that does not mean that climate legislation is over, but we will see more initiatives coming. Perhaps from this Commission, but certainly from the next Commission. We also know that at the same time we are negotiating one of what is at least as important for climate and industrial and economic growth and that is the whole energy union package. Can we make it land well and progressively and forward in how we shape energy market design and in how we bring about a progressive and forward renewable directive, we will be able to solve even much more. At the same time, I think that quite many of us are sitting at home grinding the knives for the next debate, because as soon as we have had the review of the Paris Agreement in 2023, we will start again with all these reviews that we have wisely put into legislation. Which allows us if we see this wasn't enough to screw it up properly then. Furthermore, we see the full-scale effects then of the started energy union, hopefully.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, there are four greenhouse gases of the five that are produced by farmers, and one of those is called nitrous oxide. Farmers produce nitrous oxide by cultivating leguminous crops. So the way they can reduce their nitrous oxide emissions is to grow fewer leguminous crops. However, the Commission and the green lobby are so concerned about the importation of 30 million tonnes of GM soybeans that they want farmers to grow more protein crops. Protein crops, by and large, are leguminous crops so this is a very contradictory message. There is another greenhouse gas called water vapour, and how do farmers emit this? They emit this because of the transpiration through their crops and their grass. The only way they are going to stop emitting water vapour is to keep the ground permanently ploughed so that there is no grass and no crops to transpire water. Isn’t this a wonderful debate? Finally, I would like to remind all the MEPs in here that forestry, which many of you have been talking about, is not an EU competence and therefore you cannot legislate over it.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank both of our rapporteurs today for the work that they did. I was particularly involved, as a shadow, with Mr Gerbrandy, and I take my hat off to him because he had a fairly difficult and rather a bold approach at some points, and I know that was not in line with his own personal views. That is always a difficult thing to do, so thank you for that, Gerben—Jan. I just want to take this opportunity to look ahead rather than trawl through the details, and what is obvious as we reach the end of this climate package – or at least this iteration of the climate package – is that we cannot continue to work in this way. It takes far too long, we get far too involved in small details, and we lose sight of our aim. So what we need to do, it seems to me, is to put this to one side, accept that we have the mechanisms in place and start looking in the spirit of Talanoa, which is about checking progress but then seeking ways to increase commitments – and we need to seek ways now to increase commitments in Europe that do not involve going back through this long process and are actually there because people want to do it.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. The LULUCF Regulation is a climate change mitigation instrument, not a forestry policy. I am therefore delighted with the result of our forward-looking accounting approach enabling our forestry sector to continue sustainable management of Europe's forests. In this House, we are dealing with the decarbonisation of our society in the context of climate policy and beyond — just as with other important future issues such as the bioeconomy or the circular economy. Our forests are not just a carbon reservoir for the climate balance, but a source of resources. They supply renewable building materials and packaging materials, as well as renewable energy for electricity, heat and mobility. In the Member States, we can effectively ensure sustainable management — unlike the case of imports. For these reasons, it is extremely important not to move ourselves to the sidelines, because our different objectives are repeating each other. Fortunately, we were able to prevent that in this case. Therefore, many thanks to all colleagues.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: — I also support both regulations, because in the context of efforts to combat climate change, we are going in the right direction. It seems particularly important to me that, in the LULUCF Regulation, we have managed to preserve the forest as a resource that, on the one hand, provides a sinkhole of greenhouse gases and, on the other hand, we still enable sustainable forest management. It is said that the forest is used, on the one hand, as a quality resource for building materials which prevent the use of many other materials that are the causative agents of greenhouse gases, and on the other hand, to include precisely this wood mass in the bioeconomy, which is very important. Also in the field of heating, waste wood plays a very important role, so support the regulations on my part, and I hope that we will continue to upgrade these regulations further.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, climate change is already affecting the planet and society and will continue to do so for generations to come, if the appropriate actions are not taken now! The physical and chemical changes of human activities are being felt in natural ecosystems very strongly. Both developed and developing countries have increased commitments for addressing climate change, which is gratifying, given the fact that climate change is a problem which cannot be solved by national or local action alone. Forest management has an essential role to play in combating climate change, as all sectors must contribute to the overall EU emission reduction goal. Nevertheless, forest mitigation should be measured using a scientifically objective approach, not allowing countries to hide the impacts of policies that increase emissions.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Mr President, the Paris agreement on climate change is an important agreement because it protects the environment and at a time when we are experiencing particularly adverse phenomena, all over the world and in Greece, where we are now experiencing the dangerous dust cloud from Sahara that has caused too many problems in my homeland. It is therefore a fact that measures should be taken, but in such a way as to support the eradication of poverty, and the rights of indigenous peoples of course, because there must be no grabbing of their land and the protection of forests against fires, since forests are an oxygen lung. This therefore means that such measures must be taken which, on the other hand, must not overburden the farmers themselves. I believe that forests cannot be destroyed to create biomass. Measures such as those proposed by colleagues are therefore needed.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Mr President, after climate legislation for the major industries, climate legislation has now been introduced for agriculture, transport, construction and waste management. I am pleased that this climate law leaves room for a very important natural event, namely that agriculture, as one of the few sectors, is also able to bind CO2 from the air in the form of soil life and organic substances in the soil. This is not only good for the climate, but it also creates a win-win situation on three other points. It countermeasures soil compaction, it is better for water management and it also provides fertile agricultural land. I am pleased that this legislation allows farmers, foresters and gardeners to take this into account in their own CO2 emissions, and that they can also sell and reward it to other sectors. I hope, therefore, that the national authorities will soon come up with clear programmes that will help farmers and gardeners.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Mr President, taking advantage of the fact that Commissioner Arias Cañete is here with him always talked about fishing, but this time it's time to talk about climate change and the impact of greenhouse gases, I would like to raise a very serious problem, which has been mentioned by a colleague, which is the issue of fires and their impact on the emissions of carbon gas. In the case of Galicia, Asturias, Portugal, forests, forests, are CO2 storage sinks, but it depends a lot on the type of species, and I want to bring up the problem of eucalyptus here. A few months ago, during the Galician fires, we asked the Commissioner to prepare a report on the impact of greenhouse gases and climate change on fires, drought and species types. And today I would like to recall this because such action to mitigate forests is necessary, but not on the basis of planting species that are favourable to CO2.

name: João FERREIRA
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, greenhouse gas emissions also depend on land use, land use changes, forests and the management of land use. In the process of defining a method for accounting for emissions associated with this sector, the interests of large forest producers in the North prevailed, to the detriment of the specificities of ecosystems in the South. This creative accounting demonstrates the fragility of the European Union's pledges of commitment to combating climate change, as is also demonstrated by the insistence on a market approach, which has already demonstrated all its ineffectiveness and perversity. The concern won't be so much about nature and the planet. The concern here is fundamentally with business, including what you can do with nature and the atmosphere of the planet. Only this can explain the obstinacy with the market approach, in which all the expedients, be it in the definition of reference periods or in the instruments of flexibility, provided that it is in order to defend the interests of the most powerful.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr President! I've listened to the debate, so I don't have to repeat either arguments for, or remarks, or compliments, or caveats. I will only say one thing that for me is crucial that has been left out. We must definitely benefit from the younger generation, from NGOs, from the real fervor of those who protect green areas, leafs, gardens, parks — not just in Europe, but around the world. Let us try to improve the channels of communication with this youngest generation, because there is great value in it, in the fight for precisely the elements that are contained in this report.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: — Agriculture and forestry, in addition to having significant emission absorption potential, also perform a number of social and economic functions that should be recognised within the framework of the EU climate policy. Therefore, action to reduce emissions based on these sectors must take into account their overarching role in ensuring food and energy security on our continent accordingly. It is also impossible to forget that, compared with 1990, emissions from agriculture in the Union fell by nearly a quarter. It is also necessary to remember the important differences in the level of afforestation of individual Member States and to take account accordingly of climate actions taken by some countries in the past.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, strengthening the global response to the threat of climate change, in the context of sustainable development and efforts to eradicate poverty, needs, among other things, an increase in the ability to adapt to the adverse effects of climate change. To achieve negative emission levels, land use, land use change and forestry accounting systems must be sound. Since removals through this sector are reversible, it should be seen as a separate pillar within the Union and national climate policies. In addition, sound management of forests must be accompanied by a commitment to halt and reverse deforestation and to promote afforestation. The environment is the main field of political consensus and is directly linked to the sustainability of our planet and the continuity of mankind.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Dear Chairman, I support the outcome of the negotiations on the LULUCF Regulation and thank my colleague Lin for respecting my arguments and allowing for Croatia an exemption. Thus, we can calculate our reference level for forests taking into account the occupation of part of the Croatian territory during the Homeland War and the effects of aggression, war and its consequences on forest management practices. For these reasons, forest management was reduced in intensity in Croatia, and allowed logging was realized significantly less than planned during this period and amounted to about 60% of today's quantities. Due to all of the above, without exception, the existing situation would have an extremely adverse impact on the calculation of the reference level of forest management in Croatia and that is why I am particularly grateful to my colleague Lins. I also thank the European Union, which has so far directed over 100 million euros to demining in Croatia, and 46 million euros to Bosnia and Herzegovina. I note that we still need help because in Croatia there are still 38,000 hectares of forest under mines and in Bosnia and Herzegovina 120,000 hectares.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: — Mr President, I support this outcome of the negotiations and would like to thank all the negotiators, and in particular Norbert Lins, for the work he did with other negotiators on the LULUCF Regulation. We know that forests play a very big role in the fight against climate change. Europe's forests bind up to ten percent of all greenhouse emissions. It is important that the European Union promotes sustainable forest management, both in Europe and in the rest of the world. We know that the Commission's original proposal was unfair to those countries that have managed their forests sustainably, because they would not have had the opportunity to increase the use of forests. We have now reached the bottom line, which provides the possibility to continue forestry when it is done at a sustainable level and when it is taken to ensure that forests remain carbon sinks. This is a good starting point for a continuation.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Mr President, many people in this Chamber have said everything and we are talking about the climate agreement. From day one, I have said in this Chamber that I will support it, but it must be feasible, affordable and feasible, especially for the agricultural sector - especially when we talk about Article 2 of the climate policy - and it must not be at the expense of food production. In my country - and I am also looking at Mr Gerbrandy - there is a lot of work on it. But one time they talk about one side and the other about the other side. It must therefore remain feasible, and I would certainly like to address this appeal to the Commissioner, otherwise a farmer will no longer know which way to go.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I thank all of you for this debate, which shows again how seriously the European Union takes its commitments under the Paris Agreement. I think that together we can be proud of the result of our joint effort to agree on the legal framework for the next decade for the sectors not covered by the European Union Emissions Trading System.  We all know about the scale of efforts needed to reach our long—term climate targets and some contributors to the debate have pointed to that. Specifically Ms Dali pointed to the lack of ambition of the efforts set in the proposal for a regulation,saying that these are too low and that this does not put the European Union on track towards the necessary long—term emission reductions.  I will make two comments. First, that the ambition level increase is significant because a modified trajectory – a starting date as assured by the European Parliament of seven months earlier – saves more than 120 million tonnes of emissions over the period 2021—2030 and hence increases the additional effort needed, compared to the initial proposal, by more than ten percent.  My second remark is that, in order to address the long—term issues that have been pointed out, the Commission will address them in the context of developing the European Union Mid—Century Strategy. We intend to deliver the Commission’s input in November this year. It is very clear that, if the European Union’s Mid—Century Strategy or the global stocktake after the Paris Agreement lead to changes in European Union emission reduction targets, the review clause caters for the corresponding need to adapt the efforts set out in the regulation. So this is not a closed effort. It is an open matter that we will have to discuss in the framework of the future reflection that the Commission has to do on the long—term trajectories. But, coming back to the issue of the two regulations on effort sharing and LULUCF, today I invite you to lend your support to them in tomorrow’s vote. I think it is very important to ensure that they can enter swiftly into force and that the necessary provisions can be in place by January 2021, because there is no time to lose in our fight against climate change.

name: Norbert LINS
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for this debate. I am also grateful that the Commissioner has once again highlighted the exemplary nature of the European Union here, that is, what example we are giving internationally. For colleagues who have also made it clear that we are not only talking about the period from 2021—2030, but well beyond. Thanks also to those who have made it clear that this process has not yet come to an end, but that we will of course continue to take part in the delegated acts, for example, in the context of the debate on the LULUCF regulation. I would also like to thank Mr Brannen, who made it clear that we have highlighted the positive incentives, that is to say that we do not come with regulatory law, but that we have provided a positive incentive, for example, in the area of durable wood products. I do not agree with a colleague from the GUE/NGL Group who said that we are only pursuing cosmetic policy here. I believe it will turn out that this is not the case. I would also like to thank my fellow Members who have made it clear that there is multifunctionality in forests and agriculture, in other words that ideology is out of place here, but that all areas of society must be taken into account: both the forest as a supplier of timber products, the country as a supplier to the Food production, but also the enormous contribution, the enormous potential of CO2 savings, and that we can achieve everything — including a higher sink effect, while at the same time providing wood and also ensuring food production in Europe. Once again, many thanks to all the Members, the Commission and the Council for achieving such a good result, I believe.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me start by thanking all my colleagues from far-left to the far-right for their kind words. It was a difficult process and in the end we did find an agreement with Council – that was the mission of my first remarks – also with strong support from the Commission and the Commissioner personally as well, being present at all trilogue meetings. Still, besides the fact that we did find a political agreement, it is not enough. It should have been much more ambitious, and I hope that that will be echoed by many others as well. That means, from now on, now that we have found agreement – and I hope that we have sufficient support tomorrow during the vote – that there is a huge responsibility on the shoulders of the Commission. It is up to the Commission to now think of ways to strengthen our climate policy in Europe that is necessarily in the light and in the spirit of the Paris agreement. Therefore, also in line with the upcoming long-term strategy that the Commissioner is currently drafting, I hope that we can convince together the absent Council as far as needed in order to really stay within the Paris boundaries.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. This legislative report is part of the Union's action plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and achieve the objectives of the Paris Climate Agreement. Agriculture and forestry are sectors that are already actively contributing to the mitigation of global warming through their capacity to absorb greenhouse gases. I am delighted that in this report a fair recognition of this reality has been acknowledged. On the other hand, I believe that Member States will have enough room to leverage the full potential of their forests, in order to contribute to our climate objectives while supporting the growth of the entire timber sector, which is essential in the European economy. Thank you

name: Adam GIEREK
text: in writing. — I do not support the Gerbrandy report because I do not support the EU ETS's speculative industry and energy system. These industries of material production and energy must make significant adjustment changes in efficiency to ensure that the climate target set at the COP 21 conference in Paris is met. The draft directive from the beginning was erroneously, unsubstantively referred to the ENVI committee rather than the ITRE committee, which could only elaborate on its opinion on the matter. I remind you that the extremely difficult intra-EU negotiations for revising EU ECJ directives have only recently concluded, and the tripartite negotiations on the winter package, in particular on energy efficiency and RES, have not yet been completed. In turn, in the Paris Agreement, there was no question of Member States increasing their contribution, but merely communicating or upgrading it, and it is up to Member States to decide on the implementation of the recommendations. I do not support opening and increasing the Union contribution, in the form of national contributions, up to 40% in 2030. I believe that overly prohibitive ambitions for reducing CO2 emissions could adversely affect the work on the adoption during COP 24 in Katowice of the implementation package during COP 24 in Katowice. the Paris agreement, which is the main objective of my country as the host of this conference.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: in writing. — Preventing dangerous climate change is one of the priorities for the functioning of the EU. It is taking extensive initiatives to protect the natural environment in which we live every day. All of us care to breathe clean air, which will provide us with good physical condition and health. In the context of today's debate and two reports related to greenhouse gas emissions, we must remember that the EU's ambitious targets must go hand in hand with the differences between Member States. It is therefore appropriate to stand in favour of a position that will, in a balanced and comprehensive way, lead to the implementation of the Paris Agreement and prevent further climate change. We must remember the important function of forests, which are also responsible for reducing CO2 emissions, but we must not forget that the forestry sector must meet the demand for timber and that the day-to-day activities of operators based on the resources of the harvested just from forest management. The effective fight against climate change should therefore include comprehensive actions to help integrate economic and climate policies, as well as actions to implement the rules previously adopted.
