name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after almost three years of work we have reached the end of this negotiation. In 2015, when the Commission resubmitted the package after initially withdrawing it, I must admit that the premises were not the best but in recent years significant progress has been made. The circular economy has become one of the priorities of the European Union, a priority for co-legislators, a priority for our companies who immediately understood its potential but, above all, one priority for citizens. Europe has been able to show its positive side, to put together national interests, on opposing paper, to achieve a high degree of sharing on a life goal daily citizens and the environment in which they live. For this reason I do not deny you satisfaction with the result we managed to bring home. With this package, Europe is decisively aiming for sustainable economic and social development, able to finally integrate industrial policies and environmental protection. The circular economy, in fact, is not only a policy of waste management, but it is a way to recover raw materials and not to press the already scarce resources of our planet, even by innovating deeply our production system. Certainly, the package we are going to approve also contains important measures on waste management and, at the same time, goes beyond these, defining rules that take into account the whole cycle of life of a product and set themselves the goal of changing the behavior of companies and consumers. For the first time Member States will be obliged to follow a unique and shared legislative framework. An ambitious plan, with clear and unequivocal stakes. Only to summarize the main innovations introduced: the raising of municipal and packaging waste recycling targets; the inclusion, for the first time, of a maximum landfill limit of 10%; the extension of separate collection obligations to hazardous organic, textile and domestic waste; but I cannot fail remember the inclusion, here for the first time in European legislation, of compulsory measures to reduce the abhorrent phenomenon of food waste, an environmental but also ethical problem, as well as actions aimed at countering the pollution of the seas from waste. Important rules have been put in place to prevent waste generation: this is not only because prevention is the first level of the waste hierarchy but because preventing means making products which already by their design are repairable and reusable and means having production cycles that use resources efficiently, reduce waste or reuse them for new production. And finally preventing means introducing business models that go from selling a product to sharing a service. The circular economy is therefore a total paradigm shift, with which we must confront all of us and is a challenge for the States, which are asked ambitious goals to foster the transition to a new development model. When you get a job done like this, it means that there has been the contribution of so many. Let me then, in the seconds I have left, to thank mainly the shadow speakers and their assistants for the active collaboration that has always been demonstrated, which was the added value for bringing home the result relatively quickly. A special thanks to Dr. Marco Leonardi for all the precise and painstaking work on the file. Thank you to Vice-Presidents Timmermans and Katainen, Commissioner Vella and DG ENVI, in the person of Director-General Crespo, for their competence and continued support to arrive at the final result. Finally, President, thank you Maltese and Bulgarian Presidency: but special thanks goes to the Estonian Presidency, without whose tenacity in wanting to conclude the negotiation, we would not be here today.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Members of the Council, I should like to begin the presentation of my report with a preliminary reflection. We rarely have any tools that can push Europe forward; a few days we have as today to talk about future projects we want for our Union. We remain an area of peace, even if we sometimes forget it, and we remain a space of prosperity, which has been diminished in recent years; and we remain the world region with the greatest social justice, although we must remain more ambitious. For too many years, some of the European values of solidarity, fraternity justice, freedom... have been diluted by other objectives; but, above all, the collective political will to build a community in which we all recognize ourselves in our diversity has been diluted by more particular, more selfish, more egoistic objectives extremists: we only seek to delve into a division of Europe never seen since the end of World War II. However, too often the debates we have in our House are far from what is perceived on the street. What do the media say about this Europe which is moving away from the integrative idea of our founding fathers? Europeanist sentiment does not go beyond the Brussels bubble. It's been too long since we stopped looking for what unites us to defend what separates us. We've lost our perspective from our ivory towers. That is why, in today's debate, I would like to stress that the circular economy can and should be a circle for relaunching the European project of our founding fathers. I would like to draw the Commission's attention so that it does not miss the opportunity to turn this project into a new 'Schuman Declaration'. The transition to the circular economy is to choose the path of leadership in the world and abandon the path of reaction. We must continue to exercise this leadership in the fight against climate change, as we committed ourselves at COP21. A struggle that has the support of European society. These targets are committed to the reindustrialisation of Europe with a low emission industry. This is an achievable project that has a direct impact on the creation of quality and decently paid jobs. Without jobs, any project will end up being an orphan of social support. Only by creating new jobs will we be able to carry out this change project; only with a cutting-edge and smart yet sustainable economy will we offer a present and a future to our society. Let us, Europeans, make the circular economy into our future in the twenty-first century what the ECSC went to the construction of the European Union in the twentieth century. Next Wednesday we will adopt this first package with the Waste, Packaging, Landfills and Batteries and Accumulators Directives for which Mrs Bonafè has been rapporteur. My report on environmental information is a small contribution to paving the way to the circular economy so that we can make this transition to a new economy more agile and easier for our citizens, our economy and our common project. And Mrs Bonafè's reports, as well as all the work of the shadow rapporteurs and all the people she has detailed in her speech, are the crucial first stone of this new path Europe must take. Our citizenship is demanding it from us. Let's answer that we're ready.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, this week marks a hugely important moment for the circular economy in Europe. The new EU waste legislation that we are discussing here this evening will help to prevent waste and will turn much more waste into valuable resources. I trust that this House will vote clearly in favour of the adoption of the package on Wednesday. In doing so, you would give a great push to further improving waste management in Europe, in line with our circular economy goals. This will unlock new sources of growth and innovation, create jobs and reduce our dependence on imports of critical raw materials and our reliance on waste treatment abroad, and it will of course help to protect our environment and thus the health of our citizens. I do know that this House had its doubts when this Commission in December 2014 withdrew previous proposals on waste. We did it to pursue more ambitious, better designed goals that would get the approval of Member States and would be actually enforced on the ground. I would like to express my profound gratitude to the rapporteur, Ms Simona Bonafè, all the shadow rapporteurs as well as all the other Members of the European Parliament and staff members involved for their relentless and constructive work on the Commission’s new proposals over the past two years. And I do agree with the much broader framework Mr Gambús has just given us of why we are doing this. Without your vision and support, we would not have achieved the very good result we have on the table today or indeed overcome the stalemate that the pre-2014 proposals had engendered. Thanks to your support, the ambitious recycling and landfill reduction targets proposed by the Commission were generally kept, even though Member States may take some more years to attain them. Parliament’s support was also crucial to agree on strong new rules on waste prevention, including food waste and marine litter, and you also helped to secure strong new rules on extended producer responsibility, the management of hazardous wastes and bio-waste, and the separate collection of waste. Finally, you also pushed very hard for an ambitious waste policy agenda during the coming years. This agenda encompasses and reviews the many different pieces of existing EU legislation, ranging from reusability and recyclability of packaging waste, end-of-life vehicles, waste oils, food waste and waste disposal operations, as well as recycling targets for waste other than municipal and packaging waste. Not all of Parliament’s amendments found their way into the final text. I am aware, for instance, that you would have wanted to see an even stricter harmonisation of the calculation rules for recycling. Unfortunately, the Council could not agree on a single measurement point, yet the new legislation still marks a major step forward by ensuring that only waste that enters recycling will be reported under the targets. Over the next years, the Commission will closely monitor the implementation of these new calculation rules to ensure that only input to recycling is reported. If appropriate, the Commission will consider if further harmonisation and calculating recycling targets is feasible. I should finally mention that among the Commission declarations that accompany the package are four declarations responding to points that were particularly important to this House: first, on the policy framework for the circular economy; second, on the collaborative economy; third on microplastics; and fourth, on the reporting of waste data in 2020. Our shared task now is to ensure that the promises enshrined in this Waste Package are actually delivered on the ground. This requires Member States to urgently step up action, building on the progress that many of them are already making to meet existing obligations. Local and regional administrations and businesses will also have a key role to play. Your support in keeping up the pressure for full and effective implementation will be essential. The Commission will continue to support Member States in making the best use of available instruments in terms of new legislation, economic instruments and financial support. We will also provide guidance as requested on many new key provisions, for instance on how to modulate producer fees under extended producer responsibility schemes to promote more circular products. Before concluding, I would like to very briefly touch on the other file in this joint debate – the Standard Reporting Directive. Repealing the existing directive is an important first step towards further administrative simplification and higher levels of legal certainty. The Commission has actively pursued the follow-up to the fitness check on streamlining environmental reporting which aims at increasing transparency, optimising the use of IT tools and reducing the administrative burden for all stakeholders. Before the end of May, we will present a legislative proposal to amend the reporting requirements in a number of environmental directives and regulations modelled on the proposals for the revision of the Drinking Water Directive which you are currently discussing. I believe that there is every opportunity to reach an agreement at first reading on this proposal too, so that the benefits can be delivered already in 2019, before the end of this legislature, and we have something to show for ourselves when we head for elections. We can all be truly proud – and you, especially, can be very proud – of this legislative package. Once properly implemented, the new EU waste legislation will make the European Union the world leader in waste management. The European Parliament has played an essential role in laying a foundation for this transformation and I sincerely hope you will all lend your support to make it happen later this week.

name: João FERREIRA
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. — (PT) Mr President, Commissioner, we agree with more ambitious targets in the field of recycling packaging waste, but we must not lose sight of a few issues. In accordance with the principle of waste management hierarchy, prevention, reduction of packaging waste production and reuse of packaging, in this order, should take precedence over recycling. Schemes for the extension of producer liability appear appropriate to achieve these objectives. The disparity of Member States' starting points with the revised upwards recycling and readiness targets determines the need for separate efforts to achieve the targets set. We do not think that this has been properly taken into account. The existence of new objectives, revised in high, justifies the existence of new means to achieve them. It would therefore be appropriate for the European Union to strengthen the resources available to Member States to support them in the necessary investments, especially those which are lagging behind in the field of waste management infrastructures. But it is the case that this is not happening.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Mr President, before starting to utilise my speaking time, I want to extend my apology that immediately afterwards I will have to return to the Bureau as there is a meeting. Just so you understand that, for a topic so close to my heart, truly so, unfortunately I cannot be here for the whole debate. Very briefly on the topic: I think nobody in this House would doubt that sustainability is absolutely crucial, both in environmental as well as industrial terms. What we now have at hand is a very solid package of legislation. With instruments like eco—design, or legislation on package labelling or energy efficiency and so on we are creating a regulatory environment that can work. What do we do need though, is to change the mindset. The legislation has to be implemented, but it also has to be encouraged. We cannot take it for granted. That is why maybe I would focus also the attention of the Member States on something that, as the shadow in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) on all the proposals, among other things I came up with an annex which basically consists of the incentives that can be provided. The mindset, the incentives and the regulatory environment can work, so I very much hope that we will have a very positive and strong vote on that this week.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: rapporteur of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. — Mr President, rapporteur, Europe currently produces more than 2.5 billion tonnes of waste per year, and only a third of it is utilizes retroactively or is recycled. I think we clearly need new modernized waste legislation to accelerate the transition to a fully circulatory economic model. And although the legislative proposals we have here are the result of long negotiations and compromises, I think they will contribute significantly to a very fundamental change in waste management. Especially since they set clear targets for reducing waste, preventing its creation or strengthening the waste hierarchy. I therefore welcome, for example, the increase in the reuse and recycling target to 70% of the total volume of waste. Or also arrangements for construction waste. In some areas, of course, we could be more ambitious than is being proposed. For example, I still find reducing food waste by 50% by 2030 to be inadequate. Or the pace of reducing the amount of waste and rubbish in the seas could also still be higher. However, I support the compromise and call for support of this proposal by my colleague Bonaféo.

name: Karl-Heinz FLORENZ
text: Mr President, Commissioners. A year ago today, Parliament tabled its first draft. Indeed, Mr Timmermans, we were somewhat worried when you withdrew the first report from your predecessor. But that, I think, has changed for the better. I would like to return to the core of this paper, which is the issue of resource efficiency. This is the cornerstone we have to deal with for our children and the next economic generations, and for this we need harmonised definitions. This was mixed up in Europe. We need clear calculation methods. We are a number further, Mr. Vice President, as you suspected. So we have more or less a calculation method now, and the targets for recycling targets are already very significant. Good countries, which are already a little further on this issue, also say: that is all we can do at the moment. And the harmonisation of standards in recycling is particularly important, as it went down and above. So there have always been great differences between Germany and Austria and there were also annoyances for the middle class. Ultimately, we also want to make industry competitive. After all, competitiveness and sustainability is a medal. And this medal is just meant to strengthen us in a resource-poor continent — that's us, raw materials are scarce. That is why the vote next Wednesday is extremely important. Personally, I believe that the decision from China has a beneficial effect. Of course there's trouble now. But I remember that when I once received a blue letter at school, it was also very salutary. And that's why I think we're on a good way. Commissioner and Mr President. I have a single wish still: I've been working on trash in this house for thirty years. We must finally conquer the enemy within ourselves and really enforce what we decide here. That's exactly what we haven't done in the last few years.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (NL) Mr President, I think that Karl-Heinz Florenz may occasionally talk a little longer because of his record, but together we have also worked, a long time ago, on electrical and electronic waste, and that is a bit the precursor of what we are discussing today. It will not surprise you that I would like to thank all my colleagues in Parliament for the excellent work that has been done, but I would particularly like to thank my good colleague and rapporteur Simona Bonafè, not only for the work that has been done today, but for pulling and pushing and dragging on. this very difficult dossier. Karl-Heinz Florenz referred to this, and at the beginning we were not sure whether the Commission wanted to be ambitious. Under the REFIT, the file was withdrawn, and we were all so scared. Parliament has put a lot of pressure to ensure that there is a proposal. That's good, and thank you for that. It is also extremely important that it is embedded in the Waste Directive, in the global philosophy of the circular economy. That is the last point I would like to raise. Obviously, I'm gonna have to ask you to go a little further. In relation to eco-design, we need to take really tight steps forward. It can no longer be just about the use of electricity, but it really needs to be about the whole circular economy. It must be embedded in the eco-design directive. We are very much requesting party for that.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! I support the goals of a circular economy. However, throughout the legislative process, I raised doubts about the methodology of the inquiry for purposes. It is incomprehensible to me that Poland has not been enrolled in a group of countries that have the possibility of a 5-year longer investigation to a target of 60% of municipal waste treatment — as for example Estonia, Greece, Croatia. Poland, which processed municipal waste at 20% in 2012, came together with Germany, which processed 64%, Austria - 59% or Belgium - 57%. That is, in fact, in a group of countries that already meet the EU target set for 2030 today. Of course, Poland will make every effort to achieve the objectives, but I believe that the directives should be aligned with the realities of the Member States. That's why my delegation will abstain from voting on some elements of this package.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking Simona Bonafè. The last part of her surname, Fe, translates into Swedish as fairy. She has been the good fairy of this process and I sincerely thank her for that. Having said that, I think we are on a fairly complicated mission. Today Helsingin Sanomat, the biggest newspaper in Finland, has a headline saying that the waste basket of a normal Finnish family contains up to 80% of recyclable materials which are not recycled. We usually think that we are very good at doing things. If we are that bad, then I think we are really going to need some fairies going forward. Commissioner Timmermans, I do not know how you can physically turn yourself into a fairy, but you had better try, because we are now going to need the Commission to implement this in the future.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: on behalf of the Verts/Ale Club. — Dear Chairman, Honored Vice-President of the Commission, Honored Colleagues and colleagues, first of all I would like to thank our rapporteur Bonafè who sovereignly led our team through negotiations and showed great skill in negotiating with the Council and the Commission. A big thank you to our advisors and assistants who have done a large technical part of the work in preparing this circular economy package. What I would also point out is that, despite the fact that the Council in some segments was not ambitious, especially in the objectives, the Maltese, Estonian and Bulgarian Presidencies gave the chance for dialogue and compromise. What I consider our great success, especially my club of MPs, is that we have been able to incorporate preventative measures into this package, which are the removal of hazardous substances and decontamination of waste when recycling. By doing so, we've actually opened wide the door to innovation, research, bioeconomics, new materials. This is what actually makes the core of the future circular economy when looking at and using the resources themselves, especially with open waste collection. What I would like to emphasize in the end is that implementation is very important. You, the vice president of the commission, said one statement I often mention: “trash is cash.” European Structural Funds, strategic investments, that's all that actually provides exactly the opportunity for Member States to recognise this and turn our economy into a circular economy of the future.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, let me thank you not only on behalf of my own, but especially our colleague who has already left the European Parliament, Josua, who has always praised the cooperation with you. I have to say that I welcome the agreement negotiated by the European Presidency at the end of last year. However, as with the previous climate package, I also have a lot of mixed emotions from the result. Accepting the package will hopefully lead to more recycling of waste. The new rules set legally binding targets for waste recycling and landfill restrictions. Although these objectives were more ambitious than those set out in the final text. In contrast to the Commission's proposal, some objectives were postponed by 5 years. However, I understand that further adherence to objectives that Member States are unable to meet would lead nowhere and would only delay the start of this much-needed legislation. Personally, I still lack the necessary revision of ecodesign in the package, which I consider to be the key to establishing a true circular economy in the long run.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you also to all my colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs and also the rapporteur, of course, for the excellent work done. I want to say that we will vote in favour of this package, which is a revision of the existing waste directives, meanwhile, because the compromise with the Council seems good to us and that is because, for example, increase the objectives on recycling municipal waste but also those from packaging; because finally we introduce the concept of extended responsibility that will serve everyone, but also because it has been reduced the amount of municipal waste destined for landfills. That for us is very important. However, it should be explained to citizens that it is only municipal waste, which accounts for just 10% of total waste. So Parliament should have been more ambitious, not least to set a precedent than when it comes to changing targets on commercial waste, industrial and industrial waste one tomorrow obtained from the constructions and demolitions of the constructions themselves. For example, a binding target to reduce food waste of 30% for 2025 and 50% for 2050, a target for readiness for reuse — absent — and a target for the preparation for the reuse of packaging, the obligatory ability of the vacuum system to render. Citizens want these things. Above all, from our point of view, it took an absolute ban on the incineration of all kinds of rejection, as well as the elimination of subsidies to fossil sources, from which all kinds of refusal. Without these measures, unfortunately, the package we are approving makes a timid improvement in a situation that needs, from our point of view, a strong acceleration if we really want our economy to become circular.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her demanding work and the results she has achieved. A long and technical negotiation, which with the vote on Wednesday will allow us to demonstrate our willingness to transform the European economy, through the identification of instruments capable of creating a new development model and a more sustainable industrial and production system. The agreement provides binding targets on waste reduction and recycling, for municipal waste placed in landfill, and will strengthen our hierarchy of waste by placing prevention, the reuse and recycling above landfill supplies and incineration. All important provisions that will have to be transposed by the Member States, in order to ensure a real transformation to our economy, from a disposable model to a circular paradigm. Finally, a reference goes to food waste, because we have insisted strongly on a 50% reduction in food waste: a battle I believed in from the beginning because we cannot and should not forget about the weakest and most needy.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: — Mr President, the current consumption patterns are environmentally completely unsustainable and the end of the road is starting to be visible. I would like to stress the responsibility of producers in solving the problem Consumers buy products in the store in the packaging where they are offered. What need to satisfy, for example, the fact that individual fruits are sold packaged in disposable plastic packaging? Producers must be obliged to package their products in a way that exerts minimal pressure on the environment. Today, many plastic grades can be mixed up in the same consumer product, making it very difficult to recycle it. More ecological design, production and use of packaging would significantly reduce the amount of waste generated, so that is the direction we need to steer development. Forests are a renewable resource, from which processed products provide an environmentally sustainable alternative in many cases, so product development in its sector should be promoted.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I am very pleased that we are having this debate today. We all want to entrust and hand over to our descendants a good and clean planet that will offer them what they need. We are actually quite far from that right now. We risk that this will not be the case. The importance of this issue also shows that, at least at the beginning of the debate, two Commissioners were there: Commissioner Vella and also Vice-President Timmermanns. It is very important to the Commission, to us too. We need to see that we avoid waste, that when we get there, we recycle it as much as possible. I'm especially concerned about the ocean — everyone knows that I love the ocean. We have just managed to work together with several colleagues in Brussels to set up a plastic exhibition showing how serious waste problems can be for the ocean. A plastic island is 1.6 million square kilometres in the Pacific Ocean alone. If we want this to be avoided, then we need to rethink. We also have to recognise that we are creating alternative products, including collecting and recycling existing waste. This is a great opportunity for new startups, which can also bring new jobs. We just have enough to talk about this. This package is a very good one, and I am glad that we will decide on this.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: — Respecting resources, efficient use and reducing waste of raw materials are the main objectives of the economy in circular circulation. These ambitious goals have been included in the package in question. First of all, however, it should be emphasized that our most important objective should be to prevent waste or to extend the life of products. Closed circulation is of particular importance in the case of bio-economy and biological, renewable raw materials, including biowaste, including food waste. But there are other challenges ahead, too. This is an example of the future of transport (I am, among others, rapporteur for supporting clean vehicles) and here we also need to look for synergies with new technologies being introduced. One of these solutions is to promote alternative energy sources, such as biomethane, a fuel derived from recycled organic waste, in the transport sector. Whereas, if we want to develop electromobility, we need to allocate resources to research on a new type of sustainable and recyclable batteries.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking in this debate as shadow rapporteur of the rules for the preparation of environmental reports, a technical dossier, on which we have been able to work in dispatched and positive manner with all political groups. However, the occasion of the joint debate is a good one to broaden our gaze on the issue of the circular economy. Today we are discussing the conclusion of the important work on waste directives, which set the targets for 2035; but in recent weeks we have begun to debate, or will do so very soon, others fundamental elements of the necessary transition to the circular economy. The European Commission's proposal to introduce indicators on how to assess performance is crucial and we had already supported a call for this four years ago. The plastic strategy and the forthcoming legislative proposal on single-use plastic finally set the initiative in motion with respect to the huge industrial and environmental paradox represented by this product: imagined to last over time to infinity, it is instead cast, in the vast majority of cases, as a rejection no longer usable and destroys marine ecosystems and beyond. The circular economy, in short, is not a dream, a fixation of environmentalists, but an urgent need to combine development and sustainability.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: – Madam President, tonnes of paper, glass, biowaste and even metals lie buried on the outskirts of our cities, threatening water supplies and air quality. This is not a future for our citizens and they do not wish or need it. Human beings simply wish to live and prosper in a safe and caring environment. The circular economy is therefore not only about waste recycling or targets, it is actually about air, water, new jobs, new resources and money – money that we can dig out of the bin and put to work for us in a new economy that never existed before. The circular economy is one of those policies which has the general support of the public and where EU added value is crystal clear. Implementation is, unfortunately, another story, and it will take a lot of effort by the Member States to make sure these policies are going to be implemented efficiently. I wish to thank the Commission and the rapporteurs for making a good proposal even better, and for allowing much—needed flexibility for countries that need more time to get to where we all need to be. If we make the circular economy a success story, it will become part of the new narrative that the future of Europe needs.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Madam President! In addition to climate protection, the circular economy is the second important pillar of sustainable development on this planet Earth. We are making good progress with the Circular Economy package, but we are still a long way from achieving our goal. Landfills should be a discontinued model. It is not about waste, but about raw materials and recyclables that can be reused and recycled. That is why it is important that we not only collect separately that we not only recycle, but also that we create the secondary raw material market so that these things really get into circulation. I see that we have worked hard here, especially the rapporteur. The Commission's action plan was not so ambitious, and I hope that the plastics strategy will be faster. Above all, we must also avoid plastic, and the plastic tax should not be a taboo either. I think we need to give incentives, and then producers and consumers follow. So tomorrow, I think, a big step forward, but we're still far from the finish.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Mr President, the separation and re-use of waste must be increased. By 2035, the dumping of waste or garbage dumps should be over almost everywhere. In the Netherlands we are at the forefront. Through this legislation, the Member States of the Union must finally make serious progress towards the real circular economy within the European internal market. Waste of raw materials is simply unwise. This legislation saves both our environment and our collective wallet for governments, producers and consumers alike. So it's about the future of our children. From the outset, I have been committed to more ambition in these recycling targets. Greater emphasis on waste innovation, including recovery of minerals from soil ash and drastically reducing waste landfill. Unfortunately, the European Parliament has not fully supported this higher ambition. Or supported, but the Member States have weakened those higher ambitions a little. That is particularly unfortunate. The European waste technology sector now offers enormous opportunities thanks to the persistence of this Parliament. We have to work with this because this legislation finally enforces the circular investment of governments. Finally, circular innovation simply means ecological and economic optimisation, and farmers in Europe have been doing that for hundreds of years.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I have very, very many requests for the procedure for spontaneous speeches that follow. Usually it is planned for five minutes. That is why I will give the floor to seven Members and ask the others to be lenient, because we have other, even very important issues that we have to discuss. Spontaneous Speaking

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Commissioner Vella, the circular economy is a way to limit pressure on our planet's wealth sources and raw materials, to reduce energy expenditure and ultimately to help tackle climate change. But - Vice-President Timmermans is not here - we are not all protagonists. I come from a country which, along with nine others, has been extended to comply with the framework for landfill. However, the forecast that, by 2030, all waste that can be recycled will stop going to landfill and that there will be a uniform way of valuing landfills helps to adjust. But there is a need to change the habits of citizens, there is a need to change the direction of representatives of local government, and here I will talk about a great example from Vilnius, Lithuania, where the creation of a biomass power plant was financed, and municipal waste, at the level, together with the Juncker project, together with the Cohesion Fund, of more than EUR 300 million in total. It is in this direction that we must take, such practices must be adopted.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after more than three years of work, this Parliament will finally approve the regulatory package which can launch a real revolution in the industrial field. The agreement reached in the trilogue phase is not exactly the one desired by the ENVI commission but traces an unequivocal path towards a new development model capable of combining industrial growth and environmental sustainability. The new waste plan sets out medium- to long-term objectives, with clear and inescapable stakes, such as strengthening measures to prevent waste generation, firstly strengthening the extended liability of the producer, the extension of separate collection obligations to organic, textile and hazardous waste and the maximum 10% quota for landfill waste disposal by 2035. In line with the Sustainable Development Goals, there is a 50% reduction in food waste and the 65% recycling threshold by all Member States. I congratulate Mrs Bonafè on her important result, but the real work begins now: the European Union has a duty to demonstrate to the rest of the world the effective sustainability of a model economical circular type.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the circular economy is particularly important for environmental protection. Practically means reuse and recycling. On an economic level, the benefit is EUR 1.8 trillion, creating 2 million jobs, increasing the competitiveness of the European economy, boosting innovation and research. So, in practice, we need to recycle waste, prevent waste generation, reduce food waste and marine litter. At the same time, of course, we must stop the disgrace with landfills, as they are called “landfills”, and I am thinking in particular of the toxic function of the dump in the Tribe. Immediate interventions are needed in order to move on to another way of municipal waste management, in order to have recycling and of course important intervention, because only in this way can there be protection of the health of residents in general, and of the inhabitants of Attica in particular, from carcinogenic dump of the Tribe.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Madam President! We're well on our way to a real circular economy and it's actually in place to celebrate a little bit. The legislation we call here the Waste Package raises ambitions for both recycling and reuse within the EU. Our targets are ambitious, even for a country like Sweden, which has come up at a 50% recycling rate and next to zero in landfill. For the first time, targets are being put in place to reduce marine debris and come to grips with the food wind. We throw huge amounts of food within the EU — an estimated 89 million tonnes a year. Now we are raising the ambition so that this waste should be used rather than going straight from the field to the garbage mountain. Ultimately: This is smart economics. In the old peasant community, nothing was thrown away and it is an economic insanity that year after year we create products with built-in ageing, that huge amounts of plastic end up in the sea and fine food being thrown. End of toil and toil, ahead for a future where waste will be our best friend!

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, because of global warming, many raw materials, many natural resources on which we depend, are gradually falling down, and if this problem is not detected quickly, then there will be a shortage in a few years. So the issue of the circular economy is very important because it contributes, among other things, to the protection of the environment and hence to the survival of the planet. In order to achieve this, however, we will have to use the various products under a circular system of development which means the use of one product, its recirculation and the recall of another similar product. Therefore, the various waste must be used very carefully and carefully, and various incentives must be given by the Member States so that this waste can be attractive to industrial exploitation. Various institutional factors must also be legislated in order to protect this effort, which, as I said, is so important.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President! Commissioner Frans Timmermans said the biggest trouble we have with the execution of all that we stand for ourselves, 'he told the truth, he went de facto to the bottom of it. Whereas, I'll add, we have one more problem — the problem of time. We are very slow to respond to a rapidly changing situation. We are not keeping up with the reduction of hazardous waste dumping, hazardous waste production and the lack of responsibility for hazardous waste production. We have a great deal of trouble with fiscal problems too, for example, it's easier to throw food out today than to give it to someone because it's taxed. We need to respond more quickly to these challenges that dynamically changing the world of civilization underlines us. Please note: more than three years of negotiating over the package on which we were all agreed is definitely too long.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Madam President, in one year, the total volume of waste generated by the European Union represents 2.5 billion tonnes, of which 1.6 billion have not been recycled or reused, which is a huge loss for the European economy. In urban areas, only 43% of the waste is recycled, the rest being stored in landfills, 31%, or incinerated, 26%. All of this waste is an important source of raw materials for the economy, especially if we take into account that the natural reserves of raw materials are limited in time and some of them risk not being accessible at affordable prices in the coming years. Turning waste into resources must be a desideratum for Member States, just like the circular economy. The use of packaging from biological materials will generate price reductions and a lower environmental impact. Europe must pay greater attention to hazardous waste that seriously affects the health and safety of the population, the quality of water, but also the environment.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: Madam President, it is a fact that among the countries of the European Union there is inequality in the management of waste waste. There are countries such as Greece that send 75% of the garbage to “landfills”, as they are called, polluting the environment, the sea, the water, the food chain. In my country, central governments, past and present, and regional authorities insist on creating landfills and even mixed waste, destroying the environment and polluting the aquifer. There is no landfill in Greece that does not have problems. Life is at stake in Tribe; in Katerini there is toxic marine pollution; in Samos it was destroyed in the sea; in Lefkimmi it was built on an aquifer. As we speak, residents in Aegialeia have excluded the landfill of the area which is still operating without permission since 2015. It is clear that a country such as Greece that recycles 17% of waste cannot reach the intermediate target, so it is urgently necessary to adopt the act to nihilate the landfill and also needs enhanced assistance from the European Union, as in general the countries that are delayed in waste management.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the Members who have contributed to this fine and inspiring debate and for their overall support. For me, it confirms once again that creating a circular economy is one of the big challenges of our time. But it is also offers us huge opportunities, especially in the environmental, economic and social sectors. We urgently need to make more durable and recyclable products and, at the end of the cycle, use waste as a resource and channel it back into the economy. Taking a sustainable path requires multiple changes, of a technological, organisational, financial, social and also educational nature. The road ahead may seem daunting but we can make the transformation happen. Embracing the circular economy offers significant opportunities as it will unleash new sources of innovation, growth, employment and well-being. It is for all these reasons that the European Commission and the European Union at large have made the circular economy a key political priority and that we are implementing an ambitious plan with far-reaching initiatives. A central plan of action involving taking waste legislation in the European Union to the next level with ambitious, legally binding landfill reduction and recycling targets for the period up to 2035 alongside targeted waste prevention measures. It is encouraging to see that over the past two decades many Member States have gradually improved their waste management in line with the EU waste hierarchy. In 1995, on average 64% of our waste was still landfilled. In 2000, the average had been reduced to 55%, while the average recycling rate stood at 25%. Fifteen years later, in 2015, landfilling of household waste in the EU as a whole had dropped to 25% with recycling having increased to 45%. Yet, challenges and big differences between EU countries remain. We are not closing the loop yet. In 2015, twelve Member States still landfilled over 50% of their household waste and six of them incinerated 40% or more. Regarding the concern expressed by Ms Wiśniewska, I would like to clarify that Poland can get a five-year derogation for recycling and landfilling targets, so maybe she can reconsider your position and vote in favour instead of abstaining. With regards to Mr Pedicini’s comment that we missed a crucial chance to set legally binding targets for other waste streams like food waste, marine litter, the reuse of packaging and so on, the new waste legislation foresees a large number of review clauses asking the Commission to assess the feasibility to set such targets in the next years. More and bold action is still very much needed. The new waste legislation that we hope you will approve later this week, will provide fresh impetus to this area. The Commission will do all it can to make the new legislation deliver on the ground. I cannot conclude without thanking the rapporteur, Ms Simona Bonafè. I would also like to take the opportunity to thank the shadow rapporteurs as well as all the other MEPs for their commitment, contribution and support to this dossier. As Ms Engström said, we have reason to celebrate but let us not forget that this is not the end of the road. It is the beginning of our walk. Let’s continue working together as we have done so far. It is true, nothing is easy but let’s be positive and look for the opportunities in the problems and not look at the problems in the opportunities.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it has not escaped anyone during this debate how much the circular economy is a leverage we have available to revive Europe's competitiveness and a more sustainable economic development that protects the environment, just as it has not escaped anyone who still has so much to do: I think of prevention measures, I think of the need to consider waste too industrial. But we all know that this package, which I hope will pass on Wednesday with a broad consensus, has never been considered an arrival point but a starting point, which must be strengthened with actions envisaged in the action plan, in particular with ecodesign measures but also — and here I am meeting the concerns of some colleagues and in particular colleagues in countries that are a little further behind — also emphasizing how the circular economy, in order to be really implemented, needs adequate financial instruments to build infrastructure and also to support businesses in renewal of their production system. That is why I think investment will play a crucial role, a fundamental role and the next multiannual financial framework, which the Commission is about to present, will have to insert, if we want to be credible, also the issue of resource efficiency among its load-bearing axes. In conclusion, now we just have to show that we are credible. The rules are there: they only need to be put in place and we must be convinced that the path we have taken is the right one, especially for the next generations.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Commissioner, during the debate we have indeed seen the importance and potential that the circular economy has for Europe's development in a great balance between environmental, economic and social factors, with an important role in education you are right, Commissioner. I would like to thank all the people who worked in the dossier on environmental information, especially Andrés and Kristi, from the Council, Stefan and Julia from this same house, and Andrew from the Commission, without whom we would not have been able to achieve the speed with which we have processed it. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the work of the shadow rapporteurs, who, with their cooperation, have helped to enrich and increase the efficiency of the report, which will help, as I said in my first speech, to pave the way for the implementation of the circular economy. When we started this term, President Juncker set as a priority to create the necessary conditions for job creation and the impetus for re-industrialisation after the dark years of the economic crisis that struck and continues to hit Europe. In the moments before COP21 we all conjugated ourselves so that Europe would take the international leadership it had lost in recent years and committed ourselves that the progress of our economy would have to go hand in hand with the environment. And next Wednesday we must take this first step for the European economy of the 21st century, a path that we must go along with European citizens, their industry, their social partners, to strengthen the ties that unite us in the European project in the coming decades; a real, achievable project which each and every one of us. we can feel involved every day of our lives.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 18 April 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. — Although in very small steps, the circular economy advances. Of course, if you look at the compromise reached in the trilogues, we are still far from the objectives set by the European Parliament. The worst outcome of the negotiation is the landfill of waste: against the maximum limit of 5% by 2030, proposed by Parliament, a final compromise has been reached, setting the target target at the 10% and grants states time until 2035. I regret that the targets for readiness for reuse have been cancelled, which would have had a positive impact on waste reduction and job creation. It remains firm, however, our commitment to achieving far more ambitious results such as the introduction of binding food waste reduction targets of 30% to 2025 and 50% to 2050, as well as preparation for the reuse of packaging; the compulsory introduction of the vacuum system; the prohibition on incineration of all waste and, not least, the elimination of subsidies to fossil sources that are at the origin of all rejection. Without these measures, as mentioned, the package which, however, is worth approving, will only record minor improvements.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. — After more than two years of painstaking negotiations on the draft legislative package, but also almost four years since the presentation of the first proposal for the transition of the European economy towards the circular economy, negotiations between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission reached an agreement on the final a proposal for a package of new European laws supporting the implementation of the EU Action Plan for the Circular Economy. The laws include amendments to the Waste Framework Directive, the Waste Vehicle Directive, the Waste Batteries and Accumulators Directive and Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment and the Waste Landfill Directive. The package provides guidelines for Member States to achieve the right balance of energy generation capacity from waste, highlighting the role of the waste hierarchy, in which waste management opportunities are ranked according to sustainability, while the main priority is the prevention of waste and its recycling. The package also helps to optimise Member States' contributions to the Energy Union and to exploit opportunities for cross-border partnership where appropriate and in line with environmental objectives. Croatia has been trying to solve waste management problems for many years. Although we are one of the countries that recognized the possibilities of the circular economy early, we conducted waste management more or less effectively and unsuccessfully. The new legislative package, as well as the experiences of other successful Member States, should be a new and strong incentive to truly keep Croatia beautiful and ours.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: in writing. – The adoption of the waste package is an important and welcome step in the right direction. Europe is dependent on the import of raw materials. We cannot afford to waste precious materials, as is now happening. We need a waste hierarchy that can act as a strong catalyst for the move towards a circular economy. Recycling capacity in Europe should be developed. We need separate waste collection, including optical sorting to make use of materials to their highest possible value and to feed them into new processes, closing the loops to ensure high quality resources maintain their value throughout the recycling process. The Finnish bottle recycling system of PEP bottles, based on a bottle deposit, is an efficiently functioning example to build on. Ultimately, what we must aim for is to design out all waste, and have products that are upgradeable, reusable, repairable, and recyclable. The targets and measures now adopted are not enough to get us there. Therefore, the review of the package and its measures and targets will be an important opportunity to raise the ambition level as we go forward.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: in writing. — The waste directives that are now being adopted and the more stringent recycling targets can significantly boost the circular economy. Effective recycling and reuse of materials reduces ambient load and emissions, while ensuring greater adequacy of raw materials. It's not just about the environment and health, but also about the economy. The circular economy improves competitiveness, innovation and growth and creates jobs in Europe. But it can only work if it is market-driven and supportive for manufacturers and consumers alike. The growing environmental awareness among consumers is also driving companies to seek solutions that are simultaneously cost-effective and environmentally friendly. Each year, around 2.5 billion tonnes of waste is generated in the European Union. Although municipal waste accounts for less than a tenth of this, it is a challenging part of waste production and treatment. Currently, for example, 95 per cent of all plastic is used only once. Only five per cent of plastic waste ends up properly recycling and 40 per cent as mixed waste in landfills. Plastic production is still estimated to even triple globally by 2050. Under the new targets that are now being adopted, at least 55% of municipal waste will be recycled in the Member States by 2025. In the future, separate collections of metal, glass, paper and biowaste must be arranged for plastics and, from 2025, textiles. As we know, there are already great differences between Member States in the recycling and recovery of waste. Many do not even meet current recycling targets, so the new tougher targets require significant changes in policies and processes.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. — (PT) The European Union (EU) is the area in the world most dependent on the import of raw materials. On the other hand, it leads the global commitment to the sustainability of the planet and the fight against climate change. The commitment to the circular economy is a necessary complement to the energy transition. Only by implementing this package will the EU be able to achieve levels of sustainability and competitiveness that allow it to settle on the technological and social frontier of the changing world. The current model of resource management is economically, socially and environmentally unsustainable. You have to seize the opportunity to change. Create wealth, create jobs, create better quality of life for people. As one of the shadow rapporteurs, I advocated and proposed amendments aimed at progressively abolishing landfill until complete elimination, ban landfill of waste that is subject to selective collection, create a framework programme with a schedule of objectives, monitor the shipment of waste within the EU and for third countries and improve quantification methodologies associated with landfills. The time has come for action. The circular economy has to be much more than a good narrative. It must be a concrete reality with positive impacts on the daily lives of Europeans.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report (A8-0059/2018) by Daciana Octavia Sârbu, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the implementation of the Seventh Environmental Action Programme (2017/2030 (INI)).

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Environment Action Programme includes a wide range of regulations and policies with many objectives and targets. If fully applied, it would make considerable improvements in the environment, health and quality of life. As we approach the end of the current programme, we need to assess how well it has been implemented and what changes would be needed for a future programme. I want to thank the hundreds of stakeholder representatives who have contributed views to this evaluation process. Many positively evaluated the program. The benefits to citizens and the environment, the shaping of a long-term vision and strategic orientation for decision-makers have been recognised. However, there is a huge gap between the expectations of this programme and the concrete results it produces. Progress has been made in some areas. In terms of resource efficiency and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, European Union legislation has a positive impact and clear progress is being made towards a more resource-efficient economy. In other areas, however, implementation is very weak. The European Union's natural capital is deteriorating, with devastating effects on the environment and services provided by ecosystems such as water, air or food. Environmental health threats are sometimes difficult to measure and we do not have sufficient data. In other cases, however, evidence is not missing. For example, it is clear that constantly high emissions from road transport force millions of people to breathe polluted air. The problem often lies in the fact that Member States do not meet the basic standards laid down by regulations such as the Birds or Habitats Directive or air quality legislation. EU policies are not always compatible with each other or complementary to national priorities. Better adaptation The implementation of agricultural policies to environmental objectives is essential, both for the protection of the environment and for the future security of food resources. Food security and environmental protection are not opposing priorities. Progress in nature conservation and biodiversity could be much greater if existing funds had been used more wisely. The European Court of Auditors identified several cases of inefficient use of European funds in projects with an impact on environmental objectives. Both the Commission and the Member States can support the better use of funds to bring results. At regional and municipal level, urban planning is vital to solving many resource efficiency and environmental health threats. That's why it's surprising that the section of the programme that deals with cities is criticized by stakeholders for not defining clear goals. At the municipal level, virtually many of the measures that ensure the achievement of the objectives is applied. That is why the municipal authorities need clarity on the results they are required and they need financial and political means to implement these solutions. Colleagues, time does not allow me to mention all the aspects that I have highlighted in my report, but I would like to thank all of you for the substantial contributions and the efforts made by all parties to adopt a compromise text. Our work shows that a broad political agreement can be reached on problems, but also on solutions. Commissioner, a clear majority of the Committee on the Environment called for a new global post-2020 programme.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Ms Sârbu and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on their excellent report on the implementation of the 7th Environment Action Programme (EAP). This initiative is well timed and contains several useful recommendations, which we will look into carefully, as the Commission is also working on its own evaluation. Your report points to specific areas for improvement. Land and soil degradation and, more broadly, the sustainability of agriculture and of our mobility are among the areas in which a lot still needs to be done. It is, however, fair to say that overall there has been good progress and we are working to meet our goals to protect our climate and pave the way for a low-carbon and circular economy. The Circular Economy Package, including our new waste legislation and the Commission’s plastics strategy, will help us on our way to decoupling economic growth from environmental pressures, including carbon emissions. We will continue to deliver on this, for example by delivering a proposal on single—use plastics before the end of May, in addition to a legislative proposal for water reuse in agricultural irrigation. The European Union is also well on track to meet its climate and energy targets for 2020. We expect emissions to reduce by more than 20% by 2020, taking the first steps that put the EU towards a transformation to a low-carbon economy, as stated in the 7th EAP. As part of a global effort to limit the average temperature increase to well below two degrees centigrade compared to pre-industrial levels, we are also working towards reducing by 2050 greenhouse gas emissions by 80% to 95%, compared to 1990 levels. Under the Paris Agreement, the EU has pledged to reduce emissions by at least 40% domestically by 2030 compared to 1990. We have taken key steps on putting in place the legislative framework on how to get there. I can mention here the EU emissions trading system (ETS) revision for after 2020, the targets to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at Member State-level in sectors other than ETS and the regulation of absorptions and emissions in the land sectors. You discussed the last two earlier this evening with my colleague, Commissioner Arias Cañete. In terms of quality of life and a healthy environment for our citizens, we have worked hard together to protect people’s health from exposure to harmful pollutants. In 2016, the revised National Emission Ceilings Directive set ambitious 2020 and 2030 emission reduction commitments for five main air pollutants, including particulate matter. We ratified the Minamata Convention to protect our citizens from the emission and release of mercury. We have reviewed our flagship chemical legislation ‘REACH’ and are checking whether the broader chemicals acquis is still fit for purpose. These are all important steps towards a non-toxic environment. We have also made progress on the so-called enabling framework, with specific initiatives to close gaps relating to knowledge, financing and implementation. The Environment Implementation Review (EIR) and the environmental compliance action plan will help to make this happen, not against but together with the Member States in all areas, including our fight against air pollution. Our nature action plan to improve the implementation of the Birds and Habitats Directives is an important step forward in strengthening the conservation of biodiversity, complementing the Invasive Alien Species Regulation, which is tackling an important driver of biodiversity loss in the EU. But 2020 is around the corner and we need to do more to achieve our biodiversity targets. A major challenge is the alarming decline of pollinators. This requires urgent and decisive action, and we will respond soon with an initiative to address this problem in line with what this Parliament has called for. The Commission’s recently adopted action plan for sustainable finance will make Europe a frontrunner in shifting trillions of euros towards those investments needed to build a sustainable economy. I welcome your strong support for an ambitious environmental agenda. We need to successfully address environmental challenges to meet the Sustainable Development Goals. The European Union has always been, and should continue to be, a frontrunner for sustainability and we must continue to show leadership in this process at all levels: at global level and, even more importantly, here at home.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: for the PPE Group. — Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for identifying what areas of environmental protection show the greatest shortcomings precisely in terms of performance those objectives set out by the Member States of the European Union and the Union as a whole. In addition to properly improving the implementation of the legislation adopted, it is also in place to streamline funding at EU level in particular. Not that there's little money, but it's primarily about poor management of that finances. I personally find it very important to state that the greatest environmental threats to health are most evident precisely in those urban areas themselves, but also in suburban ones areas, in those adjacent areas, so-called suburbanization. It should be stressed that emissions of air pollutants together with unbalanced zoning and infrastructure have unseen economic and environmental impacts, as well as impacts on human health. Member States, including my home Czech Republic, should therefore make more efforts in implementing European legislation.

name: Pavel POC
text: for the S&D Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, congratulations to my colleague Sârbu, I am very pleased that my amendments on pesticides and endocrine disruptors have passed through the Committee, because the situation in the field of chemicals is quite unfavorable. In particular, this is seen in Priority Objective 3, where we focus on protecting Union citizens from environmental pressures and risks affecting their health. It is not clear from the report's conclusions whether the EU will succeed in meeting targets of measuring and reducing exposure to chemicals that are harmful to human health and the environment. We are still not doing perfectly well to ensure the sustainable use of pesticides — this is why EP focuses on two other implementation reports on its own initiative. Unfortunately, with regard to the implementation of Regulation 1107/2009 on plant protection products, the results of the research are quite alarming and only confirm the justification of setting up a special committee of Parliament to Union authorisation procedures for pesticides.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President, Thank you to Mrs Sârbu and to Commissioner Vella for a good report containing reasonable answers. We've been delighted with the cooperation with you. I particularly need to emphasise that one of the serious shortcomings of the European Union's environmental efforts is that our biodiversity has gone so terribly. It has become a big discussion in Denmark, but I think in many countries that the number of insects has fallen precipitously. And it's really rampant! We know it from our car windows, which suddenly no longer have to have special washing, since there are no insects! It's gone rampant beyond the birds, but it goes beyond life! And biodiversity itself is at the heart of our all of the lives of the same. It has tremendous value to the climate too. I think that we should give it special weight and ask the Commission to take its responsibility as guardian of the Treaty considerably more seriously and to come after those countries that are skimming on compliance with the requirements imposed on both pesticides and for the protection of biotopes, so that we have a chance to have nature saved.

name: Stefan ECK
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner. Courage and determination are unfortunately not always among the qualities of the Commission and this House, even if the political will is there. As a result, we have to admit today that we will definitely not achieve the objectives of the Seventh Environmental Action Programme, because that would have required a revision of many policy areas — especially the common agricultural policy, which is currently being reviewed. Thus, the Commission could now demonstrate how seriously it takes the environmental objectives. We can't wait to see whether it will propose incentives for higher environmental standards in agriculture, whether it intends to massively reduce pesticide use and will finally put a stop to the excessive use of antibiotics in factory farming. The Commission must finally recognise that substantial improvements in environmental protection and food safety can only be achieved if production methods and socio-consumer behaviour change dramatically. Commissioner, you could make a significant contribution to this. Just courage dare to do the impossible! Perhaps it will also work to achieve environmental goals in the future.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Seventh Environmental Action Programme sets out the environmental objectives to be achieved by the Union and its Member States by 2020. Despite its qualities, the report before our vote seems to be a litany of regrets and reproaches addressed to all European policies that would not sufficiently integrate environmental issues into their objectives. Agriculture, together with our common agricultural policy, is particularly attacked in this report. It constitutes “an obstacle to the achievement of the objectives of the Programme of Action”. Agriculture in Europe is plural, diverse and multifaceted. Behind the notion of agriculture, there are men. Who are we talking to? Who are we talking about? Who are we targeting? While results are already underway, it is certain that farmers are carrying out a real public service mission for the Union and its citizens. This mission must be valued at its fair value, but it is too little so, and the equally economic dimension of agricultural activity should not be denied. Without the economic sustainability of farms, there will be no progress in terms of the environment or climate. Commissioner, what other policy can say the same?

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I think there is growing awareness year by year of the importance of protecting our environment. This was a slow burner at the start, but particularly after COP21 – where I had the honour of representing Parliament – I think the public at large are now behind us in our efforts to improve the environment because of necessity, both in terms of health, but also in terms of biodiversity and the life we enjoy. The Commission are coming forward with a whole series of packages which, taken together, will play a huge part in that regard.  The Commission referred to plastics financing, and also of course if we look at the clean energy package, it is all feeding into getting proper proposals that must be implemented at Member State level, and I think we should be pointing the finger more at the Member States who are trying to get out of their obligations, rather than at the Commission.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has robust environmental legislation whose poor and ineffective implementation is a long-standing problem. This is why, while it has ambitious objectives, the Seventh Environment Action Programme will fail to achieve the desired results. One of the causes is surely the poor integration of environmental concerns into other strategic areas. But there is much more: for example, there has been no progress on developing a Union strategy for a non-toxic environment and reducing exposure to harmful substances; there is also a lot of uncertainty about the data provided, due to the lack of indicators and the limitation of existing indicators. The European Environment Agency itself is pointing out slowdowns in progress in different areas. Certainly, funding for certain objectives is inadequate for the correct implementation of the 7th Environment Programme, but it must be said that, in several cases, the expected results have not been achieved due to of the inadequacy of financial management rather than lack of resources.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the Seventh Environment Action Programme is particularly important and, of course, we must focus on protecting public health and food safety. However, Mr Vella, I would like to raise a serious question to you, namely the import of agricultural products from third countries and, in particular, the question of the import of agricultural products from Turkey. These agricultural products are grown without any protection and without applying the rules on banned pesticides and fertilisers, so there is a serious question of how to ensure consumer protection. Should not additional phyto-health checks be carried out on these dangerous agricultural products imported into the European Union and coming from Turkey? It is a serious matter, because we cannot only impose, as we rightly impose, rules within the European Union, but also have Turkish agricultural products grown with pesticides that do not meet the standards and give them to consumers here in the European Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: — Madam President, the 7th Environmental Action Programme, the limited concrete impact on reality and the fragility of the resources that are affected by it, particularly financial ones, show the low level of priority that the European Union has given to this area. Propaganda does not arrive, especially when concrete actions or do not accompany it or work in the opposite direction. In essence, we still face a framework of inconsistency between the objectives proclaimed in the field of the environment and the content of the relevant sectoral policies, from agricultural policy to trade policy, among others. Many of the recommendations made by this Parliament prior to the definition of this programme have not been accepted, for example in terms of adequate funding for the protection of biodiversity and forests, strengthening the resources of the LIFE programme or the provision of sufficient resources for the conservation of values protected by Natura 2000 Network. Unfortunately, at the moment there is nothing to suggest that the next multiannual financial framework will fill these shortcomings. On the contrary, other priorities of the European Union are.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Sârbu for this report. As shadow rapporteur I very much appreciated the result we have achieved in photographing the implementation of the Seventh Environment Action Programme: in committee we set out the issues open and areas where the Union's environmental policy must take priority action, with those serious and concrete responses that have been lacking to date. To prevent living well within the limits of the planet becoming an impossible mission, we must carry out a real U-turn in many areas: for example, stopping the erosion of natural capital and of biodiversity, make the air of our cities breathable and reform the authorization of pesticides. These are just some of the many challenges we face and pretending they don't exist is the biggest mistake we can make. That is why I hope that attempts to weaken this report, especially by the Group of the PPE and, in particular among all people, hide the role and impact of agriculture — especially livestock farming intensive — on the environment do not find any space during tomorrow's vote.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: — In the 7th Environmental Action Report, we saw and perceived progress in individual areas, as well as the challenges ahead, especially in the field of air, water, food. And we know that Europe is changing very rapidly and, thank God, we are making many progress in the field of environmental parameters. In terms of agricultural policy, I think agriculture is ahead of a very big challenge of how to feed more and more people. So I think one of the areas that needs to be highlighted in future agricultural policy is the acceleration of precision agriculture. This is to ensure less use of all preparations and also provide greater traceability to make it easier to track what is actually happening in nature. Important in the bioeconomy: new products to replace fossil fuels. In any case, biodiversity and I am delighted that on May 20 we will celebrate the first World Bee Day, which will be in Slovenia and is an indicator of the state of bees and the environment in nature.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank our dear colleagues for their interesting suggestions, and this debate is very timely – not only for our own evaluation of the 7th Environment Action Programme (EAP), but even more for the upcoming reflections on the next environmental priorities. Your report on the 7th EAP, rightly pointed out some shortcomings in these current practices.
