I fully agree with the need for better policy coherence and increased integration of environmental objectives into other policies. Mr Marias referred to pesticide residues in imported feed. This is, as you understand, not my area, but there are standards in place which apply to imports to ensure the health of EU citizens. The next steps in these debates are the upcoming Multiannual Financial Framework and the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). I can assure you that there is strong recognition of the importance of environmental mainstreaming, and I am working closely with my colleagues in the College to ensure that environmental and climate-related challenges are duly reflected in our proposals. This is particularly important for the Common Agricultural Policy, which needs to do more for water, nature and biodiversity. In its current form, the policy is not delivering as expected, despite the significant funding dedicated to greening. This has also been confirmed by the European Court of Auditors, so I am pressing strongly to rectify this in the context of our upcoming proposals. Specifically on environmental mainstreaming in the future CAP, I count on the European Parliament to ensure that this will be reflected in the final agreement of the co-legislators.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to thank you all for your contribution to this debate. People expect better results in this area, expect faster progress in areas where they are expected, such as combating pollution or reducing biodiversity losses. To meet these expectations, to protect the environment more effectively, we need to learn as much as we can from the shortcomings of the current action programme, but also from its successful examples, so that the eighth programme is more efficient, with more calibrated objectives. I hope that, immediately after the evaluation of the current programme, the Commission will come up with a proposal for the next one. I am convinced that through the contribution of all the institutions involved, we can have a good programme and, through closer cooperation with national authorities, the results that citizens want can be achieved in its application. The European Union must ensure economic growth, but in tandem with environmental protection. This is why the new Common Agricultural Policy, as well as transport and fisheries policies, needs ambitious targets to ensure sustainability. Future European policies must be focused on innovation and funding from European funds should be directed more towards projects that ensure the fulfilment of international commitments, decarbonisation, but also the transition to a greener economy.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 17 April 2018.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on: — A8-0031/2018 by Michaela Šojdrová, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on gender equality in the media sector in the EU (2017/2210 (INI)); and — the oral question Response to the Commission on strengthening the role of women and girls through the digital economy by Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (O-000004/2018 - B8-0010/2018) (2017/3016 (RSP)).

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to present the report on gender equality in the media sector in the European Union. I have worked on this report with my colleagues in the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, for whom I would like to thank. The European Parliament is well aware of the enormous influence of the media on society. It is for this reason that our interest arises in their operation. We are convinced that women's voices should be heard more clearly in all areas, including in the media. I am convinced that the media and society deserve greater influence on the part of women. Women are as good as men. They account for 68% of journalism graduates and 40% of employees in the media sector, but the wage gap between men and women is 17%. Women are much less cited as experts, about 18%. According to the study, only 20% of films are directed by women. The main problem is the representation of women in the media in leadership positions (33%). Such a disproportion has an impact on content, media orientation and organizational culture. Internal culture is often unfavourable to reconciliation between work and private life. It is a competitive environment characterized by stress and inflexible delays. So if we want to support and encourage women, we need to change their working conditions. Union legislation establishes a framework for the operation of audiovisual services and provisions guaranteeing equal employment opportunities and protection against discrimination, harassment and sexual violence. But there are many other aspects that are outside the legislative scope. We consider that the solution goes through a stake rigorous implementation of existing legislation. We are not proposing any new regulations. We call on Member States and stakeholders in the sector to implement positive measures to ensure that women are more equitably represented, and to introduce quotas where possible and necessary. The EU Directive on Women on Boards' shows us a way forward and criteria to be met, and explains how to monitor balance, support and promote training for professionals in the sector, share examples of good practice (e.g., the repertoires of female experts such as Expertalia in Belgium or campaigns against sexist advertising such as the price of sexist pig in the Czech Republic), and introduce measures to reconcile private and professional life. Our report deplores sexism and the abundance of cases of sexual harassment in the media. The European Parliament proposal broadens the scope of this ban to include video-on-demand and video-sharing platforms. Our job, our activity, is to ensure that women are better represented in the media and treated with respect. Once again, I would like to thank all my staff for their work, hoping that it will be followed by effects.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: author. — Madam President! Commissioner! Digitisation, the internet, automation and robotisation are phenomena that have diametrically changed and continue to change both the job market and the daily lives of us all. The way of communication changes, the content of the professions performed, the mobility of many professions increases, access to services, the flexibility of the organization of work. This digital revolution creates new work opportunities for women too, but also new opportunities to reconcile work with family life. It gives hope to reduce the disparity in the treatment of women and men. According to the Commission's projections, the European digital economy requires advanced and very special skills, which at this point are more readily available to men than to women. Here I am referring to the gender-related digital gap, which brings in effect lower female participation in sectors that require digital skills. These differences — sometimes several, sometimes several dozen percentages — materially affect opportunities for women to realize the potential and their participation in high-paying professions and developing sectors of the economy. Only 9% of programmers are female, only 19% of senior managers in ICT and in communications are female, compared with 45% in other service sectors. This small participation of women in the fastest-growing and best-paid professions is a manifestation of sectoral segregation that occurs as a result of persistent gender stereotypes blocking appropriate education and career paths for girls and women gifted in the majors mathematical and natural. This is a great waste of talent that reduces women's quality of life but also brings real losses to the economy. It is estimated that an equal share of men and women in the sector would bring €9bn a year in EU GDP. This and related sectors are characterized by a huge and growing deficit of workers. It could be reduced by inclusion in the market educated in this direction women who, compared with men, are very strongly underrepresented. Digitisation and the internet also facilitate the establishment and flexible operation of micro-enterprises. This is very important especially for women who are mothers — which breeds time-organizational constraints — or for women who live away from urban centers, where the number of potential clients is small. The Internet opens up the market, reduces costs, makes it possible to sell products or services, even with much smaller infrastructure or financial facilities. It also allows remote operation and, through new means of communication, makes it easier to build strengthening professional expert networks. It's all very important. We also know that increasing the number of women in these high-paying, attractive sectors could help to reduce the pay and pension gap, because simply women would earn more. However, these potential benefits that we would experience or experience through the internet will happen provided that we remove barriers that block women's access to both high-tech professions themselves and to a fair path of advancement within these sectors and competitions. Commissioner! In order for the digitalisation benefites listed here to be harnessed to equality policies, we must also be aware of the risks. The internet facilitates hate speech and other forms of cyberbullying, including sexual violence, and working over the internet and mobility provided by new technologies can be a trap of perpetual dispatchability and a multiplied burden on women. Therefore, it is necessary that legal regulations that protect women from harmful gender stereotypes and violence also relate to analogous situations in the digital world, and work over the internet is properly billed with rules guaranteeing time for rest, leave and private life . It is also necessary to act in the sphere of education, so that girls are on equals with boys encouraged to take up science and nature subjects and that their educational paths lead to studies that give qualifications in the most attractive occupations. In this context, we welcome the actions taken by the Commission to promote the inclusion and participation of women in the information society. At the same time, we urge the Commission to prioritise the employment of women in ICT, the fight against gender stereotypes and the promotion of gender equality at all stages of education, including continuing education. I would also like to ask the Commissioner what actions are being taken by the Commission to resolve the issues presented here.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteurs, Ms Šojdrová and Ms Kozłowska-Rajewicz, as well as all the shadow rapporteurs for the excellent work with their reports. The report and the resolution we are discussing today are very relevant and very timely. Allow me also to excuse my colleague, Commissioner Maria Gabriel, who is not able to be here today but who made sure to follow your works and whose commitment towards promoting women’s participation and representation in the digital, media and audiovisual sectors is very strong. Mobilising women and encouraging them to work in the digital field and to specialise in ICT is a needed step. Women make up less than one in five ICT graduates in the EU and only 17% of the almost eight million people working in ICT are women. We need to boost the involvement of girls and women in digital technologies. That is why the Commission started a reflection process on how to take a more strategic approach on women in the digital field as part of the Commission digital education action plan and the new skills agenda. The strategy proposes three ways to attract girls and women to take up science, technology, engineering and mathematics studies and go into ICT-related areas. First, it aims at challenging the gender stereotypes and bias towards women that persist in society and in the digital economy as well. We need to highlight role-models and positive images of women in ICT. When it comes to the participation of women in media organisations or film-making, we can only agree with your report. Significant inequalities, including under-representation and career barriers remain entrenched in the media sector. This is something that the European Commission is attentive to through media pluralism monitoring, which shows that in the EU there are only a few women on public service media boards. These findings are in line with other data which show that, despite over-representation of women among graduates in journalism and information, and despite a high number of women working in the media sector in Europe, women remain under-represented in management positions in media. Only one third of the board members of public broadcasters across the EU are women and, like in other areas, women are heavily under-represented in top-level positions, accounting only for 22% of board presidents. A similar picture arises when we look at film-making. Only one in five films is directed by a woman, and the reason is not that there are no women directors. The proportion of female directors graduating from film schools and entering the film industry is 44%. That is why the Commission wants action in the field too. Working through the media programme on gender for 2018, we shall track gender equality in the projects we are going to fund. The second area of the strategy focuses on skills and education. We need to make digital skills training accessible and attractive for women. In this area, the Commission has, for example, launched the digital skills and jobs coalition which carried out a special call for concrete commitments by private companies and public institutions. In 2017, the Commission also awarded the European digital skills award, presented to projects that encourage girls and women to take up digital skills and careers. Moreover, the Commission supports EU Code Week, which had 1.2 million participants last year, of which 46% were girls or women. The third area of the strategy focuses on promoting digital entrepreneurship for women and lowering access barriers. The Commission has funded web hubs, the first European community that connects business ecosystems and provides them with mentoring tools to support women entrepreneurs in the digital sector. Every year, the EU prize for women innovators recognises outstanding women entrepreneurs and inspires others to follow in their footsteps. The Commission is acting on several fronts in the effort to boost gender equality and empowerment. You know of the initiatives launched in the past years: the gender pay gap action plan or the EU social pillar, with its work-life balance agenda. At the same time, I will try again over this year to unblock the situation in the Council as regards the women on boards directive. Another key priority is to end violence against women and girls. This is a particular challenge related to digitalisation – online violence and harassment against girls and women. We are working on several strands to prevent violence, protect and support victims. I am pushing for the swift accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention, which will provide a clear framework for our actions in this area. Overall, the European Commission is very pleased that the European Parliament shares our vision about the place of women in media organisations as well as having in media a more diversified and realistic picture of the skills and potential of men and women in society.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Madam President, I welcome this report and I thank the rapporteur for her work and for incorporating the employment opinion, of which I was rapporteur.  Women make up 68% of media and journalism graduates, yet less than 16% of the high—level strategic positions are occupied by women. This inevitably leads to a power imbalance, and this imbalance is exacerbated by the precarious nature of media work, leaving women more vulnerable to sexual harassment in the workplace. A recent international report found that 64.8% of female media workers have experienced intimidation or abuse, and almost 32% of that abuse was perpetrated by a male boss or co—worker. Media organisations need robust internal procedures to assist victims to speak out. To fundamentally reform the media sector, public and private media need to mainstream gender equality in all their content and avoid gender stereotypes and the sexual objectification of women. Pay and pension gaps must be closed and media companies must implement pay transparency. It is also critical to note that women of different ethnicity, religion and sexual orientation and those with a disability face additional barriers to equality that must be addressed.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, women suffer discrimination and inequality in all areas of life and, of course, also in the digital and media fields. That is why I welcome these two reports, in which we refer to the need to promote policies that improve the situation of equality in these two key areas. And I welcome the Commissioner's speech in which she raised the importance of unlocking the women's directive on boards of directors, which is crucial. On March 8, in Spain, the women's faces disappeared from television stations. Women's voice was not heard on radio stations; women's lyrics did not appear in newspaper articles. Women journalists helped to make the strike and women's demonstrations a success in Spain. We call the media the “fourth power”; because that power also has to be shared, we also have to break the glass ceilings in the media areas. We need to be able to move forward in fairer, more egalitarian societies, and the media play a fundamental role in this regard. Of course, women should be the main protagonists.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! Digital transformation has fundamentally changed the way people reach information, how they communicate, study, work. The information society carries great opportunities when it comes to creating prosperity and access to knowledge. Therefore, we should use the potential that lies in this to empower women economically and socially. The second point we are discussing today is gender equality in the media sector. Although more women than men study journalism and information, the proportion of women employed in the sector has steadily remained at the 40% limit. Women continue to face the glass ceiling problem in the media. On this occasion, it is also worth noting the problem of cyberbullying experienced by women and girls. I believe the media must immediately introduce the principle of equal pay for the same work. It's also time to end up sexualizing the image of a woman and a girl.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Commissioner, the essence of Mrs Shoidrova's report is the state of gender equality in the media itself. Focusing on the problems in them is an approach that allows concrete and public naming them in a sphere unknown and elitist to many. I believe that the proposal in the report on guidelines for equal representation of women and men in decision-making in media organisations would have a positive effect. But there is a need for more action to support gender equality in all areas. The strategy for women in digital technology presented on 8 March by Commissioner Mariya Gabriel, on which I congratulate her, is also in this idea. I agree with the Commissioner that the future of Europe lies in digitisation and that combating stereotypes, promoting digital skills and education will help against gender division in another area.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Madam President, the media has a fundamental role: they can perpetuate gender stereotypes or they can be an ally in favour of equality. Of course, the European Parliament must push the second path as the United Nations which recently adopted a declaration on gender equality in the media because today a majority of audiovisual content (and especially advertising) disseminate feminine and male ideals harmful to society that are neither egalitarian or healthy; content that perpetuate stereotypes about women and LGBTI people and often entail public health problems, such as the huge numbers of adolescents who today suffer from anorexia and bulimia. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, I call on you to support our amendment in favour of a European directive to end sexism in advertising. Economic reasons cannot remain an excuse to maintain discrimination in the media.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Ladies and gentlemen, only 17% of the journalistic workforce in newspapers are women. On television, nine out of ten interviews are conducted by men. Statistically, in cinema and TV films from Germany, two male protagonists have a woman in a leading role. In information broadcasts, men predominate as speakers with 72% ahead of women and 79% in expert panels. The moderation of quiz and reality shows is a male domain at 80%. Do you know how many of the German EU correspondents in private media in Brussels are women? There are 40 correspondents and only 10 correspondents. So it's high time to really do something about women's rights, and not just waste it. After all, the responsible persons in editorial offices and film studios are affected by this imbalance, but do not want to change anything. We must respond with clear political demands. A mandatory quota of women in media and journalism must now be enforced.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, this report on gender equality in the media sector is a new blow in the water. You are right to point out that harassment and pornography on social networks pose a danger to women and girls. You are right to say that maternity is synonymous with discrimination in hiring, and you are also right to say that the principle of equal pay for equal work is still a fantasy today. But the sequel is much more confusing. Your approach to the media world seems to be based only on numbers. These statistics on women working in the media would allow you to say that they are discriminated against. Either! As usual, your only solution then seems to be quotas. Let me tell you one thing: quotas don't work. It is not because women make up 50% of employees in an area that they will not be equal to men. Equality is neither decreed nor measured by statistics. You have another solution: to change mindsets through the media. This is where the text becomes very disturbing for us. In your opinion, the media would not convey a good view of the world but gender stereotypes that would be insulting women. One can easily guess the professions or roles that this term “stereotype” hides: nurse, secretary, housekeeper or even worse, mother of a family. To read to you, none of these roles should be associated with women in media content — as if disreputing them, as if it was the cause of their misfortune. Your blind and driven willingness by some communitarian lobbies to absolutely want to make girls boys, and vice versa, becomes ridiculous. You finally forget the paramount point that should prevail over everything else: freedom of choice. In this area of media, such as in all other areas of society, we as members of parliament must bear one thing in mind: that of giving each individual the opportunity to freely choose the professional and personal path that they wish to follow. Quotas, re-education of consciences, tearful speeches about the fact that only 40% of women would work in the media, which sound like incantations, I prefer complementarity between men and women, I prefer freedom of choice, I prefer equal rights.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: — This report and this discussion is some kind of nightmare misunderstanding. What you are saying here and what you are writing in the report is outrageous sexism. You forge as a criterion for hiring gender, not competence. Stop looking into strangers because it's not worthy of a Member of the European Parliament. It's not your business whether a woman or a man works in a particular position, and who someone wants to hire in their own enterprise. Freedom, including economic freedom, is not about doing what you think is right, it is about coming to terms with the fact that people sometimes do things you don't think are right and over which you may deplore, but that is not your business. If you have a better idea of hiring policies, set up your own companies, hire employees in them according to any criteria, and prove that it works in practice. If this is the right postulate, then ahead of the market this archaic competition, which applies other, improper hiring criteria according to you. Whereas, unless you bear the cost of doing this business by others, do not interfere, because they are at their own expense, at their own risk who they want. If your ideas and your hiring policy are going to make them a loss, then you're not going to go to business for that reason, so don't interfere with it. No one's interested in whether you think women in the media should be more or less because it's just your arbitrary, like an unsupported belief.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, the media are indeed a fundamental element of democracy, respect for human dignity and equality. No one here has said that the media sharpened inequality. What we say is that the media can be key partners in the fight against discrimination, and this would be the first point for reflection. This report, despite all the work done and all the positive measures included in it, I believe that we can do even more, will be stronger and more balanced with the additional amendments that we are proposing, namely the need for greater regulation both at European and Member State level, with the possibility of penalties and the creation of an ombudsman for gender issues in the media, in the dissemination of the pay gap and the introduction of binding measures to promote equal pay for equal work, refusal of any content that promotes discrimination or violence on the basis of gender, including the strong sexism that is sometimes transmitted through advertising. I therefore ask all Members to support our amendments tomorrow at the time of the vote.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Madam President! I am in favour of supporting women in areas where they are disadvantaged. We must be careful, however, that, on the sum of equality of opportunity, we do not make equality of results, because that is the wrong way. That's why I'm against rigid quotas. I do not want 50% of any positions to go to women and 50% to men. Instead, I want us to always take the best 100% and put them in appropriate positions. That must be our goal. We should also not forget in such discussions that we must focus not only on career development. We should realise that performance is also provided in families, and we must ensure that the performance in families is also appreciated accordingly and that we do not have one against each other by work on the one hand and family on the other, but that there is good interlocking. That is why for equal opportunities — yes — but not for equality.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the equal pay scandal at the BBC is yet another reminder that no sector is immune to gender inequalities. Following Carrie Gracie’s public denouncement, the extent of the pay differences between men and women in media and entertainment in the UK has been truly exposed. But we know this is true everywhere in Europe and in all sectors. The creative and cultural sector, which is historically seen as female—friendly and where women outnumber men across the sector as a whole, is a sector guilty of gender-based discrimination. However, pay gap is not the only issue. In a world of images and narratives, positive representation of women is key to combating prejudice and encourage necessary mind shifts. As a cultural activist and as a feminist, I see a link between the way women are represented in our society and consequential gender-based violence. When women are absent from the public sphere, they are disempowered, objectified and subject to violence. When women are represented according to patriarchal prejudices and stereotypes, a culture of bullying and violence prevails. That’s why we need women in decision-making positions in the media sector, as in all sectors.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Dear Chairman, Madam Commissioner, according to available data, women in the media are still not equally represented, media exposed, paid, nor are they asked for expert opinion in relation to their male counterparts. Research shows that there is only 4% of coverage in the European Union with news coverage showing men and women in equal positions. Showing women and girls takes up just 24% of media space, while men and boys are shown in 76% of media screenings. Precisely for the above reasons, the report of this type carries a special weight. However, at the same time, I would warn that a report such as this must be approached conscientiously and without imposing socially conditioned ideologies on Member States, which are more difficult for individual amendments, and I call for those amendments to be rejected. They diminish the importance of the topic and draw attention to something that is not the competence of the European Union. Empowering women and girls in society in general, including media representation and inclusion, is a key task of the European Union that can be achieved without violating the powers and competences of the European Union.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner. Digitisation, which has profoundly transformed the media sector, is an opportunity for women to make their voices heard and increase participation in the labour market, promoting the female entrepreneurship. However, even in this area, there remains a significant gap that we could call “digital” between men and women. In addition, as evidenced by a study conducted by Amnesty International, there has been a sharp increase on social media of sexist representation and discrimination, of harassment and gender-based violence online, and of cyberbullying against women. It is therefore essential that the Commission and the Member States are committed to promoting digital literacy aimed at women and, above all, younger girls, in order to provide them with skills Basic and advanced computing, which can be spent in the labour market. But it is also essential that we undertake to adopt awareness campaigns and any other appropriate measures to prevent discrimination, violence and harassment, in order to ensure that women have safer use Internet in the context of more general media education, attentive to gender specificity.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, it is a fact that the voice of women is not heard in the media. Discussion and evidence have shown that there are a limited number of women in managerial positions in the media. The pay they receive is lower than that of men, and certainly women do not play the role they should play in the media, which affects, as we have heard, both the content and the processes themselves in the media. However, we must refer to the central issues relating to the media, which are the control of them by the oligarchs, the lack of pluralism and the fake news. Especially now, a year before the European elections, we must ensure that there is pluralism and equal opportunities are given to all political groups and to all political parties to hear their views during the European elections. In this way we will contribute to pluralism and, of course, we support all measures in favour of women in the media sector.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President, thank you Commissioner for all your work and efforts. The combination of stereotypes and prejudices linked to traditional role sharing makes women less interested in vocational and higher education linked to new technologies. That is why I support the strategic approach put forward by the Commissioner. This sector offers high employability, well-paid jobs and high opportunities for entrepreneurship. However, it does not sufficiently capture the attention of women, who are underrepresented in it. This situation has an impact on products, services and ICT content and generates a vicious circle. Becoming a virtuoso requires more research to know what keeps women away from these activities; in addition, specific actions from childhood to awaken technical vocations in women and networks, products and services that bring the advantages of ICT closer to the female public. Finally, indicators that measure what we are doing so that women take advantage, like men, one of the main jobs and knowledge quarries of the coming decades.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Madam President! Kim Wall from Sweden, Daphne Caruana Galizia from Malta: two brave investigative journalists who sought the truth and had to pay with their lives. The threat and hatred of women in the media sector is an absolutely crucial issue that is about the quality of our democracy. The sexual harassment and sexist comments in a hard-line industry like the media have always existed, but intensified in recent years due to online presence. The European Parliament is united in this call that we must fight these phenomena in order to protect our democracy and create the conditions for everyone to influence the influential media sector, which affects people's everyday lives. Another important issue is the work environment and gender equality. There has to be the opportunity to have family as a journalist. The hardening working conditions strike against human health and against gender equality and become an obstacle, mainly for women in the industry who hit the glass ceiling many times. And men lose the opportunity to be close to their children in a natural way. Finally, we need to stop selling things using women's bodies. Sell thing with girl, it's so out. We can much better.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: — Madam President, the report omits aspects of the organisation of the media which are not detached from the widespread inequalities perpetuating in the sector and the violence against women which it promotes. It omits that the concentration of the media, the predominance of the private sector over the public sector, the increasing commodification of communication and information inevitably impact on content and professionals in the sector, conditioning the ideological matrix of those who direct them. A sector that mediatically promotes discrimination against women and promotes their transformation into an object could not promote best practices among its workers. Combating inequalities between men and women requires counteracting practices in the sector that impose intense and deregulated workloads, functional multivalence, job precariousness, low wages and indiscriminate redundancies. This fight, like other sectors, requires the reversal of right-wing policies that feed on exploitation and inequalities in order to maximise profits, policies that the European Union has also promoted.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: — Sinjura President, nathe seb li huwa rilevanti li din id-diskussjon tal-lejla qiegЂda ssir sitt xhur preiż wara l-assassinju tal-ornalista investigattiva Daphne Caruana Galizia f'Malta. IR-rapport korrettament jirreferi grünall-urnalisti investigattivi nisa u jguttaid kif dawn, the drabi huma soo o clocketet gatmosal aktar vjolenza u gutta al aktar atttattack sistematiköi. Fil-każ ta' Daphne, anke qabel l-assassinju tagha, kellek esponenti tal-gvern li jirreferu galiha bЂala saara, kellek l-atck kontra tagha, anke meta kien hemm is-sekwestru tal-flus tagЂ‹u, u meta kien hemm anke azzjonianke jiet biex jippruvaw imaqdru dak li hija kienet qiegda tagmel, anke b'kummenti preto iżament immirati lejha brata ala mara. Hawnhekk qegto din nitkellmu kontra l-attakk kontra sterjotipi. Żgur [li] hija kienet forza kontra dan gЂax kienet l-aqwa to the urnalista investigattiva, u llum ana kburin li l-kitba tagЂha qiegЂda tkompli tkun investigata minn konsorzju ta' 45 urnalist minn 18-il dar differenti tal-midja.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Honourable Chairman, women and men must have the same opportunities. Any discrimination in the market must go away and I will always wholeheartedly support any measures and initiatives that lead in that direction. But this Report goes in the opposite direction and does not call for equal opportunities, but equal outcomes that should no longer be in the domain of the individual's free choice, but would be decided on by social engineers. Unfortunately, this impact on individual freedoms is represented by the liberation of women, and it is actually about their detraction. Sometimes feminists used to say that a woman was free with her body to do what she wanted. Today they want to terminate the right to choose those women who, in their view, are objectified, even if in doing so directly harm their interests and go openly against their free will. This report is just on that trail, and that's why I can't support it. We need to create a safe economic environment for women, but they themselves have to make their own career decision, without the interference of social engineers.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Madam President, if women journalists stop, for journalism, as happened on 8 March in the feminist strike. This debate is very important: 37% women presenters or commentators, 30% women in media channels, 25% women on boards, 18% female commentators or media experts, these are the general data on inequality. But they are not only the only problems: the wage gap is 17% and temporary and precarious work is another of the terrible realities, the result of a patriarchal conception in which spaces are totally masculinized. And the difficulties for women journalists and communicators do not end here. Sexual and labour harassment is on the agenda. The same goes for paternalism inside and outside the newsrooms and, in this problem, sexist informative treatments abound. We political men and women, who are capable of changing reality, must prevent inequality, also prohibit advertisements of sexual contacts, and even apply social clauses for the media that promote them.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I think that the discussion has shown that we share the same vision and have a very significant role to play. Let me add a few comments based on the discussion, to which I have listened very carefully. On digitalisation: we have a tendency to say that digitalisation is a great opportunity for society, and it must be an opportunity for women as well. This is a positive vision. I will add a negative view: if we do not support women and girls to get into the digital sphere as professionals, as experts, we will undertake a very serious risk because digitalisation has the potential to increase the gaps in society, and we have to actively work against this. That is why the Commission, as I described at the beginning, is undertaking a lot of steps and is funding a lot of projects to boost the potential of women and to encourage young girls to study the relevant subjects. This is the problem, in practice: I have many debates with the captains of the IT industry because, thanks to other parts of my portfolio, I am in very frequent contact with the managers of big IT companies, and I urge them to give more chances – at least equal opportunities – for women to get to higher positions and to get better jobs. They keep convincing me that women are not in the pipeline, but I always say that they do not have to be technicians or programmers or specialists for IT, for the technologies – they can be marketing experts; they can be lawyers employed in the IT sector. I think this is also a way to get women into this very promising and emerging sector and also, among other things, to get to higher positions and to the better paid jobs in order to decrease the pay gap, because I think we are working on several different things here. On media: we are witnessing a very worrying trend, because online hate speech and violence online is now more and more discouraging women journalists from doing their jobs. We have statistical figures that show that women are much higher victims and targets of online violence than men. Simply, the attackers recognise women as the weaker part of society, and that is why they are attacked more frequently. I have had many debates with the IT industry: we are urging the IT companies to delete hate speech against many groups of our society, including women. I am urging law enforcement authorities in all the Member States to react and to find the perpetrators, to find the attackers and to punish them, because online violence is a huge problem for the whole of society and is already very negatively affecting the freedom of work of journalists – especially women. We have to be better in this, because this is a very serious problem. Lastly, I want to explain my approach to the quota, which has been discussed here as well. My approach is that women must be guaranteed fair competition. I said many times that positive discrimination for me is not the option, but we have to ensure that there will be fair competition; if the candidates are equally qualified, if they have similar experience, I don’t see any reason why men should always get priority. There should be fair competition: I know I am repeating it for the third time, but if we manage this it will not only be good for women; it will be good for society, because our labour market, our IT sector, our other promising sectors need more talents and we need to use the potential of women for the good of the whole society. Thank you very much for this debate. Again, I want to thank the rapporteurs for attracting our attention to these very important topics, and I am ready to cooperate with Parliament in the future because we have to join forces. We have to encourage the Member States, but also the universities, the politicians on all levels and the opinion leaders, because I think that to achieve what we want to achieve in the field of gender equality we need also the change the mindset of our society, and there is much more work to be done.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Madam President, I would like to thank all those who participated in the discussion for their opinions but also for their criticism. Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your work and for your efforts in reconciling family and working life. Women and men are complementary. Therefore, if we are to improve the quality of the media, we need to strengthen the participation of women by taking advantage of their presence and potential in the media. In my view, the Member States and the European Union have a common responsibility: we must develop opportunities and improve conditions so that women can exercise their freedom of choice. This is our task. Our report deals with this freedom of choice and opportunities. Therefore, I thank all those who contributed to this report.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I have received a motion for a resolution in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure. The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - This European Parliament report addresses the issue of equality between men and women in the EU media. Media is the fourth power, it has a great influence on politics and society. We must therefore make great efforts to ensure that it works properly and in a balanced manner, which inevitably involves ensuring gender balance. Given that both public and private media must serve society as a whole, its structure and activities should reflect the fact that women account for half of society. This report focuses on the situation of women working as reporters and commentators in the media, but also draws attention to the lack of women in decision-making positions. The latter situation is of particular concern: only 30 to 40% of women hold leadership positions in the media sector, although most graduates of media studies are women. Such imbalances can not only harm media content and theme choices, but also contribute to an increase in the overall wage and pension gap between women and men. Women working as reporters and moderators also face great difficulties: they are under enormous pressure to meet high standards of attractiveness for viewers, and they are rarely instructed to work on important political or economic issues. The situation of women is often complicated by the increased need to reconcile family (maternity) and professional duties. We would like to offer as much support as possible in this area.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I would like to thank the rapporteur for this motion for a resolution and talking about this important topic. Indeed, the participation of women and girls in the digital sector is still very low. Whether we talk about learning digital skills or working in the ICT sector, the situation is desperate now. We already lack IT professionals in Europe and the number can only increase. This is where the increased participation of women in the IT sector could make a real difference. We want to lead in innovation but we can’t do it without enough IT professionals. In order to encourage women to increase their interest in the IT sector we should not only try to change gender stereotypes about the sector, encourage mentorship programmes within companies, but also start more serious changes. We have to change our education systems. IT classes have to be mandatory starting from the first grade in the EU. That’s how girls would be able to engage more in digital sector and to understand that they have a lot of potential, and that it is an interesting field not only for boys.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: in writing. — (NL) Mr President, when I open my newspaper or turn on television, I see and read mainly about men. In the media, only 24% of the population appears to be women. And if women already appear in the media, they are usually asked for a “personal story” and rarely for their expertise (17%). These harrowing figures indicate that women, including in the media, have not yet achieved the same status as men. The under-representation of women in the media contributes to the idea that they would occupy a less prominent position in society. While it is precisely the media sector that should play a major role in changing gender stereotypes. Mr President, if we really want to achieve equality between men and women — equality in terms of wages, pensions and rights including — women must be represented everywhere. The media has a crucial example role in this, as it affects everyone's imaging. There is so much female talent that is currently not fully exploited. Progress has been made in recent decades, but we are still facing a pay gap in the workplace and gender inequality in the media. That is why I say: let us not bury the hatchet as long as persistent remains of the past are still visible.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. — Digitisation has leaps and bounds altered the availability and distribution of information, as well as created opportunities for learning, working and participating in public and political discussions. At the same time, women use less internet than men, and only around 16% of the nearly eight million people working in the ICT sector in Europe are women. Improving digital skills will provide a great opportunity to improve work-life balance, increase access to education and training, facilitate labour market involvement in rural and remote areas, and create entrepreneurial opportunities. It is important to use more targeted Digital Agenda and the Digital Single Market Strategy to eliminate gender inequality in the ICT sector. In addition, it is important to start adding age-appropriate ICT learning to the curriculum as early as possible and to direct girls to learn more real subjects.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. — Equality between men and women is a fundamental principle of the European Union enshrined in treaties on the functioning of the EU. This principle states that, in all its activities, the Union seeks to abolish inequality and promote equality between men and women. This principle also applies to mass media. The Fourth World Conference on Women recognized that the relationship between women and the media is important for achieving gender equality, and set out, among other things, two strategic objectives, which are: increasing the participation of women in the expression of opinion, in decision-making processes, and also providing them with greater opportunities in this regard through media and new communication technologies and promoting sustainable and non-stereotypical portrayal of women in the media. Member States are therefore urged to focus together with the equality authorities on the implementation of existing gender equality legislation, and to encourage regulatory authorities to pay attention to women's presence and improve their position, as also on stereotype-free media content. It is also an important aspect to encourage Member States to carry out regular checks on these areas and, if necessary, develop legislative provisions on stereotype-free media content. In addition, further research is encouraged on the presence of women in senior positions in the media.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Enrique Guerrero Salom, on behalf of the Committee on Development, the Development Cooperation Instrument, the Humanitarian Aid Instrument and the Implementation of the European Development Fund (2017/2258 (INI)) (A8-0118/2018).

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, the European Union has been and must continue to be a global actor aimed at peace, progress and solidarity. But peace cannot thrive in the midst of poverty, injustice and insecurity. Unequal development—lack of opportunities—fuels conflict, imbalances regions and causes disorderly population movements. Climate change jeopardizes the very future of humanity and multiplies the frequency and intensity of many natural disasters. The summits in Sendai, Addis Ababa, New York, Paris and Istanbul have stressed that we all live in one world, on a common planet, and that we will only improve and preserve it if we assume a shared responsibility to improve it among all and for all. This report calls for the European Union to continue to lead this joint responsibility. The Lisbon Treaty has established that poverty reduction and eradication are the main objectives of the Union's development cooperation policy; a policy aimed at promoting fundamental values such as respect for human rights, democracy, peace, solidarity and support for public goods global. In fact, the European Union and its Member States are the main donors in the world. They are so because of the financial weight of their contribution, also because of their experience and leadership in the negotiations on the main international instruments. Of the various financial instruments of the Union's external action, three of them are the responsibility of the Committee on Development to review them. The purpose of this report is to contribute to this review, initiated by the Commission, of the European Development Fund, the Development Cooperation Instrument and the Humanitarian Aid Instrument. Part of the analysis of its implementation from January 2014 to June 2017 and — while lacking important information, something that needs to be improved in the face of future — considers the implementation of these instruments positively, but in turn evaluates for the future and sets out some recommendations until the end of their validity in 2020 and for the next multiannual financial framework. The assessment was based on several of the Commission's reports, a specific report prepared by the European Parliament's Studies Service (specifically on humanitarian aid) and some other reports made by non-governmental organisations and civil society actors. The challenges that the European Union has faced in recent years have not seriously undermined the effort of its actions, but above all they must not undermine them in the future, even with the foreseeable reducing impact of Brexit, because there are other global actors who are willing to abandon their global responsibilities, something that must at some point assume the European Union to replace them. That is going to be very necessary from the point of view of financial resources. We therefore call for a clear and committed timetable to achieve 0.7 per cent of GDP. I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their contribution to this report because it is certainly not a contribution of correcting certain points of the report, but of reincorporating whole paragraphs, different approaches, which have enriched that continent. The report underlines the need for at least 20 per cent of the Development Cooperation Instrument to continue to provide basic social services and public goods. It advocates future budgeting of the European Development Fund; advocates greater participation by civil society and local actors; calls for increased transparency, accountability and parliamentary scrutiny; and calls for a revision of the next multiannual financial framework. We are twelve years away from meeting the sustainable development goals: it seems like a long period but it is on the back of the corner, and the effort has to be increased.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Parliament, in particular, the Chair of the Development Committee (DEVE), Linda McAvan, and the rapporteur Enrique Guerrero Salom for the excellent collaboration over the past months concerning the mid-term review of the external financing instruments. I very much welcome this report as a valuable contribution to the Commission’s preparatory work on the future external financing instruments. I fully share your conviction that we have to remain ambitious in the financing of EU external action after 2020. Heading four has been stretched to the limits during this Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). We have been facing unprecedented levels of crisis world-wide, from conflicts to natural and climate-related disasters, health epidemics, insecurity and massive displacement and migration. As the report rightly points out, we need to work harder to deliver on the international commitment of the European Union and its Member States to devote 0.7% of gross national income to official development assistance (ODA) by 2030. The ODA figures published a few days ago show that our collective, aggregate ODA has gone down. Even if we are still the world’s largest donor, we cannot accept such a downward trend. I agree that, overall, the current set of instruments has proven useful and strategically relevant, and enabled the European Union to adapt to evolving situations and needs in strategic sectors and regions. However, we need to have the courage to re-examine the next generation of external instruments. Our guiding policy framework with the 2030 Agenda, the Global Strategy, the European Neighbourhood Policy and the European consensus on development as well as the global challenges to which they are responding are highly complex and intertwined. The current multitude of programmes does not facilitate the necessary multi-dimensional approach to poverty eradication and sustainable development. I am therefore happy that the report calls for greater coherence and simplification. Indeed, we need to get rid of artificial boundaries within our current instruments to ensure the right synergies between different policies for different countries and regions. We must avoid working in silos, while preserving the focus on poverty eradication and on promoting European values. Keeping a comprehensive approach towards our partners is the best way to serve our mutual interests. By streamlining existing instruments, development cooperation can take a truly integrated and innovative approach, both from a geographical and thematic point of view. The policy-driven nature of financing instruments will also be reinforced. A streamlined architecture can facilitate our interinstitutional dialogue as well, by truly looking at the bigger picture, rather than specific envelopes. Having differentiated policies such as neighbourhood or development policy does not require having separate instruments. In this logical coherence, it should also make sense to integrate the European Development Fund into the EU budget. But I concur with the report that this should be done only if certain preconditions are met: the volume of funds, in particular for Africa, should not decrease and important elements of flexibility, such as significant reserves and multiannuality should be preserved. On humanitarian aid, I also agree with the report’s key findings. Humanitarian assistance should remain self-standing, taking account of the specific nature and principles of humanitarian assistance. We have been able to provide humanitarian aid rapidly and flexibly in most acute crises. This was possible, not least because of the principles of humanity, impartiality, neutrality and independence. As the recent comprehensive evaluation shows, our instrument is fit for purpose. It is also important that EU humanitarian aid continues to have adequate access to an emergency reserve to deal with unforeseen needs. We are committed to making sure that, whenever possible, humanitarian aid works hand in hand with longer-term instruments as part of the nexus approach in building resilience.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Madam President, development policy instruments are of the utmost importance for showing the EU’s commitment to global justice and for the provision of public global goods. Still, development aid needs long—term programing and predictability. The insufficient amount of EU resources devoted to external action and the need to react within the margins to unforeseen humanitarian emergencies are usually detrimental to meeting development aid goals in a more efficient way.  Furthermore, development money should only be used for development—related purposes, and not for other purposes such as covering internal refugee costs, externalising migration policies outside the EU’s border or paying the cost of returns and readmissions to countries of origin.  Last, but not least, the fight against climate change should play a more important role in development cooperation, and Paris commitments should be fully reflected in instruments and programmes.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, there are a few things that I want to say about this report and I’ll have to be brief. I’ll start with thanking the rapporteur, Mr Enrique Guerrero, for his inclusive approach and for having been willing to take on board suggestions and particular preoccupations of colleagues from other political denominations. That’s always appreciated, and I believe we have come up with a good report. On the topics: one, we need more coherence, Commissioner, you know that that is something that our external partners are demanding of us, that is something that external partners would wish for. We are confusing people with the diversity of the instruments that we have, and setting up another new instrument every year does not really help. More coherence is certainly going to be needed. We are not doing enough, I believe, on micro assistance. We have seen again and again and again on parliamentary missions lately and in the bigger picture that where true development could start, where people could take charge of their own destinies, there is no one to support them with EUR 500 or EUR 1000 in order to be able to do that. We have no instruments that foster that. It would fall well within the remit of the future development bank, as the report by Enrique states, and such a development bank would have to have recourse to innovative financial instruments. Finally, budget support will need to remain on the agenda and with greater funding than it has now. Because the patronising attitude that we’ve had in the past has made us look second or third in line in terms of preference of many recipient states, and that effects the notional validity of the partnership was well. More budget support in the future will be unescapable.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to echo firstly my congratulations to Mr Enrique Guerrero for his excellent report.  Commissioner, you spoke mainly about the future instruments and I want to limit my brief comments to the future because we just had a meeting of the coordinators of our committee and we talked about the ideas that are floating around at the moment on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and the new programmes. The key messages that were coming out are, one, that the MFF should deliver on the SDGs, that there should be no reduction in the amount of funding available – despite Brexit – and, if the European Development Fund (EDF) goes into the budget and the EDF and the Development Cooperation Instrument (DCI) are merged, that should not be an excuse to cut the overall amount.  The focus must be kept on poverty reduction, as set out in the Treaties and money not put into short-term priorities like migration because poverty eradication requires long term predictable funding.  You said humanitarian aid should remain outside of any new instrument, and I think we welcome that very much. As Enrique Guerrero said, there should be a clear strategy to reach the 0.7% aid.  There are lots of questions though that our colleagues have and I’m sure we’ll have time in the next few months to address those, particularly about how the reserve will work –you are talking about a huge reserve. How will Parliament’s budgetary control be exercised? Will we have continued new off-budget instruments like the trust funds? With issues like the private sector getting more involved, have you got the expertise inside the Commission to make sure the kind of mistakes that some countries have gotten into with the private sector are not repeated in the European Commission?

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Guerrero Salom on his initiative in drafting this report, as well as all those involved. The report shall indicate ways of evaluating and increasing the effectiveness of the implementation of the financial instruments for development cooperation, humanitarian aid and the European Development Fund in relation to the European Union's development and humanitarian aid policies; with the obvious aim of sustainable development and poverty eradication. The driving force behind this is coherent actions, both in the European Union's internal and foreign policy. In order for the European Union to remain a pioneer and effective force in financing development cooperation and humanitarian aid, the new multiannual financial framework beyond 2020 should provide for financial contributions from the Member States to meet the global challenges, whether man-made or natural disasters, always with full respect for human rights, the dignity of poor people, peace and democracy. The integration of the European Development Fund into the new Multiannual Financial Framework constitutes a measure of coherence for the development and other policies of the European Union, but also a mechanism for scrutiny by the European Parliament of the transparency and effectiveness of development assistance.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, I would first of all like to congratulate my colleague Enrique Guerrero on this report, although we show moderate optimism about this report which we will be voting tomorrow. Optimism, because Parliament reaffirms that development aid serves to eradicate poverty in a context of sustainable development and nothing else; moderate, because we find it unacceptable that national interests in migration management end up determining the European development agenda. We also denounce the fraudulent use of these items in trust funds and very much regret the lack of coherence between development and trade policies, because we do not stop prioritizing business profit over sustainable development goals. The Union's cooperation policy and its instruments should follow comprehensively the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the Paris Agreement on Climate Change and the other international agreements on the subject. Our optimism, as I said, is moderate because we know that, although this Parliament's position is firm and clear, the ball is on the roof of the States. From here, we call for the voice of the European citizenship represented here to be respected, always much more supportive and fair than its rulers, and which has been supporting 0.7% of GDP for development aid for years, for example.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, EDF budgeting is not necessarily a good thing for greater transparency and democracy. I remain convinced that development needs the States, our States and the ACP States, and that it is primarily through the association of parliaments — national parliaments, the European Parliament — upstream and downstream of the decision that we will have more transparent processes. With regard to trust funds, I share the criticism. I do believe that these trust funds should be avoided as a way of supporting NGOs, committees or development agencies, without States being re-involved. However, that is the case. This was shown for the Bêkou fund. It is not even possible to clearly involve the State and make it an instrument of support for the development of States. Moreover, I remain convinced that if we are to develop Africa, we need, in addition to the States and globalised aid, sectoral aid which accompanies developments in which we are fully associated with the funds and in which there is codecision and co-management, which also implies monitoring expenditure. Finally, with regard to security and the fight against immigration, I show the importance of these funds. Security and development funds need to be put in place, particularly in the countries of the Sahel or the Great Lakes region. These funds must always combine this approach. This must be done by States and with States; it cannot be done with NGOs or development agencies.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Madam President! I will also join my congratulations to my colleague Guerrero for preparing this report. It provides a careful review of the use of EU foreign policy tools that contribute to reducing poverty of course and reducing the causes of instability in partner countries. The report also contains a number of proposals and recommendations for the multiannual financial framework beyond 2020. A positive assessment of the conformity of the existing implementation of these instruments with the Sustainable Development Goals and the new European Development Consensus is an important element of report. Unfortunately, the number of crises and natural disasters is globally increasing, causing these instruments to be saddled with significant financial pressures and new ad hoc mechanisms such as trusts lack transparency. External financing instruments beyond 2020 should continue to allow multiannual geographical and thematic programmes to be combined in order to enable development activities on a different scale. It is also of great importance in this context to promote regional cooperation and integration of partner countries. It is equally important to ensure comprehensive support for countries affected by poverty and instability through mutually complementary humanitarian and development efforts, while maintaining separate development aid instruments and humanitarian assistance beyond 2020.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: — Madam President, as the rapporteur said in his introductory remarks, the crises that we are unable to contain where they arise necessarily have a very significant impact on our territory sooner or later. We therefore have every reason to focus on the global situation and developments, especially in the poorest countries. What do the actors ask us? They ask us first of all for a clearer policy, a policy simpler to apply, a more readable policy. They often have administrations that are themselves in trouble: we must avoid adding complexity to complexity, it is a European evil. Let us listen to what our interlocutors, especially those in the South, tell us: “Help us, but do not be too complicated”.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I welcome — this is important — the report whose purpose is to contribute to the revision of the European Development Fund and the Development Cooperation Instrument while analysing their relevance and that of the humanitarian aid instrument in relation to the objectives of the European Union's policies. development cooperation and humanitarian aid from the Union. It is reassuring that, according to the evaluations, the objectives of these instruments are largely relevant to policy priorities when they were created and are generally consistent with the ambition of the Sustainable Development Goals. However, as highlighted in the report, it should be noted that a proliferation of crises and the emergence of new political priorities have consistently put financial pressure on the three instruments, which have thus been exploited to their limit. As far as the future is concerned, I am of the opinion that if the Union wishes to maintain its leading position in this field, both in terms of its financial contributions to development cooperation and humanitarian aid and by the appropriateness of its actions in this field, the new post-2020 multiannual financial framework should be able to respond to the EU's global challenges and Understand financial allocations tailored to these challenges. I also congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Guerrero Salom.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the Development Cooperation Instrument, the Humanitarian Aid Instrument and the European Development Fund are important tools provided that they contribute to reducing poverty, hunger and unemployment. This is the key element. Do we have an evaluation report? Was there really the achievement of these objectives? These mechanisms must also support public goods, they must involve local society, self-government and parliaments, so that there is, of course, transparency and, above all, they must take into account whether, where this aid is given, human rights are defended. rights and there is no violation of labor rights. These are the conditions under which these mechanisms will be able to make a real contribution to growth, to tackling poverty and, of course, to hitting unemployment.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: — Madam President, the themes of development cooperation, humanitarian aid instruments and the European Development Fund are very important and important topics without dispute. Consistency debate should also be part of them. Certainly the European Union boasts of helping where it is needed, but isn't this whole debate completely irrelevant when we send our bombs and weapons to some countries in addition to food? Isn't it hypocritical if we destroy these countries without UN approval and isn't it shameful to complicate even such an impossibly complex and explosive situation in these countries? The draft resolution stresses that: “the response to global problems will only be effective if it is common.” But the attack on Syria was led by only three states, with two from the EU, eroding the EU's reputation as a possible mediator and peacemaker across a region that, as it is known, never to do so not oblivious. Partners have to trust us, and tomahails will not help us to trust.

name: Seán KELLY
text: — A Uachtaráin, is féidir lei an aontas a bheith an-bhródúil as an méid a thugaimid do na tiortha is boichte trií na cistí seo; an ciste daonnúil agus an ciste forbartha, agus tá suil against gur féidir linn níos níos mó a thabhairirtha dóibh amach anseo. Ach ag an am céanna, tá an Riocht Aontaithe ag fágáil an Aontais agus measure go mbeidh laghdú suas go EUR 14 billion inár mbuiséad, node an MFF to thugaimid air. Give bhrí sin, tá daoine ag ra ar thaobh amháin gur chart níos mó a thabhairt do na cistí seo, agus aontaím leo, gur chart níos mó a thabhairt do CAP, do na cistí slándála, cosanta, Erasmus agus mar sin de. Ach muna mbíonn na Ballstáit sásta níos mó airgid a thabhairt don Aontas, ní féidir linn is sin a dhéanamh. Gives bhrí sin, molaim of the gach Feisire bru to chur air to MBallstát féin, ardú a thabhairt dúinn san MFF.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Madam President, as Enrique Guerrero, our rapporteur rightly says, the European Union must be a global player in peace and solidarity. Poverty is the cause of many evils which our world suffers, namely hunger, conflict, immigration, and the Union has a duty to rely on its fundamental values in its external action, including, of course, solidarity among peoples. Having led decentralised cooperation operations once, I know the importance of external financing and I know their potential leverage. The Union has a duty to maintain its level of intervention, and even more, as well as to put its expertise at the service of humanitarian organisations. It should, in my view, increase its involvement in the establishment and extension of public services in developing countries, because public services are the real wealth of the poor and must be accessible to all and everywhere.

name: João FERREIRA
text: — Madam President, the problem of the so-called development cooperation policy of the European Union lies not only in a progressive weakening of the resources devoted to this purpose, nor in the fact that the European Development Fund remains outside the EU budget. Apart from the inconsistency of the European Union's sectoral policies with the proclaimed development objectives, it is visible, for example, in the liberalisation and deregulation of international trade and in the blackmail of the implementation of so-called economic partnership agreements, in addition, that is the attempt to condition more and more the way in which development funds are used. They are conditional on the acceptance of European Union policies, for example in the field of migration and the externalisation of borders, as well as the recurring attempt to impose forms of organisation of the economy, society or the political system. This attitude disrespects the legitimate sovereignty of developing countries and does more to defend the neo-colonial ambitions of the European Union, its powers and its economic groups than for the development of these countries.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for these positive words and the support and engagement of Parliament in this file. The Commission will make its proposal for the next MFF on 2 May, and the proposal for the external financing instruments will follow after. Let me conclude by underlining that I am very much looking forward to fruitful discussions with Parliament. The issues at stake are important and numerous, and I am convinced that the upcoming interinstitutional negotiations will be key to ensuring that the EU keeps being a major global actor: standing strong for its values, promoting its interests and effectively assisting its partners so as to jointly ensure a safer and more sustainable future for all. I look forward to continuing the excellent work with the European Parliament and to engaging with you again soon.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, indeed, as Commissioner Nimica pointed out, what we have to do now is look to the future and win the future for development cooperation. It is clear that with these instruments we will live until 2020. But we need to look further and focus on sustainable development goals at the 2030 border. It is true that we need more coherence. It is true that we need simplification, but this can be achieved without the need for development cooperation policy to be subordinated to short-term political strategies that may have a strategic interest. If tomorrow — as I hope — this report is approved by Parliament, it is not a report that will draw the future, but it will be a good basis for us to start discussing with the Commission and the Council the near future of the multiannual financial perspective.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — With the exacerbation of problems within the EU, we are seeing continuous divergence and instrumentalisation of development aid funds to meet expenditure meeting different objectives , among them the contrast to illegal migration. I have already denounced several times that development funds have been diverted by creating new ad hoc mechanisms, often with different purposes and nature and opaque management, such as trust funds. Whereas, development at international and European level has come to define specific commitments on funding but also on the objectives to be achieved, even indicating the deadline by which achieve them, we have not encountered the same goals and deadlines when talking about security and defense. In conclusion, I believe that safety and development need to go hand in hand and coordinated, but I believe that resources should be distinct and separate.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Jean-Paul Denanot, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on a European strategy for promoting protein crop production (2017/2116 (INI)) (A8-0121/2018).

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at a time when we fear an escalation of the conflict between the United States and China and its possible repercussions on the agricultural sector, I have come to tell you about a sector that represents one of the most crucial issues for tomorrow's food security. Whether we consume them directly, such as peas and soy products, or are intended for animal feed, protein plants are at the heart of our diet today. These cultures have immense agronomic interests and play a central role in the transition to more sustainable production systems. Every effort should therefore be made to encourage European farmers to use them and to strengthen their competitiveness.
