Because the future of vegetable proteins in Europe raises another question: what development of our agriculture and what feeding model do we want for future generations? In terms of supply, the signing of the GATT and Blair House agreements and the opening of markets have sealed the European Union's dependence on third countries. As a result, we now import more than 75% of our plant protein supplies from Argentina, the United States and Brazil, and this deficit is growing steadily. Today, countries like China are implementing procurement strategies based on untransparent production contracts with Latin American countries, and the European Union is likely to see its supplies and market stability seriously threatened. This dependency situation leads to irreversible damage to biodiversity, such as deforestation, but also represents a considerable carbon footprint. It runs counter to the demand of European citizens, who are increasingly expressing fears about GMOs, since the majority imported crops, particularly soybeans, are genetically modified. With the following international agreements, whose adjustment variable is inevitably agriculture, and more particularly livestock, can we really afford to put a little more at risk our chain, which is also distinguished by its quality and traceability? Today I am worried about the international situation, but I also have confidence in all the relevant European actors who can help us change the game, be it farmers and their organisations, food producers, scientists, administrations and elected officials. Together, let us set up a medium and long term strategy that Europe is sorely lacking. The European Union must be more ambitious and have a real strategic supply plan that mobilizes agricultural, research, trade and neighbourhood policies. Developing a European sector and limiting imports would reduce pressure on soil and forest in Latin America. This fight against deforestation is at the heart of the Paris climate agreement. But let us be clear: there will be no increase in production if we do not first improve the competitiveness of these crops. Today, growing protein crops remains far less profitable than traditional field crops. How to be surprised then that only 3% of arable land in the European Union is dedicated to proteins? Yet legumes do not lack advantages: they have the unique property of capturing atmospheric nitrogen that allows farmers to use less fertilizer. By generating many co-products valued in green chemistry and for the production of renewable energies, they fit perfectly into the circular economy. I hope that in the next CAP, incentives for the production of nitrogen-fixing plants are not only carried out under areas of ecological interest, but through a set of measures in the first and second pillars, such as crop rotation, crop associations and support for ecosystem services. We must value not only protein-rich crops, but also fodder and grass surfaces, as these are the largest source of protein inputs in Europe. This requires a clear increase in research, greater use of innovation and better territorial structuring of the sectors. Finally, I hope that some crops will be able to have coupled aid which is a valuable tool and will allow farmers to turn more towards pulses. Food sovereignty and security, fight against global warming, better closure of the nitrogen cycle and the rise of our chains: as you will understand, vegetable proteins are at the heart of all the issues we will address tomorrow for the future of our common agricultural policy. It is essential that the forthcoming CAP give them a special place to enhance the services rendered by agriculture and farmers. In conclusion, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and all their collaborators who helped to carry out this report.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: — A European protein strategy is more than necessary. Proteins are the basis of our meat and therefore of paramount importance for our livestock farming. After the mad cow disease in the 1990s, we in Europe rightly banned the use of animal protein in animal feed and vigilance remains necessary. But the European ban on the use of animal meal in animal feed has led to a large number of vegetable proteins from GMO soya from Latin America being imported into Europe. We must try to limit this dependence, and the promotion of other protein crops and the breeding of soya can, for example, be a step in the right direction. But I think we should dare to look at more protein sources. The use of proteins from insects or algae is a really good example of this. But because insects are now considered agricultural animals, they are also covered by the ban from the 1990s. That is why I also clearly ask the Commission to review exactly that and, if possible, adapt the rules for insects to make their full potential possible.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: — Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank and congratulate Mr Jean-Paul Denanot and to pay him a strong tribute to this excellent report. I think we have to stop lying to each other, that we have to stop lying to us. In Europe, we are dependent on vegetable proteins, it has been said: we import more than 90% of vegetable proteins, especially soybeans that are largely transgenic. Our European livestock is fed with GMO soybeans. That is the reality and nobody says so, whereas GMO crops are banned in Europe. We have to get out of this hypocrisy. We must develop a European protein plan, as Jean-Paul Denanot suggests. We must value not only GMO-free protein crops, especially soybeans, but also all seed legumes and forage and grass surfaces, because 70% of the protein comes from these meadows. I call on the European Commission, as has been said, to integrate this protein plan into the CAP after 2020 and to take bold decisions to value proteins in Europe.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, Mr Denanot's report really touches on the serious issue of food security, because it has been shown that protein crops and legume crops have not been sufficiently developed in the European Union. 35% of all these plants and their respective substances are imported into the European Union, and certainly the soybean imported from the United States is genetically modified, which is why there is a huge reaction from both the European Parliament and, of course, from the consumers. China at the same time uses a different strategy, has entered into an exclusive - essentially opaque - agreement with Brazil, has investments in production infrastructure, in port transport and is thus competing, I would say and to a great extent, with the European Union. We must follow the proposals in Mr Denanot's report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, listening to my colleague Denanot, whose work I welcome, I had the impression that I was in this chamber seven years earlier when we were debating the Häusling report. The same words, the same terms, the same expectations, and yet the same result: Europe remains a cruelly importer of protein. We still have a deficit of more than 20 million tonnes to feed mainly our livestock. Certainly, in the last reform of the CAP we introduced coupled aid, but we need coherence beyond incantations. Decisions proposed at the end of last year on areas of ecological interest are now translating into a regression of protein surfaces. The policies proposed to us in the area of circular economy — even though vegetable oils are a by-product of meal production that is used for animal feed — will lead to a decline in protein use and valorization. We must, therefore, all together be consistent first if we are to make progress on this issue.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: — Madam President, one of the major challenges of European Union agriculture is ensuring the need for protein, both for milk production and meat production, but also for human consumption. Protein plants are also a resource with significant environmental benefits, helping to fix nitrogen in the soil, increase soil quality and thus create favourable conditions for organic farming. Supporting protein crops through voluntary green payments and the second pillar should consider increasing the flexibility of support for protein crops. It is important to facilitate the use of existing financial envelopes and to ensure their continuity. At the same time, after 2020, fair implementation is needed at the level of all Member States. However, I draw attention to the need to introduce new forms of support for diversifying the supply of protein plants that can benefit from coupled support, given that they have a high protein content, but also beneficial effects for the soil, such as red clover.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I would like to highlight the need for the EU to finally start addressing this issue. As the report mentions, sufficient protein stocks are indeed a must for the Union's self-sufficiency in food security. It is not entirely happy for the EU to be dependent on imports of any raw material from outside in general. The more so when China, for example, is indirectly holding the Trumps in this area. It is necessary to ensure that we are self-sufficient with regard to protein crop stocks or to ensure sufficient import of such raw materials from reliable and partner countries from which they are not in danger the danger of possible future import problems or an extraordinary rapid cessation of supply. I personally support securing the stockpile of these raw materials with my own hands and adhering to the principles of sustainable development, if this is not possible through our own forces, so turn to partner countries such as for example, Ukraine.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Dear Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, the problem of lack of protein supply in the European Union has been known and present for many years. For the future of European agriculture, it is important to adopt a European strategy to promote protein crops because we now unfortunately depend on imports. I am pleased to say that numerous proposals I have submitted with MEPs from the European People's Party have found their place in this Report. I consider the diversification of crops on agricultural areas necessary, and I welcome the recommendation to reintroduce vegetable proteins such as soybeans, beans, peas and crops such as clover and many other legumes into the systems of crop crops and forage plants. The development of regional protein production and processing chains by associating farmers and better cooperation between crop producers and breeders needs to be supported within the framework of the common agricultural policy, as is important and the introduction of support for protein crops. I welcome European consumers' interest in GMO-free products, as well as encouraging those initiatives that, such as Danube Soybeans, promote the safety and high quality of GMO-free soybean products.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I promise not to request a catch-the-eye in the next debate or in any other debate tonight. This topic is very important and I think our rapporteur, Mr Denanot, gave an excellent speech. It was balanced; he pointed out the situation, which is farcical in Europe and which we have tolerated for too long: on the one hand trying to be too idealistic and on the other hand actually doing more damage. He mentioned about soya being imported: we do not want GMOs, but they are GMO modified. Add to that the carbon footprint of hauling soya halfway across the world. It would be far more sensible to grow it here in Europe and to have the benefit for our farmers – and, indeed, as he pointed out, the added benefits in terms of nitrogen fixing and especially in renewable energy. I was rapporteur for the renewable energy file, and there was a proposal there at one stage to phase out first generation biofuels altogether. Thankfully, that has been rolled back by Parliament. Hopefully, as Mr Denanot has said, we can get a sensible, practical solution and have protein crops grown here in the European Union.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the European Parliament, and especially the rapporteur, Mr Denanot, for preparing this own-initiative report on a European strategy for the promotion of protein crops. The challenges and opportunities facing the European plant protein sector and its importance among EU institutions and stakeholders are well illustrated in this report. As we all know, plant proteins are essential for EU livestock farming as a vital component of animal feed and source of amino acids for livestock. Moreover, plant proteins are now becoming increasingly popular in human food consumption. As highlighted in Parliament’s report, the development of plant protein production in the European Union will not only benefit farmers and producers of animal feed and provide food for consumers, but will also contribute to a wide range of environmental and climatic benefits, such as the ability to fix nitrogen from the atmosphere. In this context, the European Parliament’s own-initiative report is a very welcome and constructive contribution to the Commission’s preparations of an EU protein plan, scheduled for publication by the end of this year. This publication will be accompanied by a high-level EU conference on plant proteins in Vienna this November during the Austrian Presidency of the Council, and I want to acknowledge the interest which the forthcoming Austrian Presidency has shown in this important issue. The Commission’s EU protein plan will aim to develop a viable and sustainable domestic protein supply mindful of the challenges we face. The EU is only 38% self-sufficient in its main source of feed proteins and only 5% self-sufficient for soya meal, which represent a very efficient and, therefore, important source of feed proteins. As such, we are hugely dependent on imports of soya, which have significant global consequences. An EU study in 2013 identified soya expansion as being responsible for 19% of global forest loss between 1990 and 2008, mainly in South America. There are a number of practical reasons which explain why this is such a complex issue to address. These include the agronomic conditions in Europe, the economic profitability of these crops in Europe, the competitiveness of the EU protein crops compared to imports and international WTO commitments, which limit the level of specific EU support permissible for oilseed production. The reality is that there are no silver bullets to address this issue. The scope of the EU protein plan will therefore be broad, addressing all the different domestic sources of plant proteins in Europe, as well as the different types of demand. Within this broad framework, the European protein plan will concentrate on four areas which are also highlighted in Mr Denanot’s report. Research and innovation in plant proteins with respect to yield improvements and better adaptability to EU conditions; the agronomic and environmental benefits of protein crops; the development of different supply and value chains for EU plant proteins and the market potential for EU plant proteins in different market segments. The European Parliament’s report also refers to the importance of support from the common agricultural policy to protein crop cultivation. The common agricultural policy indeed provides a series of measures which directly or indirectly encourage plant protein production in the European Union. The ongoing discussions about reforming the common agricultural policy will provide an opportunity to further confirm policy support for EU plant protein production. Parliament’s report also highlights the importance of research work which will feature prominently in the Commission’s plan. The Commission looks forward to further cooperation with the European Parliament in the development of this protein plan, which will ultimately benefit us all by making Europe more self-sufficient in the provision of essential proteins.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: in writing. — In human nutrition, protein, like energy, is an essential and indispensable component of nutrition that can be supplied in the form of vegetable or animal protein. The cultivation of high protein crops could provide a number of environmental benefits, and increasing the production of high protein plants could make an important contribution to the sustainable development of the European food and agricultural sector. The aim of the report is to discuss the benefits of high protein plants and how to increase the EU's self-sufficiency, to prepare a European strategy for promoting high protein crops, and to consider how the CAP could contribute to increasing cultivation and use of high protein plants. It should be noted that the EU suffers from a significant plant protein deficit, which is dependent on imports of feed from third countries, and this situation does not change despite the intentions and initiatives claimed for more than 15 years and despite the use of by-products in feed materials production of biofuels. The situation in the EU with imports of plant proteins from South America is not sustainable and indicates that we should take more vigorous action, especially to give these imports a more sustainable character. Bearing in mind the above, I am voting in support of this report, but I would strongly emphasise that I am against the cultivation of genetically modified high protein plants, as well as the production of genetically modified foods.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - As draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, I welcome the report before us, which is in line with the requests that we have made. A previous report by the European Parliament noted seven years ago that European protein crop production occupies only 3 -4% of the EU's arable land, while some 70% of our vegetable protein rich raw materials are mainly genetically engineered will be imported. It is clearer than the day that Europe needs a new comprehensive protein policy in food production and agriculture. I am proud that my country has been leading the GMO-free protein self-determination initiatives in the European Union by announcing the National Protein Programme. In the summer of 2017, the European Soya Statement was born on a Hungarian-German initiative. alternative protein crops, replacing imported soybeans with GMO-free European protein crops. Protein crops also contributes to sustainable agricultural production: it improves the carbon balance, diversifies cultivation and reduces the risks of weeds and pests. Nitrogen bound by protein crops can also be used to reduce the amount of nitrogen in the form of fertilisers. The report rightly points out that, in addition to growing its own soy, the replacement of imports should also be encouraged by alternative protein crops such as fodder peas, alfalfa, lupin. And the consumption of protein-rich vegetables also promotes a healthy diet.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Charles Goerens, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on improving debt sustainability in developing countries (2016/2241 (INI)) (A8-0129/2018).

name: Charles GOERENS
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the Committee on Development for entrusting me with the report on debt sustainability of developing countries. It's a topical issue. In particular, the IMF considers that eight African countries are, for the time being, over-indebted. In addition, eight other African countries are in the process of becoming so. This situation challenges us because we are talking about ways to achieve the sustainable development goals. Let us recall from the outset, the use of borrowing is not reprehensible in itself; the problem is to lend lightly. All borrowing must meet the criteria of relevance, efficiency and sustainability. The relevance criterion means that the charges involved in repayment of the debt are justified only if it contributes to financing investments that are still effective after the payment of the last instalment. If, for example, you build a school in 2020, then in 2040, when the last tranche of the loan is repaid, the school can still serve the purpose for which it was intended. Therefore, children must continue to attend this school, teachers and infrastructure must always meet the needs of the moment. The efficiency criterion is met if the added value generated by this investment is real. Finally, the sustainability criterion applies for obvious reasons: we do not borrow to finance the short term but to invest in the future, in the medium and long term. The present report intends to go even further: it aims to empower both borrowers and creditors. With regard to creditors, not only institutional creditors but also others should, in my view, be obliged to respect the democratic principle. In other words, the borrowing developing country must be duly authorized by its parliament to do so. Who other than parliament can express the will of the people? If this is not the case, the creditor should not have the right to sue the country in default. Consequently, the creditor would not have this right if the loan was not approved. It may sound hard, but what is the point of constantly reminding us of our commitment to upholding the democratic principle if we cannot introduce it into the conditionality of European development policy? The Committee on Development also recommended that the principles established by UNCTAD on debt restructuring be respected. In the event of a country's default, for example, the right to human development must prevail over the creditor's right to recover his claim. We are no longer in the 1980s or 1990s, when we decided to administer horse remedies to countries that were unable to repay their loans. We saw what this has done, especially in countries affected by Ebola: those who had not been able to invest in infrastructure due to lack of budget resources were unable to counter the disease and after three days their health care system was on the ground. Does that mean that people in developing countries that do not qualify for borrowing would no longer be eligible for financing? No, other means are possible. In particular, I am thinking of donations financed from official development assistance to support projects or programmes. I am thinking of the budgetary aid that the Commission can give to developing countries. I am also thinking of innovative means of financing, in particular the financial transaction tax. Finally, and I should have started here, let us emphasize that the levy of taxes in borrowing countries is the primary condition for ensuring sustainable financing. Let's also talk about 0.7%. If the European Union, the Commission and Member States combined, were to spend 0.7% on development, as it has repeatedly promised, we would have more than 25 billion more to finance these programmes. Let us not say, therefore, that this is a matter of lack of funds. No! It is a question of financing otherwise. In conclusion, this report is not intended to propose an approach that could cut funds to developing countries, no! We have to borrow differently and borrow better.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Madam President! The problem of debt sustainability of developing countries is an extremely complicated topic that has repeatedly appeared at United Nations conferences on development finance. It is worth pointing out that the main forum for discussions on sovereign debt restructuring remains the International Monetary Fund, which has considerable influence over the European Union and its member states. But the key issue — as the rapporteur mentioned — for the sustainable improvement of developing countries' credit debt servicing capacity is the issue of accountability. This is about the responsibility of those lending to developing countries, as well as the great responsibility that lies with borrowers, that is, countries that benefit from credit. Our group, however, cannot support some of the records in this report calling for the allocation of own resources, such as the FX Transaction Tax and Financial Transaction Tax, to finance developing countries' debt. We believe that tax and fiscal policy remains the responsibility of the Member States and it is up to them to decide on the shape of this policy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the issue of developing countries' debt is crucial to their development. We have certain countries in Africa where public debt reaches 48% of GDP, in Ethiopia it will exceed 50%, we have new players who give loans, we have a new role for China. What the report is working out and rightly says is that debt regulation is needed, debt restructuring is needed in order for growth to occur. We argue that, firstly, there should be a possibility of auditing debt; secondly, there should be a recommendation by the International Court of Justice to restructure debt; thirdly, there should be a hit of tax evasion; fourthly, the creditor should have responsibilities if the loan does not have is approved by the National Parliament, fifthly, there must be a possibility of debt write-off and finally, Mr Mimica, if these principles are important, should they also apply to the regulation and cancellation of debt within the European Union? There is a debt of Greece which is shameful, it is odious debt because Mr Dijsselbloem himself admitted that the debt taken over by Greece, the loans it received were used not for the rescue of the Greek economy but for the rescue of Greek lenders, for the rescue of main shareholders of foreign banks. So look at the question of restructuring the Greek debt and writing off the odious debt, this debt which is shameful and weighs on the Greek people.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: — Madam President, first of all thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for this good report. It is not often that I have the opportunity to say it, so I say it as an introduction. I believe that often our aid creates new dependencies and often borrowing us in debt. It is time to regain a dynamic where we are in the creation of wealth that effectively allows us to get out of aid and does not create new dependencies. Once in the Bible, there was wisdom: after 50 years, debts were cancelled. I don't think we can lock up any people in debt. You are also right when you attack the “vulture funds”. Indeed, it is too easy today, but it is a general concept: man works for the economy, the economy works for finance and finance itself is governed by the market. Behind this, there is no more sovereignty, there is no more development, there is confinement in debt and in the finance that governs. It is a new imperialism that goes against development in Africa and against development in our country. I do not know if the IMF will find the solutions, but I think you are taking the right track and your report is in the right direction.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I consider it important to crack down on bad loans to poorly functioning countries with debt. This is indeed a good thing, both for the EU and, of course, for those individual states, but the aim should be to ensure sustainable development. It is even then that describes the 2030 strategy. This is important in my opinion only with countries that fulfill certain goals and go in the right direction because giving funding to corrupt and bad rulers in Africa, that's what I think is not the European Union's objective. We should not play with the public opinion and wishes of our citizens, because even they would not want to gamble with the EU project as such and provide these loans to unreliable partners, who don't heed our policies and, say, our visions, that I think is not the step in the right direction.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Charles Goerens, for the excellent work on this important report, which underlines worrying debt trends in developing countries. It points out very relevant issues that need to be addressed and is an important contribution to the international debate. Ensuring debt sustainability is essential to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals. For this reason, the debt management capacity of developing countries needs to be further strengthened. We need well-designed and executed debt management strategies, as well as improved data recording, reporting and analysis. Borrowing and lending should take place in a responsible manner and further work by the international community is needed to create incentives for such responsible lending and borrowing, building on existing principles issued by the G-20. Sustainable public finances are contingent on good public financial management, transparency, domestic revenue mobilisation and fighting against illicit financial flows. The European Commission is closely monitoring the debt situation in developing countries and is active in supporting partner countries in managing their debt in a sustainable manner. For instance, we actively support the World Bank’s debt management facility. We will also continue to contribute to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) debt management and financial analysis system. Through its political and policy dialogue with partner countries, the Commission is helping to tackle the most critical weaknesses. Budget support is a central element in our toolbox to help countries in managing their debt sustainability. We continue to monitor countries’ debt sustainability through our regular risk assessment and microeconomic analysis. We are also monitoring debt sustainability in relation to the external investment plan and to blending operations, and we respect internationally agreed debt limits. Our objective is to improve transparency and oversight and to progressively strengthen our partner countries’ public finance management capacity, including investment management and procurement. In parallel, the Commission is also scaling up efforts in support of domestic revenue mobilisation and the fight against illicit financial flows, in line with the Addis Ababa action agenda. On debt sustainability, the Commission works very closely with the World Bank and the IMF. On 28 and 29 May this year, the Commission and the World Bank will organise in Brussels the Debt Management Facility Stakeholders’ Forum, focusing on the rising tide of debt, risk resilience and responsibility. This forum will discuss current challenges of debt policy and management in the context of increasing financing needs for development, the growing levels of debt, complexity of the debt portfolios and uncertain market conditions. It will bring together high-level policymakers from developing and emerging countries, multilateral and bilateral donors, providers of technical assistance and civil society. We count on the Parliament’s participation in fruitful discussions. As regards the International Monetary Fund, the Commission welcomes the approach in the Parliament’s report, which underlines the role of the IMF as a principal forum for discussing issues relating to the restructuring of sovereign debt, and notes that any further work should be carried out in coordination with the IMF. The Commission, however, has reservations regarding the call for the establishment of a multilateral legal framework. The EU Member States, in line with the Commission’s position, have consistently been in favour of applying the current international practice of encouraging a market-based voluntary approach in debt restructuring. This principle is not reflected in the Parliament’s report. Thank you again for putting this crucial issue on the agenda and for this report, which provides a very valuable contribution to the international debate.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: I welcome this important report, which highlights the need to promote more stringent rules in order to strengthen the debt sustainability of developing countries, while making key recommendations that I strongly support. To discourage the provision of lending with zero impact on development; promote financing routes that are not likely to affect future generations; reach agreement on insolvency proceedings of States in default of payment; ensure that the right to development of citizens of developing countries prevails over the right to debt recovery: these are some examples of the approaches proposed in the report that could change the lines in this area. Finally, I would like to stress that the Union, as the world's leading player in development cooperation, must give a new impact to official development assistance by seeking, in particular, to better frame lending to developing countries, while playing an important role in the accountability of the parties involved in sovereign borrowing operations.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Marc Joulaud, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion within the Union (2017/2279 (INI)) (A8-0138/2018).

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Madam President, cohesion policy is a European policy that is unfortunately too little discussed but which, as we know, is essential for our territories. It makes it possible to finance many projects ranging from financing SMEs to vocational training and cooperation between regions. Above all, this policy embodies a Europe that is both concrete and of proximity, as we know, these funds are managed as close as possible to the territories. The proposals for the next budgetary framework of the Union are imminent, and it is clear that we are hearing a lot about the new European challenges of defence, security and the refugee crisis and the reception of refugees. It is of course quite legitimate and necessary for the European Union to adapt to these new challenges, but I would like to say that the objective of cohesion and support for the territories has not become obsolete overnight, quite the contrary. The report that has been entrusted to me shows that Europe must invest more than ever in concrete achievements in order to get closer to citizens and contribute to the improvement of their daily lives. So, of course, let us not be mistaken. It would be wrong to claim that cohesion policy is now fully satisfactory, but in order to guarantee it a future, it is not a matter of defending the status quo but of reinventing it, redesigning and adapting it. The first project concerns — I believe — simplification. With nearly 800 pages, 450 articles and 89 annexes, this policy is, as we know, become illegible. Worse, it is complex, sometimes absurd and dissuades more and more beneficiaries from resorting to it. However, concrete solutions exist to make this policy simpler, more readable and more effective. That is what is clearly evident of a consultation that I wanted to launch with the beneficiaries of European funds in my region of the Pays de la Loire. This survey, which I sent to 150 structures that benefited from these funds, gave rise to a very concrete feedback to illustrate this report and demonstrated a need for simplification, but above all the real added value of European funds for project owners. This survey, which was carried out in a region ranked among the most developed, also confirms that concentrating cohesion policy exclusively on the poorest regions would in fact be a mistake. The report therefore underlines that the coverage of all European regions is not negotiable for the European Parliament. Several recently published studies show that while the least developed regions of Europe have experienced significant growth in recent years, many territories are nevertheless weakened and remain fragile. These territories are in a certain way caught up between, on the one hand, the major metropolises that concentrate development and wealth and, on the other hand, competition with regions that are less developed or less favoured. The real fight will therefore be — I believe — to ensure that cohesion policy as a whole is better adapted to the challenges of today's regions. Of course, it will be a matter of strengthening the social dimension of cohesion policy but also, of course, to take better account of subregional disparities, because our regions, including the most developed ones, face pockets of difficulty and poverty, and they need adequate support, which is not necessarily the case today. It will also be a question of protecting a number of territories that are sometimes forgotten from globalization, such as some rural territories, and of course it will be a question of providing answers differentiated according to the specificities of a number of territories, including ultramarine territories. This is in a few words, very simply, an overview of the report that will be put to the vote tomorrow and must, in a certain way, embody the position of the European Parliament on the future of European regional policy. There would, of course, be said about this. In any case, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs of the other political groups who participated in the negotiations and in this work. I am counting on colleagues tomorrow to support this report and send a signal in favour of a strong Europe at the service of the territories.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: When we talk about the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the European Union, I am convinced that the future of the EU is at stake. If European and Member States' policies cannot substantially reduce the differences in territorial development, they cannot achieve an appreciable increase in the standard of living for people in and within these regions, and the necessary infrastructure investments will not be accelerated by In the most underdeveloped regions of the EU, there will be unforeseen consequences. In the eastern part of the EU, the credibility of European integration as a whole depends on the results of cohesion policy. It would be a terrible mistake to use it as a criminal instrument or to link it to policies that do not serve the purpose of cohesion. The post-2020 cohesion policy needs to be continued and even strengthened, and reforms must focus on simplification. Citizens expect decision-makers to be cleansed of complex and bureaucratic rules. The enlargement of the EU after 2004 was a huge number of challenges, and we were aware of that at the time. I propose that we face this and reinforce our commitment to approximating the development of the Member States.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, responding to economic, social, environmental and democratic challenges requires a collective strategy in order to achieve social justice and develop a fair and inclusive model for the 21st century, which will put at the forefront, not only economic development but, more importantly, the collective and individual well-being of citizens.  Touching upon all the key policy areas, cohesion policy is indeed the right tool to address these challenges. Structural funds have ensured increasing economic and social convergence of European regions, thanks to a very concrete and effective model of solidarity. Cohesion policy has helped vulnerable communities and regions, ensuring they do not fall behind. I saw this with my own eyes on a mission to Slovenia recently and I see it on a regular weekly basis in my own North West England constituency.  Understanding the real impact that Brexit and the loss of the Structural Funds will have for UK regions is crucial. That is why Labour MEPs have called for Brexit regional impact assessments, which must take account of the loss of billions of pounds of EU regional development money, funds that come directly to the poorest areas such as Liverpool, Blackpool and rural Cumbria. The failure of successive UK governments to tell this story is shameful and other Member States should not make the same mistake.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: — Dear Chairman, I thank my colleague Marc Joulaud for his excellent report and excellent work done. What this Report makes clear is that cohesion policy delivers results in practice, that it really leads to a decrease in different levels of development among the regions of the European Union and this is an important message for the adoption of the future budgetary framework where we continue to want a strong and strongly represented cohesion policy. What we can also learn from this Report is that for the success of implementation it is very important to simplify the procedures, that it is very important to have well-prepared projects and bring implementing regulation in time. That is why I welcome the efforts of the European Commission and Commissioner Creţa to start discussing the implementation regulation as early as June this year. This is important for Member States to prepare for the next perspective in time and that after 2020 we have concrete implementation in practice as soon as possible.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Madam President, Commissioner Cretu, developments in recent years at Union level show that urban areas are attracting more and more citizens and are concentrating more economic, social and cultural activities, which is why more attention is needed to be given to the problems in areas periurban and rural adjacent to cities and metropolises. These areas face challenges related to the concentration of the population, but also to the existence of areas of poverty, including in relatively prosperous cities. As such, we need measures to reduce risks, such as social exclusion, problems that remain a major challenge for the Member States and the European Union. I support the need to introduce integrated strategies for sustainable urban development, including within sub-regional territories, as well as improve communication with European citizens, because they need to know better the concrete achievements of cohesion policy and the results of using European funds in the regions where they live. It is important to support medium-sized cities in each Member State, as their development can reduce pressure on larger cities.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first and foremost I would like to commend our dear colleague, rapporteur Jouland, and the Committee on Regional Development on this excellent report, and I would like very much to thank all of you. You have underlined the importance of this policy for improving the lives of millions of people in the European Union. This report captures the very essence of what cohesion policy has helped to achieve so far and what is yet to be achieved. In this regard, your analysis on the 7th cohesion report is to the point. I also welcome the very concrete recommendations on the way forward after 2020. They are in line with many of our own beliefs. In particular, you state very assertively that the coverage of all EU regions is a red line for the European Parliament, and you know very well that I could not agree more with you, and I praise this ambitious approach – ambitious yet realistic. As evidenced in the 7th cohesion report, regional disparities remain important, and the needs are clearly not limited to the poorest regions, as you clearly said. Indeed, pockets of poverty are observed in all kinds of regions, notably in urban areas, where the average living standard is very high. But at the same time we have very poor pockets – very poor communities. Moreover, several middle-income regions still lack capacity to fully benefit from the EU integration process. They have failed to move to higher-value-added activities. Europe has probably never needed solidarity and equality more than today. Phenomena such as globalisation, climate change, terrorism and social exclusion are exerting polarising forces inside our European Union. The temptation of isolation is growing, and our European project is at risk. We have to be honest and recognise this. The need to continue cementing our Union is very important, and clearly the best answer post-2020 is a strong cohesion policy for our regions, and in the meantime the Commission is preparing the ground, notably by strengthening smart specialisation strategies. I believe this innovative and cooperative approach to policy-making is the best way to help regions find their competitive niche and become resilient. It is very important. I am so glad to see that you also call for an intensification of smart specialisation strategies. In this context, your report mentions the pilot actions we have launched to help regions in industrial transition build their strategies for their regional transformation. This should be ready by the end of 2018, and I remain at your disposal to update you on the progress we have made as soon as we get the first results. I would like to conclude by talking about the implementation of cohesion policy, which is very important. We share the view that radical simplification and faster delivery of results are needed. The options we are working on are largely in line with those proposed in your report, such as taking account of the different administrative capacities across Member States; a single set of rules; stronger synergies with other EU instruments; and a revised allocation system to better reflect the variety of challenges faced by EU territories. We all know that the proposal for the next Multiannual Financial Framework is just around the corner. My only concern is that cohesion policy remains the main investment policy for the European Union, that it carries on supporting growth and improving the conditions of investment. Knowing our common aspirations, I am sure that we will make our way through the negotiations with good cooperation and constructiveness.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. — The seventh Cohesion Report has given us a lot of good evidence that cohesion policy is beneficial to all European regions, both less and better developed. On the other hand, however, it pointed to a number of lingering problems, the solution of which still lies ahead. I believe that a transparent, well-targeted and accessible cohesion policy should be the backbone of EU investment. It is a tool that best addresses challenges in infrastructure, environmental investment, human capital investment, entrepreneurship or public administration reform. In order for her to continue fulfilling her role beyond 2020, however, she must have a strong position in the EU budget. It is therefore essential to maintain at least the same financial level as in 2014-2020. It is also extremely important to simplify this policy considerably — so that potential beneficiaries have easy access to funding.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: in writing. — I think everyone will agree that cohesion policy has played an important role in defeating the economic crisis. However, the Cohesion Report presented by the EC shows that there are some weaknesses in this policy that we need to eliminate. In 2015, almost ¼ Europeans were declared at risk of poverty or social exclusion. Bearing in mind the figures on the unemployment rate of youth and those living in poverty, it should be noted that the prospects for rapid improvement are slim. The Union is as strong as its weakest links are. Therefore, the Union's well-being will not be average GDP growth and real results in the fight against poverty. This fight must be based on long-term investment rather than ad hoc subsidies, and this is the Union's cohesion policy. So I can't imagine the possibility of cutting resources for cohesion policy. We are also seeing a new phenomenon of deepening differences within regions, and in relatively affluent regions, poverty enclaves. Some territories were found “in the middle income trap.” It is therefore appropriate to fine-tune the indicators taken into account for the allocation of funds, alongside GDP per capita. They need to be flexible, with an emphasis on the overall unemployment rate and the unemployment rate of young people. A significant threat to the integrity of cohesion policy is the plans to integrate the ESF into the proposed social investment fund. The ESF has an undeniable territorial dimension and should therefore remain an integral part of the cohesion policy.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: in writing. — I would like to congratulate Marc Joulaudd on his report. I am very pleased that the report highlights the potential for further investment in the areas of culture, education, heritage, youth and sport in terms of job creation, ensuring economic growth and improving social cohesion. This is of particular importance for less developed regions and rural areas. I also believe that it is crucial to support and strengthen strategies for the development of cultural and creative industries that are closely linked to innovation and creativity. I hope that in the future the European Commission will take a greater account of the role of culture, education, youth and sport in strengthening cohesion in the Union and analyse the impact of specific projects in these areas. This will make better use of potential synergies between European structural and investment funds.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on important political issues (Rule 163 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: — Madam President, I am talking about Romania, because in Bucharest, the Minister of Education cut the budgets of universities that did not applaud his appointment in office. Political servitude is rewarded with money. Unfortunately, the University of Bucharest loses hundreds of places because it dared to criticize the minister's superficial attitude towards plagiarism. In a way, it is no wonder: the government is led by a person whose literacy has failed. It is not the only one: a minister, Daea, became popular by saying enormities weekly. Busy with this, he did not find time, in 2017, to come even once to the meetings of the Agriculture Council. Again, it is no exception: in the majority of them, PSD-ALDE ministers skipped the work of the Council of the European Union. Next year, when Romania assumes the presidency of this institution, they will come unprepared, like falling from the Moon. Citizens go out again for a European Romania. Two civic organizations that organised the protests recently invited LIBE members to come to Bucharest on 12 May. All of you come and see what the Socialists and Liberals are doing in my country!

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Madam President, today the Court ruled that 23-month-old Alfie Evans should not be allowed further treatment for his condition. I pay tribute to the NHS staff who have worked tirelessly for him and who care for little boys and girls like Alfie every day, but Tom and Kay are being denied the right to keep their child alive with the help of doctors in Italy who stand ready to help. What they want is what every parent would want for their child. They want Alfie to be given every chance to prolong his short life. They don’t want his life to be a matter of legal dispute; they want to care for him in the best way they know how. It is not clear to me why his parents are being denied the right to decide the most dignified outcome for their own child. I hope a solution can be found with Alfie’s best interests at heart; one that respects the love that parents have for him as well as the dignity and sanctity of his life. As an MEP there is frustratingly little that I can do for them, but as a parent, I stand in solidarity with Tom and Kay at this difficult time. Like millions of others, I am also praying for the beautiful, strong and courageous Alfie.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: - Madam President! Eight years ago, a Polish president was killed in a tragic disaster near Smolensk in Russia, along with 85 members of Polish elites. He flew to Russia to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the murder of some 15,000 Polish officers and police officers murdered by Soviet Russia in 1940. Until today, this plane crash has not been explained. The Russians gave neither the wreckage of the Tu-154 plane nor the black boxes to Poland. I think the international public should pressure Russia to finally reckon with this issue.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Madam President, today the amendments to the Education Act in Latvia come into force. By 2021, bilingual secondary education will be abolished. For Russian speakers – 37% of the population – everything will be in Latvian. At the same time, the Education Act preserves the possibility of teaching in the official languages of the European Union. Similar changes in Ukraine in educational law were criticised by the Venice Commission as discrimination against Russian speakers. This is also contrary to European values.  The Latvian reform is ill—founded. Graduates of Russian schools have no problems with the Latvian language. Sixty percent of their studies in secondary school is in Latvian. Behind this controversial reform is the Latvian Unity Party: this is a shameless election campaign. We cannot tolerate the struggle with the linguistic diversity of the Union. This reform is also a security risk for Europe: it leads to marginalisation of the Russian minority and provides opportunities for foreign manipulation.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: Madam President, yesterday hundreds of thousands of people were demonstrating again in Barcelona peacefully, as we always do, to call for the release of political prisoners and the return home of exiles. Today, Jordi Sànchez and Jordi Cuixart, two of the political hostages, are serving six months in pre-trial jail; but the Spanish State and those who feed this spiral of repression and this undemocratic drift will not get away with it, because they will not be able to fight so many tons of dignity of an entire people; because the fiction they have invented to justify repression that if violence, that if coup d'état, that if rebellion will fall like a castle of letters, and because more and more opinions in Europe say that harassment of fundamental, civil and political rights cannot be allowed. And this Europe will always be our Europe.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: — Madam President, I believe that there are topics that we would no longer have to discuss in the 21st century. Yet yet again this year there was an annual march to celebrate Latvian veterans who fought alongside German Nazis during World War II. Once again, SS veterans could recall undisturbed their crimes against humanity, in an area that has seen the horrors of the Holocaust firsthand. I find it monstrous that these marches are still occurring, and I want to thank everyone who is protesting against them. Nazis belong in sewers or in prisons, and not in the streets where they can present their twisted version of history. If the EU wants to play the role of moral authority, it must strongly and uncompromisingly oppose these marches and stop them. We owe it to ourselves and those who experienced Nazi monstrosities on their own skin. So I call on the European Commission and the European Council to do so.

name: Martin SONNEBORN
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. For reasons, I would like to point out that it is forbidden to shoot cruise missiles to foreign countries. And to our old colleague Lambsdorff, who is eagerating himself because Germany has canceled its participation in this nonsense, I would like to say: Dear Count, if you absolutely want to go to war — no one is stopping you. Skydiving has a certain tradition in the FDP. Winking smiley. We can't send the Bundeswehr, though. It's broken. The most likely to drop defective military equipment at Assad's Palace. Such a leopard 2 from a height of 8,000 meters bangs in there. Similar to the German NATO tanks in Afrin, where the misguided by the Bosporus is currently waging a brutal war of aggression. One more word to President Macron: you make great speeches at the Sorbonne. They completed the French elite career. You should know that the authoritative heritage of your culture is the enlightenment: first it is enlightened, then shot — not the other way around. How will you justify yourself to Voltaire and Diderot? Why don't you ask your wife, she could have been familiar with both of them personally.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: — Dear Chairman, cross-border pollution is a major problem that must be influenced by European institutions. It is inadmissible for residents of Slavonski Brod to suffer for ten years the effects of air pollution from a refinery in the neighbouring state in Bosanski Brod. At European Union level, we have developed financial instruments whose use depends on the will of countries and entrepreneurs to report projects. However, when it comes to cross-border endangering people's health then the decision should not only be on the state and the entrepreneur. The institutions of the European Union must play a greater role in influencing tackling the cross-border source of pollution. Thus, the EU funds available in Bosnia and Herzegovina must be able to focus on the modernisation of the Bosnian ship refinery. The residents of Slavonski Brod have the right to clean air and we are obliged through the EU project to ensure the highest standards of ecological production in Bosanski Brod, with the guarantee that pollution will be discontinued, and I urge the European Commission to engage in addressing this issue.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Madam President, dear colleagues, we are witnessing effervescent times in which the subject of combating terrorism must become priority, national and European policy, and I am not just talking about everything that stands for state policy, but I would also like to emphasise responsibility private domain. Both state institutions and large companies should work together in detecting and combating discourses based on discrimination, hatred and affecting human rights, freedoms and dignity. I stress the importance of the European Union Code of Conduct against hate speech, and I also call on national and international companies to adopt it. A unified, common policy of monitoring and prevention between national and international bodies and companies is imperative. Even social media understood the importance of the topic and expressed their willingness to adhere to the European Union Code of Conduct against hate speech. National laws should be brought into line with the requirements of this in the field of prevention and combating terrorism.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — Madam President, honourable Members, we have spoken several times in this House about the fact that there are double standards in the European Union and Parliament. These double standards create a different lifestyle, a different standard in both parts of the Union — the eastern and western. A concrete example of this is the attitude of some of the colleagues in the European Parliament towards the development of tourism in Bulgaria, for example. Bulgaria needs to develop the infrastructure in tourism because of its location and its natural resources. A number of colleagues in this hall are actively hindering the development of winter tourism, say in Bulgaria in one of the main mountains — Pirin. It is, of course, about the Rhodope Mountains and Vitosha Mountain, but especially about the Pirin Mountain. There is an obstacle to the construction of new facilities. When I asked colleagues in the room “How many facilities were built for last year in Germany” — because this colleague is German — “and in the past few years ago?” she could not answer. It's about fifty facilities instead of one. This, honourable Members, is hypocrisy and a double standard. And it dooms the eastern states to a low standard of living and migration, which cannot be allowed.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President. On April 9, the Spanish Senate rejected a proposal for an international congress to review the historical dimension of the Gernika bombing. The Condor Legion used this war against defenceless civilians — a crime against humanity — to test what it would subsequently commit in the rest of Europe during World War II. This refusal is a consequence of the Spanish policy on historical memory, repeatedly condemned by the main international institutions. The lack of training in fundamental rights, which the United Nations denounces in the Spanish judiciary, or the resistance to assume its own diversity, are part of this unhealed wound. Today, now, 100,000 families are still looking for their families in gutters and mass graves. The same judiciary that denies them truth, justice and reparation invents accusations of rebellion to disable the absolute majority newly elected by citizens in Catalonia. The same judiciary has repeatedly been convicted of not investigating crimes of torture. A scandal in any other Member State.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: — Madam President, I would like to begin by having a thought for the families of the Saharawi people who died in the plane accident near Algiers. We demand the immediate and unconditional release of all Saharawi political prisoners and denounce the inhumane conditions of their imprisonment. Gdeim Izik's prisoners, sentenced to very brutal sentences ranging from 20 years imprisonment to life imprisonment, were brutally dispersed in mid-September 2017 to seven different prisons across Moroccan territory, mostly more than 1,000 kilometres from their families. Conditions of detention in prisons in Morocco prompted Saharawi prisoners to go on hunger strike for 33 days: a slow death for claiming the rights of the Saharawi people to self-determination. Together with many Members of the European Parliament from six different political groups, we co-signed a parliamentary question addressed to Mrs Mogherini expressing our concern and concern about the situation of political prisoners. Morocco does not respect international law. The European Union must play the role of mediator and put pressure on Morocco about its action and the conditions of detention in Moroccan prisons. On the other hand, the Council today signs a fisheries agreement... I send a message of solidarity from the peoples of Europe to the Saharawi people and all political prisoners. Viva el Sáhara free!

name: João FERREIRA
text: Madam President, the bombing of Syria by the United States, the United Kingdom and France with the support of NATO, the European Union and Israel represents an unacceptable act of aggression, in flagrant violation of the United Nations Charter and international law. Under the pretext of an alleged and unproven use of chemical weapons in Doua, whose responsibility Syria rejects, the bombing was carried out hours before the expected arrival in the country of international experts who were going to investigate these allegations. The perpetrators of the bombing have a known history of lies and inventions of pretext to carry out aggressions, such as those that took place in Iraq and Libya. Over the past eight years, they've trained, armed and funded terrorist groups for a proxy war. In view of the defeats inflicted on these groups, they have made a new and serious step in Syria's aggression and destruction operation. Here we affirm our full solidarity with Syria and its people in the resistance and struggle in defence of their sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity, in defence of the right to decide free of interference, their destiny.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I think it is only recently that the public at large has become aware of the extent of pollution by plastics, both on land and at sea, and are now expecting solutions from us politicians. Thankfully, we are about to do so and I am honoured to be rapporteur for the EPP in the Committee on Fisheries (PECH) in this regard. Some of the statistics are truly shocking. For instance, the EU sends about half of its collected plastics waste abroad, which is a disgrace. Up to 13 million tonnes of plastic waste ends up in the world’s oceans every year. The damage to marine environments is estimated to be at least EUR 8 billion per year.  We are totally dependent on plastics. If you go into a shop, the chances are that you will be given your goods in a plastic bag. Our normal toiletries all come in plastic. Children’s toys, insulation, medical devices: plastics. So we need to do something about it. We particularly need to put an end to the once-only use of plastics. They need to be recyclable, they need to be reusable and, above all, we must ensure that we eliminate plastic pollution by 2030. I look forward to playing my part in that.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, media freedom is essential to democracy, but since 2009 the Iranian authorities have systematically targeted BBC Persian Service journalists based in London and their families in Iran. Many of these journalists are European Union citizens. In 2017, the Iranian authorities commenced a criminal investigation, alleging that the work of these journalists is an offence against Iran’s national security. This was accompanied by an asset-freezing injunction, preventing over 100 current and former journalists from buying or selling property inside Iran. Arrests and detention of family members in Iran and ongoing surveillance and harassment – including threats to the children of journalists in London – continue, as does the spread of fake news designed to discredit female journalists especially. I am urging High Representative Mogherini to raise this matter urgently with the Iranian authorities, because we must stand against these attempts to silence journalists in Europe.

name: Marek JUREK
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday thousands of people took part in a march for the sanctity of life in Warsaw, Szczecin and other Polish cities. It was not organized by the government or by any other political force. It was simply an expression of the moral convictions of Polish society. It would be nice for everyone to realize that, especially those in this chamber who are attacking Polish society for actions in favour of the rights to life of the weakest.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: — Dear Chairman, the European Commission report on the progress of the Western Balkans countries is an opportunity to send clear messages and continue our work on the integration of this region, although financial and political assistance has not been sufficient so far. IPA money of 42 euros per capita in Bosnia and Herzegovina per year is lower than ours we have here for coffee in this Parliament. All these countries have the will to be and become members of the European Union, but that will should not be taken for granted. Europe needs these countries and these countries need Europe. These countries still show that we are one desirable club, and the Western Balkans need Europe to strengthen security, expand its market and create lasting peace in a tumultuous region. That's why these countries should not be ranked in A, B, C groups but to keep them in one package where they are strongly interconnected. Every mistake we make will be taken advantage of by other countries. If we don't do what we need to do, Russia, Turkey, Saudi Arabia will use every mistake and punish us for it.

name: Miroslavs MITROFANOVS
text: – Madam President, I would like to call on the Members of the European Parliament and the leadership of their countries to change their priorities. At the present moment, there is no more important global issue than the preservation of peace. Mankind is balancing on the edge of war. In recent months, we have seen the excessive reaction of Western countries to the poisoning of the former Russian spy in the United Kingdom. This was followed by the excessive military reply to the obscure case of the use of chemical weapons in Syria.  I am an ethnic Russian and a Latvian citizen. I am not going to judge whether either Russia or the West is guilty in the recent aggravation. In my opinion, it is not a fruitful approach to look at who is guilty when the situation is developing in a fast and dangerous manner. But I may – and I have to – speak on behalf of my people, my voters: the residents of Latvia. We live on the frontline between the West and Russia – our people will suffer first and most dramatically if a war begins. We strongly ask the governments of the EU countries, the USA and Russia to stop moving towards war. We ask the European Parliament to play a more active role in the de—escalation of the conflict between the West and Russia. Let us give the globe a chance.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: — Madam President, Ryanair crew members in Portugal promoted a strike in early April demanding compliance with Portuguese labour legislation and contesting the deterioration of working conditions, denouncing abusive disciplinary processes, psychological conditioning, threats of transfer of base and disrespect for the laws of parenting. The courageous fighting action, which we jointly welcome here, had a shameful response from the multinational with threats to reduce the operation and, more seriously, in flagrant violation of national legislation, measures to replace the crews on strike, relocating base crew members in other countries with threats of Disciplinary lawsuits, career freeze and redundancies to anyone who refused this demand. Threats, blackmail and persecution which continued to end the strike, in an assertion of impunity of that multinational company operating on the assumptions of the Single Market and the Single European Sky, with the consent and complicity of the European Commission, which has not expressed its opinion on such serious facts. There is full evidence of the consequences of liberalisation and the imperative need to defend the public management of the aviation sector.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Madam President! As a Hungarian representative of Transcarpathia, I am delighted that the FIDESZ-KDNP won the Hungarian election on 8 April, so it will continue to be the political government of Hungary in the Hungarian national interests. It is a government that seeks to preserve Hungarian identity, language and culture in Hungary, as well as in Hungarian territories abroad. Since 2014, the Hungarian community in Ukraine of about 150 thousand people has been more than 180 times by anti-Hungarian atrocities. The existence of which power tried to make impossible by restricting laws — see the linguistic provisions of the new education law or the abolition of language law favourable to minorities — where they were incited against them in the media. At other times, paramilitary organisations marched with impunity, chant anti-Hungarian slogans and intimidating the population, or blew up the headquarters of Hungarian advocacy organisations. Hungary alone raised its voice and provided political assistance against the grievances suffered by the Hungarian community in Transcarpathia. While the other times so active rights protection organisations and the European Union remained silent or went beyond the infringements with empty phrases. It was therefore vital for the Hungarians in Transcarpathia that Hungary should remain a government that stands out and protects this handful of Hungarian communities.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: Madam President, the Hostelcur Gijón team, formerly known as 'Club Patín Gijón Solimar', is a modest, neighborhood hockey club — specifically in the La Calzada district in Gijón — but its sports team, its management, its players and all its fans are universal. Recently the women's senior team won their fifth European Cup, five European Cups! and yet I wonder why sports in minority disciplines, and even more women's, continue to endure a double penalty against public opinion. I therefore call on the European Commission to improve the programmes within Erasmus+ to encourage sport, always with a gender perspective. Congratulations, Hostelcur, congratulations!

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, recently the deeply concerning news broke that there has been a data breach at the largest news organisation in Ireland: Independent News and Media. Potentially hundreds of thousands of emails may have been compromised, and to date we know that 19 individuals were singled out for a data interrogation. Included on that list were investigative journalists and lawyers who worked on one of the biggest tribunals in the history of the state. The protection of privacy for journalists is not just fundamental to how they do their work, but it is also critical to their safety, and the safety of their sources. The recently retired chairman of that media company, Leslie Buckley, ordered that interrogation. Why would the Chair of a media company order such a data interrogation, why were those specific individuals singled out and why was the tab for that interrogation picked up by a company which is based in Wales? I would hazard a guess that if you draw a line between all these questions, you will find one single common denominator: Denis O’Brien.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, last week the Commission introduced a new policy for consumers and, in the framework of it, presented a legislative regulation that identifies sales as a deceptive and illegal practice food in the same package and with the same brand, but with a different composition. I very much welcome this initiative because, since the beginning of my mandate, I have been making efforts for the Commission to come up with a solution to the problem of dual food quality in the European Union. So I am glad that the Czech Commissioner Jourová has put forward this new legislation. Within the Council of Ministers, the Czech Minister of Agriculture Marian Jurečka repeatedly submitted a proposal for a solution. And I also want to stress that it was other Czech colleagues, especially Olga Sehnalova, who has been intervening in the long term about solving this issue. Of course, ministers and MPs from other Member States have also done their work, and we will need us to join forces to bring this legislation together as part of the legislative process to a successful end for the benefit of consumers in the internal market.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, as a representative of a large Kashmiri diaspora in the north-west of England and as a human rights campaigner, I have always stood in solidarity with the people in Indian-occupied Kashmir who are fighting against military occupation. Sadly, the situation for civilians in Indian Occupied Kashmir (IOK) is worsening. Last week, four civilians and an Indian soldier were killed in a gun battle. These terrible deaths provoked further violence between protesters who had gathered. This incident occurred in a context of growing human rights violations, particularly against women. Recently, the abhorrent practice of braid chopping has been used against women. These terrible attacks deny women of their dignity and are extremely worrying. The Indian State enjoys complete impunity for these human rights violations and this is unacceptable. I am saddened to see, for instance, that India sits unperturbed at the Commonwealth Summit this week, whilst my Kashmiri women friends demonstrate outside on the streets of London. I therefore call on the High Representative to strongly condemn the use of force against civilians, and to use all diplomatic means in her power to deescalate the situation.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Madam President, I have such a comment on the very important directive we are discussing these days, the directive on combating money laundering. Fighting organised crime is extremely important, it's a very important topic. On the other hand, one must always think about what that legislation specifically looks like. And I stand out here for the reason that recently in the Czech Republic, Czech antiquaries, people, small business people who are honestly doing their business and are afraid of the fact that if a directive is adopted in the form as debated here, it will not penalise money laundering, but will bully small traders, small business owners and will significantly complicate their work. And we should take such voices very seriously, they are EU citizens, and think if the legislation we are enacting, which is passed in good faith, cannot, on the contrary, harm and work there where it should not work, i.e. harm small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: — Madam President, dear colleagues, World Tuberculosis Day was celebrated on 24 March. Although it should be a festive moment, at the level of the European Union this moment is far from a joy. 2017 was a record year in terms of increasing cases of tuberculosis, considered one of the most aggressive diseases. In this context, we should leave festivism aside and strongly call on the European Commission's Directorate-General for Health to speed up the implementation of the recommendations of the European Parliament Resolution of 5 July 2017 on the effective fight against Tuberculosis, HIV-AIDS and Hepatitis C. Without a generalised programme, applicable across all Member States, and without a subsidisation of tests and treatments for disadvantaged categories, in a few years, it will probably be impossible for us to control the spread of this disease.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: I would like to inform the European Parliament that a very important European citizens' initiative, the indigenous national minorities living in the European Union, about 50 million EU citizens, has gathered the required number of signatures, and even 25 percent more than the minimum required. Accordingly, in a few months, the Minority Safe Pack will be on the Commission's table, and then Parliament will certainly be able to deal with it. One of the conditions for registration of the initiative was that its subject matter should not fall outside the scope of the Commission's legislative initiative. The Commission will therefore, following the necessary consultations and investigations, submit proposals to adopt legislation at EU level in the area indicated. It is time for the EU to deal with this issue, because it is evident — a successful citizens' initiative confirms — that this is an unresolved problem of citizens, which can only be dealt with in a European framework, and that national minorities expect a response from the Union.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: — Madam President, recently, the European Commission presented an action plan to improve the mobility of troops and military equipment on the European continent. There is talk of a military Schengen. Given that Romania is placed on the eastern border of the European Union, it is clear that it will play an extremely important role when discussing joint defence objectives. Thus, I find it deeply unfair the attitude of some Member States, such as the Netherlands, who have been opposed to Romania's accession to the Schengen area for years, although all European institutions recognise that my country meets the criteria for accession. It is a discriminatory and unfair attitude. Romania cannot be an important actor only for joint defence objectives. Romanians deserve full access to the free movement of goods and persons as well. It is clear that the opposition of countries, such as the Netherlands, is connected with their own economic situation and domestic policy issues. I am afraid that the risk that such an attitude puts on the credibility of the European project is not understood. The future of the European Union can only be greater solidarity between the Member States. Any other approach means that this project is vulnerable.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I would like to address myself in my minute of the future of cohesive funds, because I consider this to be an extremely important topic. The European Commission will present a proposal for the future of cohesion policy in the following month. This is what the States, the regions are waiting for, of course, the beneficiaries of this aid. I would be very keen to see the cohesion policy, despite the challenges of Brexit or the new challenges of the defence community, sufficient resources precisely to help the development of the poor regions, because to focus on reducing the difference between regions, that is, I think, the main backbone force of Europeanism, the EU. The achievement of thematic objectives should certainly remain, but I think it would be good for the Commission to also hear calls from the Member States concerning their needs. And what is our greatest pain, I find it important to mention — simplification. Simplification, simplification, because the drawdown of European funds is often discouraged by excessive bureaucracy.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The item on the agenda is thus concluded.
